|STARTSENT| Every day newspaper and magazine articles and radio and TV stories report on cloud computing. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The phrase “in the cloud” has entered into our colloquial language. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| You may have heard that the United States government has initiated a “cloud initiative,” or that nearly |NUMBER| percent of the developers at Microsoft are currently working on “cloud-related” products, or that a phone or service stores its data in the cloud. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The cloud is therefore this amorphous entity that is supposed to represent the future of modern computing. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In reality, the cloud is something that you have been using for a long time now; it is the Internet, along with all the associated standards and protocols that provide a set of Web services to you. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| When you draw the Internet as a cloud, you are representing one of the essential characteristics of cloud abstraction. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In the cloud, resources are pooled and partitioned as needed, and communications are standards-based. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The Internet was begun as a network of networks, with an architecture that was redundant and could survive massive disruption. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| What the original system architects of the Internet could not have anticipated is that the size of resources attached to it would become massively scalable, which is the second characteristic of cloud computing. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| infrastructure, for example, which is described in this book in Chapter |NUMBER| spans |NUMBER| datacenters around the world with over a million computers; infrastructure that Google now leases out to developers upon which applications may be staged. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| So the third and equally as important characteristic of cloud computing is that the cloud is a “utility” and that services are provided using a model. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A computing utility has been a dream of computer scientists and industry luminaries for several decades. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| With a utility model of computing, an application can start small and grow to be enormous overnight. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This democratization of computing means that any application has the potential to scale, and that even the smallest seed planted in the cloud may be a giant. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Cloud computing will affect your life in the following ways in the next ten Applications in the cloud will replace applications that are local to your devices. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Information will become cheaper, more ubiquitous, and easier to find because the cloud makes it cheaper to scale applications and connections to always-on networks such as wireless carriers that make the information always available. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| xxv Introduction The cloud will enable new social services by connecting users via social networks that are constructed using multiple cloud services. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| New applications will be easier to create and will be based on standard modular parts. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| It will lessen the role that proprietary operating systems have in our daily computing. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| You will be connected through the cloud wherever you are and at all times. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Frankly, it is hard to predict what new capabilities the cloud may enable. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The cloud has a trajectory that is hard to plot and a scope that reaches into so many aspects of our daily life that innovation can occur across a broad range. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Many technologically savvy people have told me they understand what the fuss about cloud computing is; in fact, they believe there is nothing new about cloud computing, at least from a technological standpoint. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Indeed, they have a point. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The technologies that enable cloud computand resource virtualization, thin clients (browsers, for example), virtual private networks and tunneling, and all technologies that existed before anyone ever began to talk about cloud computing. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| That is all true. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Cloud computing is a revolutionary way of architecting and implementing services based on evolutionary changes. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Cloud Computing Bible attempts to explain how this all came about. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| How to Read This Book Cloud Computing Bible is made up of |NUMBER| chapters in five parts. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| To read this book and get the most out of it, you should know about basic computer operations and theory. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| You should be able to turn a computer on and know what operating system is running, how processing and is used, and be able to connect with a browser to different Web sites. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| You should understand the basic user interface elements used by many browsers, such as Microsoft Internet Explorer, Mozilla Firefox, Apple Safari, or Google Chrome. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| These are basic skills without which it would be hard to effectively maximize the value contained in this book. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| If you have these skills, Wiley publishes a number of introductory computer books that will give them to you. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| It matter which type of computer operating system you use because most of cloud computing is Indeed, as time goes by, it may not matter whether you use a computer at all. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Mobile devices such as smartphones and tablets are on their way to displacing computers in many venues. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| If you have some familiarity with smartphones, that would be helpful in understanding the last part of this book on mobile-based cloud applications, but it a necessity. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Part I of the book, called “Examining the Value Proposition,” defines what cloud computing is and why you should be interested in it. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This vocabulary, along with description of cloud architectures xxvi Introduction and types, will allow you to discuss cloud computing in a standard way and serves to give you a framework over which you can place all the different service types that make cloud computing such a rich area. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Part II, called “Using Platforms,” looks at the fundamental features that make a cloud computing application unique. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| You get a background in the concepts of abstraction and virtualization, along with methods for examining how applications are scaled. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This part contains several chapters of vendor-specific services that are illustrative of different cloud computing models. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In several chapters, I discuss vendors that are thought leaders in different fields of cloud computing. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| For infrastructure, chosen to highlight Amazon Web Services, and for platforms and services, you learn about the efforts of Google and Microsoft in cloud computing. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Part III, “Exploring Cloud Infrastructures,” contains two chapters about managing the cloud and working with the cloud securely. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The cloud builds on standard distributed networking technologies, applied over systems with large resources, often over federated systems and services. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In Part IV, “Understanding Services and Applications,” the first two chapters describe Service Oriented Architecture and of which are important principles in building cloud applications so they are efficient and moving applications to the cloud. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The remaining chapters in Part IV describe different types of applications in common use in the cloud today. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Those applications are the most highly developed ones in the cloud and have the largest number of users and services. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The examples chosen are online backup and storage, Webmail, online productivity applications, messaging, and online media, particularly using streaming technologies. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The book rounds out with two chapters on “Using the Mobile Cloud,” Part V. These chapters describe the rise of the smartphone and its predecessor, the feature phone. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| These phones are supported by a host of Web services. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Since |NUMBER| more traffic has been flowing over wireless networks than wired networks, so it would be hard to underestimate how much impact mobile devices have on the cloud. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| For vast portions of the world, the cell phone is the only computer most people will know. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Mobile Web services use different protocols and technologies and can take into account location and other user profile information that can use the cloud to create a rich user experience. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Please dive into whatever chapter interests you. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| I hope you enjoy reading about cloud computing as much as I enjoyed writing about it. |ENDSENT|

|STARTSENT| Contacting Us If, after reviewing this publication, you feel some important information was overlooked or you have any questions concerning cloud computing, you can contact us and let us know your views, opinions, complaints, or suggestions for the next revision. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| You can reach the author, Barrie Sosinsky, at the following e-mail bsosinsky@mind |URL| xxviii Part I Examining the Value Proposition IN THIS PART Chapter |NUMBER| Defining Cloud Computing Chapter |NUMBER| Assessing the Value Proposition Chapter |NUMBER| Understanding Cloud Architecture Chapter |NUMBER| Understanding Services and Applications by Type IN THIS CHAPTER Defining cloud computing Learning about cloud types Understanding the paradigm shift that is cloud computing Comparing the benefits and disadvantages of cloud systems Defining Cloud Computing Cloud computing refers to applications and services that run on a distributed network using virtualized resources and accessed by common Internet protocols and networking standards. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| It is distinguished by the notion that resources are virtual and limitless and that details of the physical systems on which software runs are abstracted from the user. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In an effort to better describe cloud computing, a number of cloud types have been defined. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In this chapter, you learn about two different classes of those based on the deployment model and those based on the service model. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The deployment model tells you where the cloud is located and for what purpose. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Public, private, community, and hybrid clouds are deployment models. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Service models describe the type of service that the service provider is offering. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The best-known service models are Software as a Service, Platform as a Service, and Infrastructure as a SPI model. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The service models build on one another and define what a vendor must manage and what the responsibility is. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Cloud computing represents a real paradigm shift in the way in which systems are deployed. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The massive scale of cloud computing systems was enabled by the popularization of the Internet and the growth of some large service companies. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Cloud computing makes the long-held dream of utility computing possible with a infinitely scalable, universally available system. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| With cloud computing, you can start very small and become big very fast. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| why cloud computing is revolutionary, even if the technology it is built on is evolutionary. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Not all applications benefit from deployment in the cloud. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Issues with latency, transaction control, and in particular security and regulatory compliance are of particular concern. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Part Examining the Value Proposition Defining Cloud Computing Cloud computing takes the technology, services, and applications that are similar to those on the Internet and turns them into a self-service utility. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The use of the word “cloud” makes reference to the two essential Abstraction: Cloud computing abstracts the details of system implementation from users and developers. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Applications run on physical systems that specified, data is stored in locations that are unknown, administration of systems is outsourced to others, and access by users is ubiquitous. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Virtualization: Cloud computing virtualizes systems by pooling and sharing resources. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Systems and storage can be provisioned as needed from a centralized infrastructure, costs are assessed on a metered basis, multi-tenancy is enabled, and resources are scalable with agility. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Computing as a utility is a dream that dates from the beginning of the computing industry itself. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A set of new technologies has come along that, along with the need for more efficient and affordable computing, has enabled an on-demand system to develop. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| It is these enabling technologies that are the focal point of this book. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Many people mistakenly believe that cloud computing is nothing more than the Internet given a different name. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Many drawings of Internet-based systems and services depict the Internet as a cloud, and people refer to applications running on the Internet as “running in the cloud,” so the confusion is understandable. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The Internet has many of the characteristics of what is now being called cloud computing. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The Internet offers abstraction, runs using the same set of protocols and standards, and uses the same applications and operating systems. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| These same characteristics are found in an intranet, an internal version of the Internet. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| When an intranet becomes large enough that a diagram no longer wishes to differentiate between individual physical systems, the intranet too becomes identified as a cloud. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Cloud computing is an abstraction based on the notion of pooling physical resources and presenting them as a virtual resource. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| It is a new model for provisioning resources, for staging applications, and for platform-independent user access to services. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Clouds can come in many different types, and the services and applications that run on clouds may or may not be delivered by a cloud service provider. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| These different types and levels of cloud services mean that it is important to define what type of cloud computing system you are working with. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| To help clarify how cloud computing has changed the nature of commercial system deployment, consider these three Google: In the last decade, Google has built a worldwide network of datacenters to service its search engine. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In doing so Google has captured a substantial portion of the advertising revenue. |ENDSENT|

|STARTSENT| Cloud Types To discuss cloud computing intelligently, you need to define the lexicon of cloud computing; many acronyms in this area probably survive long. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Most people separate cloud computing into two distinct sets of Deployment This refers to the location and management of the infrastructure. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Service This consists of the particular types of services that you can access on a cloud computing platform. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This is a very useful demarcation that is now widely accepted. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The NIST model The United States government is a major consumer of computer services and, therefore, one of the major users of cloud computing networks. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The |URL| National Institute of Standards and Technology that separate cloud computing into service models and deployment models. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Those models and their relationship to essential characteristics of cloud computing are shown in Figure |URL| The NIST model originally did not require a cloud to use virtualization to pool resources, nor did it absolutely require that a cloud support multi-tenancy in the earliest definitions of cloud computing. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Multi-tenancy is the sharing of resources among two or more clients. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The latest version of the NIST definition does require that cloud computing networks use virtualization and support multi-tenancy. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Part Examining the Value Proposition FIGURE |URL| The NIST cloud computing definitions Deployment models Service models Service attributes Community Hybrid Private Public Infrastructure as a Service (laaS) Platform as a Service (PaaS) Software as a Service (SaaS) Resource pooling Broad network access Measured service On-demand self-service Rapid elasticity Because cloud computing is moving toward a set of modular interacting components based on standards such as the Service Oriented Architecture (described in Chapter |NUMBER|), you might expect that future versions of the NIST model may add those features as well. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The NIST cloud model address a number of intermediary services such as transaction or service brokers, provisioning, integration, and interoperability services that form the basis for many cloud computing discussions. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Given the emerging roles of service buses, brokers, and cloud APIs at various levels, undoubtedly these elements need to be added to capture the whole story. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The Cloud Cube Model The Open Group maintains an association called the Jericho Forum (|URL| |URL| whose main focus is how to protect cloud networks. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The group has an interesting model that attempts to categorize a cloud network based on four dimensional factors. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| As described in its paper called “Cloud Cube Selecting Cloud Formations for |URL| the type of cloud networks you use dramatically changes the notion of where the boundary between the network and the cloud begins and ends. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The four dimensions of the Cloud Cube Model are shown in Figure |URL| and listed Physical location of the Internal (I) External (E) determines your boundaries. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Ownership: Proprietary (P) Open (O) is a measure of not only the technology ownership, but of interoperability, ease of data transfer, and degree of vendor application lock-in. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Chapter |NUMBER|: Defining Cloud Computing Security Perimeterised (Per) De-perimiterised (D-p) is a measure of whether the operation is inside or outside the security boundary or network firewall. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Sourcing: Insourced or Outsourced means whether the service is provided by the customer or the service provider. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| FIGURE |URL| The Jericho Cloud Cube Model Outsourced Insourced External Internal Proprietary Open De-perimeterised Perimeterised Taken together, the fourth dimension corresponds to two different states in the eight possible cloud Per (IP, IO, EP, EO) and D-p (IP, IO, EP, EO). |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The sourcing dimension addresses the deliverer of the service. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| What the Cloud Cube Model is meant to show is that the traditional notion of a network boundary being the firewall no longer applies in cloud computing. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Deployment models A deployment model defines the purpose of the cloud and the nature of how the cloud is located. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The NIST definition for the four deployment models is as Public The public cloud infrastructure is available for public use alternatively for a large industry group and is owned by an organization selling cloud services. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Private The private cloud infrastructure is operated for the exclusive use of an organization. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The cloud may be managed by that organization or a third party. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Private clouds may be either onor off-premises. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Hybrid A hybrid cloud combines multiple clouds (private, community of public) where those clouds retain their unique identities, but are bound together as a unit. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A Part Examining the Value Proposition hybrid cloud may offer standardized or proprietary access to data and applications, as well as application portability. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Community A community cloud is one where the cloud has been organized to serve a common function or purpose. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| It may be for one organization or for several organizations, but they share common concerns such as their mission, policies, security, regulatory compliance needs, and so on. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A community cloud may be managed by the constituent or by a third party. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Figure |URL| shows the different locations that clouds can come in. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In the sections that follow, these different cloud deployment models are described in more detail. |ENDSENT|

|STARTSENT| Service models In the deployment model, different cloud types are an expression of the manner in which infrastructure is deployed. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| You can think of the cloud as the boundary between where a network, management, and responsibilities ends and the cloud service begins. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| As cloud Part Examining the Value Proposition computing has developed, different vendors offer clouds that have different services associated with them. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The portfolio of services offered adds another set of definitions called the service model. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| There are many different service models described in the literature, all of which take the following XaaS, or as a Service” Three service types have been universally Infrastructure as a IaaS provides virtual machines, virtual storage, virtual infrastructure, and other hardware assets as resources that clients can provision. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The IaaS service provider manages all the infrastructure, while the client is responsible for all other aspects of the deployment. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This can include the operating system, applications, and user interactions with the system. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Platform as a PaaS provides virtual machines, operating systems, applications, services, development frameworks, transactions, and control structures. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The client can deploy its applications on the cloud infrastructure or use applications that were programmed using languages and tools that are supported by the PaaS service provider. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The service provider manages the cloud infrastructure, the operating systems, and the enabling software. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The client is responsible for installing and managing the application that it is deploying. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Software as a SaaS is a complete operating environment with applications, management, and the user interface. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In the SaaS model, the application is provided to the client through a thin client interface (a browser, usually), and the responsibility begins and ends with entering and managing its data and user interaction. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Everything from the application down to the infrastructure is the responsibility. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The three different service models taken together have come to be known as the SPI model of cloud computing. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Many other service models have been StaaS, Storage as a Service; IdaaS, Identity as a Service; CmaaS, Compliance as a Service; and so forth. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| However, the SPI services encompass all the other possibilities. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| It is useful to think of cloud service models in terms of a stack. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| One such representation called the Cloud Reference Model is shown in Figure |URL| At the bottom of the stack is the hardware or infrastructure that comprises the network. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| As you move upward in the stack, each service model inherits the capabilities of the service model beneath it. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| IaaS has the least levels of integrated functionality and the lowest levels of integration, and SaaS has the most. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Examples of IaaS service providers Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud Eucalyptus GoGrid Chapter |NUMBER|: Defining Cloud Computing FlexiScale Linode RackSpace Cloud Terremark All these vendors offer direct access to hardware resources. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| On Amazon considered the classic IaaS example, a client would provision a computer in the form of a virtual machine image, provision storage, and then go on to install the operating system and applications onto that virtual system. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Amazon has a number of operating systems and some enterprise applications that they offer on a rental basis to customers in the form of a number of canned images, but customers are free to install whatever software they want to run. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| responsibilities as expressed in its Service Level Agreement, which is published on Web site, contractually obligates Amazon to provide a level of performance commensurate with the type of resource chosen, as well as a certain level of reliability as measured by the uptime. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| FIGURE |URL| The Cloud Reference Model SaaS PaaS IaaS Presentation mobility Presentation platform APIs Applications Data Video Voice Embedded Mobile PC Various by vendor Embedded Native Web Data Metadata Content Structured Unstructured Integration and middleware Database Identity Messaging Queuing APIs Core connectivity and delivery Abstraction Hardware Facilities SaaS Management PaaS IaaS Authentication Security cluster Images VMM Compute Network Storage HVAC Power Space A PaaS service adds integration features, middleware, and other orchestration and choreography services to the IaaS model. |ENDSENT|

|STARTSENT| With SaaS, the customer uses the application as needed and is not responsible for the installation of the application, its maintenance, or its upkeep. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A good example of an SaaS offering is an online accounting package, with the online versions of Quicken and Quickbooks a prime example. |ENDSENT|

|STARTSENT| Chapter |NUMBER|: Defining Cloud Computing Other good examples of SaaS cloud service providers GoogleApps Oracle On Demand |URL| SQL Azure These service model classifications start to get confusing rather quickly when you have a cloud service provider that starts out offering services in one area and then develops services that are classified as another type. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| For example, |URL| started out as a Customer Relationship Management SaaS platform that allowed clients to add their own applications. |ENDSENT|

|STARTSENT| Examining the Characteristics of Cloud Computing Cloud computing builds on so many older concepts in computer technology that it can be hard for people newly introduced to the concept to grasp that it represents a paradigm shift in computing. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| an evolutionary change that enables a revolutionary new approach to how computing services are produced and consumed. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Paradigm shift When you choose a cloud service provider, you are renting or leasing part of an enormous infrastructure of datacenters, computers, storage, and networking capacity. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Many of these datacenters are investments by the companies that run them. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| To give you some sense of scale, it has been estimated that a microchip fabrication facility can cost anywhere from to billion. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| By comparison, a state of the art cloud computing datacenter can run in the range of million. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Most of the large cloud computing service providers have multiple datacenters located all over the world. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| An accurate count can be difficult to obtain, but in Chapter |NUMBER| Part Examining the Value Proposition the location of some |NUMBER| datacenters in Amazon Web cloud are detailed. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| cloud includes perhaps some |NUMBER| datacenters worldwide. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In the military initiative aimed at miniaturizing electronics funded many of the semiconductor production lines that led to advanced microprocessors, dense memory arrays, and the sophisticated integrated circuit technology that makes computers, mobile devices, and so much more possible today. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In the the commercialization of the Internet gave rise to some very large companies that were forced to build very large computing infrastructures to support their businesses. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| |URL|’s infrastructure was built to support elastic demand so the system could accommodate peak traffic on a busy shopping day such as “Black Monday.” Because much of the capacity was idle, |URL| first opened its network to partners and then as Amazon Web Services to customers. |ENDSENT|

|STARTSENT| Benefits of cloud computing “The NIST Definition of Cloud Computing” by Peter Mell and Tim Grance (version |NUMBER| |DATE|) described previously in this chapter (refer to Figure |URL| that classified cloud computing into the three SPI service models (SaaS, IaaS, and PaaS) and four cloud types (public, private, community, and hybrid), also assigns five essential characteristics that cloud computing systems must Chapter |NUMBER|: Defining Cloud Computing On-demand A client can provision computer resources without the need for interaction with cloud service provider personnel. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Broad network Access to resources in the cloud is available over the network using standard methods in a manner that provides platform-independent access to clients of all types. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This includes a mixture of heterogeneous operating systems, and thick and thin platforms such as laptops, mobile phones, and PDA. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Resource A cloud service provider creates resources that are pooled together in a system that supports multi-tenant usage. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Physical and virtual systems are dynamically allocated or reallocated as needed. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Intrinsic in this concept of pooling is the idea of abstraction that hides the location of resources such as virtual machines, processing, memory, storage, and network bandwidth and connectivity. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Rapid Resources can be rapidly and elastically provisioned. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The system can add resources by either scaling up systems (more powerful computers) or scaling out systems (more computers of the same kind), and scaling may be automatic or manual. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| From the standpoint of the client, cloud computing resources should look limitless and can be purchased at any time and in any quantity. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Measured The use of cloud system resources is measured, audited, and reported to the customer based on a metered system. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A client can be charged based on a known metric such as amount of storage used, number of transactions, network (Input/Output) or bandwidth, amount of processing power used, and so forth. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A client is charged based on the level of services provided. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| While these five core features of cloud computing are on almost list, you also should consider these additional Lower Because cloud networks operate at higher efficiencies and with greater utilization, significant cost reductions are often encountered. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Ease of Depending upon the type of service being offered, you may find that you do not require hardware or software licenses to implement your service. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Quality of The Quality of Service (QoS) is something that you can obtain under contract from your vendor. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Reliability: The scale of cloud computing networks and their ability to provide load balancing and failover makes them highly reliable, often much more reliable than what you can achieve in a single organization. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Outsourced IT A cloud computing deployment lets someone else manage your computing infrastructure while you manage your business. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In most instances, you achieve considerable reductions in IT staffing costs. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Part Examining the Value Proposition Simplified maintenance and Because the system is centralized, you can easily apply patches and upgrades. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This means your users always have access to the latest software versions. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Low Barrier to In particular, upfront capital expenditures are dramatically reduced. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In cloud computing, anyone can be a giant at any time. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This very long list of benefits should make it obvious why so many people are excited about the idea of cloud computing. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Cloud computing is not a panacea, however. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In many instances, cloud computing work well for particular applications. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Disadvantages of cloud computing While the benefits of cloud computing are myriad, the disadvantages are just as numerous. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| As a general rule, the advantages of cloud computing present a more compelling case for small organizations than for larger ones. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Larger organizations can support IT staff and development efforts that put in place custom software solutions that are crafted with their particular needs in mind. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| When you use an application or service in the cloud, you are using something that necessarily as customizable as you might want. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Additionally, although many cloud computing applications are very capable, applications deployed on-premises still have many more features than their cloud counterparts. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| All cloud computing applications suffer from the inherent latency that is intrinsic in their WAN connectivity. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| While cloud computing applications excel at large-scale processing tasks, if your application needs large amounts of data transfer, cloud computing may not be the best model for you. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Additionally, cloud computing is a stateless system, as is the Internet in general. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In order for communication to survive on a distributed system, it is necessarily unidirectional in nature. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| All the requests you use in PUTs, GETs, and so on are requests to a service provider. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The service provider then sends a response. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Although it may seem that you are carrying on a conversation between client and provider, there is an architectural disconnect between the two. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| That lack of state allows messages to travel over different routes and for data to arrive out of sequence, and many other characteristics allow the communication to succeed even when the medium is faulty. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Therefore, to impose transactional coherency upon the system, additional overhead in the form of service brokers, transaction managers, and other middleware must be added to the system. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This can introduce a very large performance hit into some applications. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| If you had to pick a single area of concern in cloud computing, that area would undoubtedly be privacy and security. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| When your data travels over and rests on systems that are no longer under your control, you have increased risk due to the interception and malfeasance of others. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| You count on a cloud provider maintaining your privacy in the face of government actions. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In the United States, an example is the National Security program that ran millions of phone calls from and Verizon through a data analyzer to extract the phone calls that matched its security criteria. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| VoIP is one of the services that is heavily deployed on cloud computing systems. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Another example is the case of service in China, which had been subject to a Chapter |NUMBER|: Defining Cloud Computing filter that removed content to which the Chinese government objected. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| After five years of operation, and after Google detected that Chinese hackers were accessing Gmail accounts of Chinese citizens, Google moved their servers for |URL| to Hong Kong. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| So while the cloud computing industry continues to address security concerns, if you have an application that works with sensitive data, you need to be particularly aware of the issues involved. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Chapter |NUMBER| “Understanding Cloud Security,” expands upon these points in more detail. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| These days most organizations are faced with regulatory compliance issues of various kinds. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In the United States, companies must comply with the accounting requirements of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act; health care providers comply with the data privacy rules of HIPAA, and so on. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In Europe, the European Common Market has a raft of its own legislation for companies to deal with. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Rules apply to data at rest, and different rules may apply to data in transit. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| If you stage your cloud computing deployment across states and countries, the bad news is that you may end up having to comply with multiple jurisdictions. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| expect much support from the cloud system provider or from the governments involved. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The laws of most regulatory agencies place the entire burden on the client. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| So when it comes to compliance, cloud computing is still the “Wild West” of computing. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Assessing the Role of Open Standards When you consider the development of cloud computing to date, it is clear that the technology is the result of the convergence of many different standards. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Cloud promise of scalability completely changes the manner in which services and applications are deployed. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Without standards, the industry creates proprietary systems with vendor lock-in, sometimes referred to as “stovepipe” clouds. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Because clients do not want to be locked into any single system, there is a strong industry push to create standards-based clouds. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The cloud computing industry is working with these architectural Platform virtualization of resources Service-oriented architecture Web-application frameworks Deployment of open-source software Standardized Web services Autonomic systems Grid computing These standards help to enable different business models that cloud computing vendors can support, most notably Software as a Service (SaaS), Web |URL| applications, and utility computing. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| These businesses require open standards so that data is both portable and universally accessible. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Part Examining the Value Proposition The race to create the first generation of open cloud platform technologies that will compete with proprietary technologies offered by companies such as Microsoft (Azure Platform) and VMware (vSphere) is already underway. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| |URL| one of the large IaaS cloud service providers, announced in |DATE| that it is initiating an open-source project called OpenStack that will begin with the code used to run its Cloud Files and Cloud Servers technologies. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| NASA has also donated some of the Nebula Cloud Platform technology that it developed. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The software developed will be released under the Apache |URL| license. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Founding members of this project include AMD, Citrix, Dell, Intel, NTT Data, and several other cloud service providers. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| |URL|’s home page The first two deliverables of the project are a distributed object store based on Rackspace Cloud Files and a scalable machine provisioning technology based on NASA Nebula and Rackspace Cloud Servers. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| OpenStack Compute software will automatically create large groups of virtual private servers on industry-standard systems. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| OpenStack Storage is the software that will create redundant object-based storage using clusters of commodity servers and storage systems. |ENDSENT|

|STARTSENT| To understand cloud computing and fully appreciate its subtleties, you need to categorize the different cloud types. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The two types of cloud models are those based on where the cloud is deployed and those based on the types of services that clouds offer. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In this chapter, you were introduced to these cloud types. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Cloud computing has a number of benefits and has attracted great industry and general interest. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Cloud computing allows systems to be created cheaply with little upfront costs and to be scaled to massive sizes, when needed. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Not all applications and services benefit from cloud computing, and I presented some of the factors that help you differentiate between successful deployments and those that are not. |ENDSENT|

|STARTSENT| Aside from technological reasons, behavior considerations associated with cloud adoption are discussed. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Cloud computing is particularly valuable because it shifts capital expenditures into operating expenditures. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This has the benefit of decoupling growth from cash on hand or from requiring access to capital. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| It also shifts risk away from an organization and onto the cloud provider. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This chapter describes how to begin to measure the costs of cloud computing and some of the tools that you can use to do so. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The concept of optimization known as right-sizing is described, and cloud computing has some unique new capabilities in this area. |ENDSENT|

|STARTSENT| They are essentially your working contract with any provider. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Cloud computing is having impact on software licensing, which although not entirely settled is also described in this chapter. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Part Examining the Value Proposition Measuring the Value Cloud computing presents new opportunities to users and developers because it is based on the paradigm of a shared multitenant utility. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The ability to access pooled resources on a basis provides a number of system characteristics that completely alter the economics of information technology infrastructures and allows new types of access and business models for user applications. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Any application or process that benefits from economies of scale, commoditization of assets, and conformance to programming standards benefits from the application of cloud computing. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Any application or process that requires a completely customized solution, imposes a high degree of specialization, and requires access to proprietary technology is going to expose the limits of cloud computing rather quickly. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Applications that work with cloud computing are ones that I refer to as “low touch” applications; they tend to be applications that have low margins and usually low risk. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The “high touch” applications that come with high margins require committed resources and pose more of a risk; those applications are best done on-premises. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A cloud is defined as the combination of the infrastructure of a datacenter with the ability to provision hardware and software. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A service that concentrates on hardware follows the Infrastructure as a Service (IaaS) model, which is a good description for the Amazon Web Service described in Chapter |NUMBER|. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| When you add a software stack, such as an operating system and applications to the service, the model shifts to the Software as a Service (SaaS) model. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Windows Azure Platform, discussed in Chapter |NUMBER| is best described as currently using SaaS model. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| When the service requires the client to use a complete stack, it is using the most refined and restrictive service model, called the Platform as a Service (PaaS) model. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The best example of a PaaS offering is probably |URL| The Google App Engine discussed in Chapter |NUMBER| is another PaaS. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| As the Windows Azure Platform matures adding more access to Microsoft servers, it is developing into a PaaS model rather quickly. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Cross-Ref Chapter |NUMBER| “Understanding Services and Applications by Type,” describes a number of these XaaS service models. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Cloud computing is in its wild and wooly frontier days, so best to take a few of the lesser known acronyms with a grain of salt. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| n A cloud is an infrastructure that can be partitioned and provisioned, and resources are pooled and virtualized. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| If the cloud is available to the public on a basis, then the cloud is a public cloud, and the service is described as a utility. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| If the cloud is captive in an infrastructure (network), it is referred to as a private cloud. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| When you mix public and private clouds together, you have a hybrid cloud. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Any analysis of the potential of cloud computing must account for all these possibilities. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| These are the unique characteristics of an ideal cloud computing Scalability: You have access to unlimited computer resources as needed. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This feature obviates the need for planning and provisioning. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| It also enables batch processing, which greatly speeds up high-processing applications. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Chapter |NUMBER|: Assessing the Value Proposition Elasticity: You have the ability to right-size resources as required. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This feature allows you to optimize your system and capture all possible transactions. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Low barrier to You can gain access to systems for a small investment. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This feature offers access to global resources to small ventures and provides the ability to experiment with little risk. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Utility: A model matches resources to need on an ongoing basis. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This eliminates waste and has the added benefit of shifting risk from the client. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| It is the construction of large datacenters running commodity hardware that has enabled cloud computing to gain traction. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| These datacenters gain access to low-cost electricity, high-network bandwidth pipes, and low-cost commodity hardware and software, which, taken together, represents an economy of scale that allows cloud providers to amortize their investment and retain a profit. |ENDSENT|

|STARTSENT| The development of cloud computing has been likened to the situation that has faced hardware companies that rely on proprietary silicon to produce their the AMDs, nVidias, eVGAs, and Apples of the world. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Because a semiconductor fabrication facility costs several billion dollars to create, these companies were at a severe disadvantage to companies such as Intel or NEC, which could build their own fabs or fabrication facilities. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| (A fab is a facility that is a self-contained semiconductor assembly line.) |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Companies such as TSMC (Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company) have come along that provide fabrication based on customer designs, spreading their risk and optimizing their operation. |ENDSENT|

|STARTSENT| The nature of cloud computing should provide us with new classes of applications, some of which are currently emerging. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Because Wide Area Network (WAN) bandwidth provides one of the current bottlenecks for distributed computing, one of the major areas of interest in cloud computing is in establishing content delivery networks (CDN). |ENDSENT|

|STARTSENT| n The laws of cloudonomics Joe Wienman of Global Services has concisely stated the advantages that cloud computing offers over a private or captured system. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| His article appeared on |URL| http:// |URL| A summary of “|NUMBER| Laws of Cloudonomics” follows and his |NUMBER|. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Utility services cost less even though they cost more. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Utilities charge a premium for their services, but customers save money by not paying for services that they using. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| On-demand trumps forecasting. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The ability to provision and tear down resources (de-provision) captures revenue and lowers costs. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Part Examining the Value Proposition |NUMBER|. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The peak of the sum is never greater than the sum of the peaks. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A cloud can deploy less capacity because the peaks of individual tenants in a shared system are averaged over time by the group of tenants. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Aggregate demand is smoother than individual. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Multi-tenancy also tends to average the variability intrinsic in individual demand because the “coefficient of random variables” is always less than or equal to that of any of the individual variables. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| With a more predictable demand and less variation, clouds can run at higher utilization rates than captive systems. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This allows cloud systems to operate at higher efficiencies and lower costs. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Average unit costs are reduced by distributing fixed costs over more units of output. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Cloud vendors have a size that allows them to purchase resources at significantly reduced prices. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| (This feature was described in the previous section.) |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Superiority in numbers is the most important factor in the result of a combat Weinman argues that a large size has the ability to repel botnets and DDoS attacks better than smaller systems do. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Space-time is a continuum The ability of a task to be accomplished in the cloud using parallel processing allows realtime business to respond quicker to business conditions and accelerates decision making providing a measurable advantage. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Dispersion is the inverse square of latency. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Latency, or the delay in getting a response to a request, requires both large-scale and multi-site deployments that are a characteristic of cloud providers. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Cutting latency in half requires four times the number of nodes in a system. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| |NUMBER|. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| put all your eggs in one basket. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The reliability of a system with n redundant components and a reliability of r is Therefore, when a datacenter achieves a reliability of |NUMBER| percent, two redundant datacenters have a reliability of |URL| percent (four nines) and three redundant datacenters can achieve a reliability of |URL| percent (six nines). |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Large cloud providers with geographically dispersed sites worldwide therefore achieve reliability rates that are hard for private systems to achieve. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| An object at rest tends to stay at rest (Newton). |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Private datacenters tend to be located in places where the company or unit was founded or acquired. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Cloud providers can site their datacenters in what are called “greenfield sites.” A greenfield site is one that is environmentally locations that are on a network backbone, have cheap access to power and cooling, where land is inexpensive, and the environmental impact is low. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A network backbone is a very high-capacity network connection. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| On the Internet, an Internet backbone consists of the high-capacity routes and routers that are typically operated by an individual service provider such as a government or commercial Chapter |NUMBER|: Assessing the Value Proposition entity. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| You can access a jump page of Internet backbone maps http://www. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| |URL| Cloud computing obstacles Cloud computing a panacea; nor is it either practical or economically sensible for many computer applications that you encounter. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In practice, cloud computing can deviate from the ideals described in the previous list in many significant ways. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The illusion of scalability is bounded by the limitations cloud providers place on their clients. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Resource limits are exposed at peak conditions of the utility itself. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| As we all know, power utilities suffer brownouts and outages when the temperature soars, and cloud computing providers are no different. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| You see these outages on peak computing days such as Black Monday, which is the Monday after Thanksgiving in the United States when Internet Christmas sales traditionally start. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The illusion of low barrier to entry may be pierced by an inconsistent pricing scheme that makes scaling more expensive than it should be. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| You can see this limit in the nonlinearity of pricing associated with “extra large” machine instances versus their “standard” size counterparts. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Additionally, the low barrier to entry also can be accompanied by a low barrier to provisioning. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| If you make a provisioning error, it can lead to vast costs. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Cloud computing vendors run very reliable networks. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Often, cloud data is load-balanced between virtual systems and replicated between sites. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| However, even cloud providers experience outages. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In the cloud, it is common to have various resources, such as machine instances, fail. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Except for tightly managed PaaS cloud providers, the burden of resource management is still in the hands of the user, but the user is often provided with limited or immature management tools to address these issues. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Table |URL| summarizes the various obstacles and challenges that cloud computing faces. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| These issues are described in various chapters in this book. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| TABLE |URL| Challenges and Obstacles to Cloud Computing Subject Area Accounting Management Captive Chargeback or Licensed Cloud Usage Challenge In private systems, costs associated with operations are fixed due to licenses and must be charged back to accounts based on some formula or usage model. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| For cloud computing, the usage model allows for costs to be applied to individual accounts directly. |ENDSENT|

|STARTSENT| This requires that the cloud accommodate multiple compliance regimes. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| To ensure data privacy in the cloud, additional security methods such as private encryption, VLANs, firewalls, and local storage of sensitive data is necessary. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| For private systems, any monitoring system the organization wishes to deploy can be brought to bear. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Cloud computing models often have limited monitoring because it is vendor-defined. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Network bottlenecks occur when large data sets must be transferred. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This is the case for staging, replication, and other operations. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| On-premise operations use LANs that are better able to accommodate transfers than the WAN connections used in cloud computing. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The reputation for cloud computing services for the quality of those services is shared by tenants. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| An outage of the cloud provider impacts individuals. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Clouds often have higher reliability than private systems. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The different trust mechanisms require that applications be structured differently and that operations be modified to account for these differences. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Cloud SLAs are standardized in order to appeal to the majority of its audience. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Custom SLAs that allow for multiple data sources are difficult to obtain or enforce. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Cloud SLAs do not generally offer industry standard chargeback rates, and negotiations with large cloud providers can be difficult for small users. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Business risks that covered by a cloud SLA must be taken into account. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The cloud enforces standardization and lowers the ability of a system to be customized for need. |ENDSENT|

|STARTSENT| In cloud computing large data stores are possible but they have low bandwidth connection. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| High speed local storage in the cloud tends to be expensive. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Vendor lock-in is a function of the particular enterprise and application in an on-premises deployment. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| For cloud providers, vendor lock-in increases going from the IaaS to SaaS to PaaS model. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Vendor lock-in for a cloud computing solution in a PaaS model is very high. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Behavioral factors relating to cloud adoption The issues described in Table |URL| are real substantive issues that can be measured and quantified. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| However, a number of intrinsic properties of cloud computing create cognitive biases in people that are obstacles to cloud adoption and are worth mentioning. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This goes for users as well as organizations. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Duke University economist Dan Ariely, in his book Predictably The Hidden Forces that Shape Our Decisions (Harper Collins, |NUMBER|), explores how people often make choices that are inconsistent based on expediency or human nature. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Joe Weinman has expanded on these ideas and some others to formulate ten more “laws” for cloud computing adoption based on human behavior. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| You can read the original article at |URL| The “|NUMBER| Laws of Behavioral Cloudonomics” are summarized People are risk averse and loss averse. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Ariely argues that losses are more painful than gains are pleasurable. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Cloud initiatives may cause the concerns of adoption to be weighed more heavily than the benefits accrued to improving total costs and achieving greater agility. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| People have a flat-rate bias. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Loss aversion expresses itself by preferences to flat-rate plans where risk is psychologically minimized to usage-based plans where costs are actually less. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Weiman cites the work of Anja Lambrecht and Bernd Skiera, “Paying Too Much and Being Happy About Existence, Causes, and Consequences of Tariff-Choice Biases” for this point. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Part Examining the Value Proposition |NUMBER|. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| People have the need to control their environment and remain anonymous. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The need for environmental control is a primal directive. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Loss of control leads to “learned helplessness” and shorter life spans. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| You can read about the research in this area in David Oxford Leadership Journal article “Managing with the Brain in Mind,” found at |URL| The point about shorter life spans comes from the work of Judith Rodin and Ellen Langer, “Long-Term Effects of a ControlRelevant Intervention with the Institutionalized Aged” (|URL| which appeared in the Journal of Personality and Social Psychology in |NUMBER|. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| People fear change. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Uncertainty leads to fear, and fear leads to inertia. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This is as true for cloud computing as it is for investing in the stock market. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| People value what they own more than what they are given. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This is called the endowment effect. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| It is a predilection for existing assets that is out of line with their value to others. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The cognitive science behind this principle is referred to as |NUMBER|. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| People favor the status quo and invest accordingly. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| There is a bias toward the way things have been and a willingness to invest in the status quo that is out of line with their current value. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In cognitive science, the former attribute is referred to as the status quo bias (|URL| quo_bias), while the latter attribute is referred to as an escalation of commitment |NUMBER|. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| People discount future risk and favor instant gratification. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Weinman argues that because cloud computing is an on-demand service, the instant gratification factor should favor cloud computing. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| People favor things that are free. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| When offered an item that is free or another that costs money but offers a greater gain, people opt for the free item. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Weinman argues that this factor also favors the cloud computing model because upfront costs are eliminated. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| People have the need for status. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A large IT organization with substantial assets is a visual display of your status; a cloud deployment is not. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This is expressed as a pride of ownership. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Chapter |NUMBER|: Assessing the Value Proposition |NUMBER|. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| People are incapacitated by choice. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The Internet enables commerce to shift to a large inventory where profit can be maintained by many sales of a few items each, the so-called long tail. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| When this model is applied to cloud computing, people tend to be overwhelmed by the choice and delay adoption. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Measuring cloud computing costs As you see, cloud computing has many advantages and disadvantages, and you always measure them. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| You can measure costs though, and a valuable exercise. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Usually a commodity is cheaper than a specialized item, but not always. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Depending upon your situation, you can pay more for public cloud computing than you would for owning and managing your private cloud, or for owning and using software as well. |ENDSENT|

|STARTSENT| Chapter |NUMBER|: Assessing the Value Proposition FIGURE |URL| The Amazon Web Service Simple Monthly Calculator Avoiding Capital Expenditures A major part of cloud value proposition and its appeal is its ability to convert capital expenses (CapEx) to operating expenses (OpEx) through a usage pricing scheme that is elastic and can be right-sized. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The conversion of real assets to virtual ones provides a measure of protection against too much or too little infrastructure. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Essentially, moving expenses onto the OpEx side of a budget allows an organization to transfer risk to their cloud computing provider. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Capitalization may be the single largest reason that new businesses fail, and it is surely an impediment to established businesses starting new enterprises. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Growth itself can be difficult when revenues cover the expansion and obtaining financing is difficult. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A company wishing to grow would normally be faced with the following Buy the new equipment, and deploy it in-house Lease the equipment for a set period of time Outsource the operation to a managed-services organization Part Examining the Value Proposition Capital expenditures must create the infrastructure necessary to capture the transactions that the business needs. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| However, if demand is variable, then it is an open question as to how much infrastructure is needed to support demand. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Cloud computing is also a good option when the cost of infrastructure and management is high. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This is often the case with legacy applications and systems where maintaining the system capabilities is a significant cost. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Right-sizing Consider an accounting firm with a variable demand load, as shown in Figure |URL| For each of the four quarters of the tax year, clients file their quarterly taxes on the Web site. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Demand for three of those quarters rises broadly as the quarterly filing deadline arrives. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The fourth quarter that represents the year-end tax filing on April |NUMBER| shows a much larger and more pronounced spike for the two weeks approaching and just following that end. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Clearly, this accounting business ignore the demand spike for its year-end accounting, because this is the single most important portion of the business, but it needs to match demand to resources to maximize its profits. |ENDSENT|

|STARTSENT| Fitting the infrastructure to meet the average demand, DAVG, means that half of the transactions in the Chapter |NUMBER|: Assessing the Value Proposition spike are not captured, which is the mission critical portion of this enterprise. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| More accurately using DAVG means that during maximum demand the service is slowed to a crawl and the system may not be responsive enough to satisfy any of the users. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| These limits can be a serious constraint on profit and revenue. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Outsourcing the demand may provide a solution to the problem. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| But outsourcing essentially shifts the burden of capital expenditures onto the service provider. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A service contract that match infrastructure to demand suffers from the same inefficiencies that captive infrastructure does. |ENDSENT|

|STARTSENT| Computing the Total Cost of Ownership The Total Cost of Ownership or TCO is a financial estimate for the costs of the use of a product or service over its lifetime, often broken out on a yearly or quarterly basis. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In pitching cloud Part Examining the Value Proposition computing projects, it is common to create spreadsheets that predict the costs of using the cloud computing model versus performing the same functions in-house or on-premises. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| To be really useful, a TCO must account for the real costs of items, but frequently they do not. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| For example, the cost of a system deployed in-house is not only the cost of acquisition and the cost of maintenance. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A system consumes resources such as space in a datacenter or portion of your site, power, cooling, and management. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| All these resources represent an overhead that is often overlooked, either in error or for political reasons. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| When you account for monitoring and management of systems, you must account for the burdened cost of an IT employee, the cost of the hardware and software that is used for management, and other hidden costs. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The Wikipedia page on Total Cost of Ownership (|URL| contains a list of computer and software industries TCO elements that are a good place to start to build your own worksheet. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Note A really thorough and meaningful TCO study should probably be done by an accountant or consultant with a financial background in this area to obtain meaningful results. |ENDSENT|

|STARTSENT| Specifying Service Level Agreements A Service Level Agreement (SLA) is the contract for performance negotiated between you and a service provider. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In the early days of cloud computing, all SLAs were negotiated between a client and the provider. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Today with the advent of large utility-like cloud computing providers, most SLAs are standardized until a client becomes a large consumer of services. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Caution Some SLAs are enforceable as contracts, but many are really agreements that are more along the lines of an Operating Level Agreement (OLA) and may not have the force of law. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| good to have an attorney review these documents before you make a major commitment to a cloud provider. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| n SLAs usually specify these Availability of the service (uptime) Response times or latency Part Examining the Value Proposition Reliability of the service components Responsibilities of each party Warranties If a vendor fails to meet the stated targets or minimums, it is punished by having to offer the client a credit or pay a penalty. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In this regard, an SLA should be like buying insurance, and like buying insurance, getting the insurer to pay up when disaster strikes can be the work. |ENDSENT|
