|STARTSENT| Defining Licensing Models When you purchase shrink-wrapped software, you are using that software based on a licensing agreement called a EULA or End User License Agreement. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The EULA may specify that the software meets the following It is yours to own. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| It can be installed on a single or multiple machines. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| It allows for one or more connections. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| It has whatever limit the ISV has placed on its software. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In most instances, the purchase price of the software is directly tied to the EULA. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| For a long time now, the computer industry has known that the use of distributed applications over the Internet was going to impact the way in which companies license their software, and indeed it has. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The problem is that there is no uniform description of how applications accessed over cloud networks will be priced. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| There are several different licensing models in play at the no clear winners. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Part Examining the Value Proposition It can certainly be argued that the use of free software is a successful model. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The free use of software in the cloud is something that the open-source community can support, it can be supported as a line extension of a commercial product, or it can be paid for out of money obtained from other sources such as advertising. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| advertising juggernaut has allowed it to create a portfolio of applications that users can access based on their Google accounts. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| free software in Windows Live is supported by its sales of the Windows operating system and by sales of the Microsoft Office suite. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In practice, cloud-based providers tend to license their applications or services based on user or machine accounts, but they do so in ways that are different than you might expect based on your experience with physical hardware and software. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Many applications and services use a subscription or usage model (or both) and tie it to a user account. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Lots of experimentation is going on in the publishing industry on how to price Internet offerings, and you can find the same to be true in all kinds of computer applications at the moment. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Some services tie their licenses into a machine account when it makes sense. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| An example is the backup service Carbonite, where the service is for backing up a licensed computer. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| However, cloud computing applications rarely use machine licenses when the application is meant to be ubiquitous. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| If you need to access an application, service, or Web site from any location, then a machine license going to be practical. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The impact of cloud computing on bulk software purchases and enterprise licensing schemes is even harder to gauge. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Several analysts have remarked that the advent of cloud computing could lead to the end of enterprise licensing and could cause difficulties for software vendors going forward. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| It clear what the impact on licensing will be in the future, but it is certainly an area to keep your eyes on. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Summary In this chapter, you learned about the features that make cloud computing unique. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| It is both a new model and a new platform for computing. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The idea of computing as a utility is as old as the computer industry itself, but it is the advent of low-cost datacenters that have really enabled this platform to thrive. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A unique features are scalability, elasticity, low barrier to entry, and a utility delivery of services. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| These features completely change the way in which applications and services are used. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Cloud computing will enable the development of new types of applications, several of which were described in this chapter. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Undoubtedly many new application types will arise that will be a complete surprise to us all. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| However, cloud computing has some limitations that were discussed as well. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| To help you get a handle on cloud computing, this chapter stresses measurements of costs in comparison to private or on-premises systems. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Cloud computing shifts capital expenditures into operating expenditures. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Chapter |NUMBER|: Assessing the Value Proposition Cloud computing changes the nature of the service provider and its relationship to its client. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| You see this expressed in the Service Level Agreements (SLAs) and software licensing that are part of this new developing industry. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| There are many changes to come in these areas. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Chapter |NUMBER| “Understanding Cloud Architecture,” is an in-depth look at the superstructure and plumbing that makes cloud computing possible. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In that chapter, you learn about the standards and protocols used by the cloud computing industry. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Understanding Cloud Architecture IN THIS CHAPTER Using the cloud computing stack to describe different models Understanding how platforms and virtual appliances are used Learning how cloud communications work Discovering the new world of the cloud client Cloud computing is a natural extension of many of the design principles, protocols, plumbing, and systems that have been developed over the past |NUMBER| years. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| However, cloud computing describes some new capabilities that are architected into an application stack and are responsible for the programmability, scalability, and virtualization of resources. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| One property that differentiates cloud computing is referred to as composability, which is the ability to build applications from component parts. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A platform is a cloud computing service that is both hardware and software. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Platforms are used to create more complex software. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Virtual appliances are an important example of a platform, and they are becoming a very important standard cloud computing deployment object. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Cloud computing requires some standard protocols with which different layers of hardware, software, and clients can communicate with one another. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Many of these protocols are standard Internet protocols. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Cloud computing relies on a set of protocols needed to manage interprocess communications that have been developed over the years. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The most commonly used set of protocols uses XML as the messaging format, the Simple Object Access Protocol (SOAP) protocol as the object model, and a set of discovery and description protocols based on the Web Services Description Language (WSDL) to manage transactions. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Some completely new clients are under development that are specifically meant to connect to the cloud. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| These clients have as their focus cloud applications and services, and are often hardened and more securely connected. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Two examples presented are Jolicloud and Google Chrome OS. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| They represent a new client model that is likely to have considerable impact. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Part Examining the Value Proposition Exploring the Cloud Computing Stack Cloud computing builds on the architecture developed for staging large distributed network applications on the Internet over the last |NUMBER| years. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| To these standard networking protocols, cloud computing adds the advances in system virtualization that became available over the last decade. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The cloud creates a system where resources can be pooled and partitioned as needed. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Cloud architecture can couple software running on virtualized hardware in multiple locations to provide an ondemand service to user-facing hardware and software. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| It is this unique combination of abstraction and metered service that separates the architectural requirements of cloud computing systems from the general description given for an n-tiered Internet application. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Many descriptions of cloud computing describe it in terms of two architectural A client as a front end The “cloud” as a backend This is a very simplistic description because each of these two components is composed of several component layers, complementary functionalities, and a mixture of standard and proprietary protocols. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Cloud computing may be differentiated from older models by describing an encapsulated information technology service that is often controlled through an Application Programming Interface (API), thus modifying the services that are delivered over the network. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A cloud can be created within an own infrastructure or outsourced to another datacenter. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| While resources in a cloud can be real physical resources, more often they are virtualized resources because virtualized resources are easier to modify and optimize. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A compute cloud requires virtualized storage to support the staging and storage of data. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| From a perspective, it is important that the resources appear to be infinitely scalable, that the service be measurable, and that the pricing be metered. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Composability Applications built in the cloud often have the property of being built from a collection of components, a feature referred to as composability. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A composable system uses components to assemble services that can be tailored for a specific purpose using standard parts. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A composable component must Modular: It is a self-contained and independent unit that is cooperative, reusable, and replaceable. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Stateless: A transaction is executed without regard to other transactions or requests. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| It an absolute requirement that transactions be stateless, some cloud computing applications provide managed states through brokers, transaction monitors, and service buses. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In rarer cases, full transactional systems are deployed in the clouds, but these systems are harder to architect in a distributed architecture. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Chapter |NUMBER|: Understanding Cloud Architecture Although cloud computing require that hardware and software be composable, it is a highly desirable characteristic from a developer or standpoint, because it makes system design easier to implement and solutions more portable and interoperable. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| There is a tendency for cloud computing systems to become less composable for users as the services incorporate more of the cloud computing stack. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| From the standpoint of an IaaS (Infrastructure as a Service) vendor such as Amazon Web Services, GoGrid, or Rackspace, it makes no sense to offer non-standard machine instances to customers, because those customers are almost certainly deploying applications built on standard operating systems such as Linux, Windows, Solaris, or some other well-known operating system. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In the next step up the cloud computing stack, PaaS (Platform as a Service) vendors such as Windows Azure or Google AppEngine may narrow the definition of standard parts to standard parts that work with their own platforms, but at least from the standpoint of the individual platform service provider, the intent is to be modular for their own developers. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| When you move to the highest degree of integration in cloud computing, which is SaaS (Software as a Service), the notion of composability for users may completely disappear. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| An SaaS vendor such as |URL| or |URL| is delivering an application as a service to a customer, and no particular benefit from the standpoint of the service provider that the customer be able to compose its own custom applications. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A service provider reselling an SaaS may have the option to offer one module or another, to customize the information contained in the module for a client, to sell the service under their own brand, or to perform some other limited kind of customization, but modifications are generally severely limited. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This idea that composability diminishes going up the cloud computing stack is from the point of view. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| If you are a PaaS or SaaS service provider and your task is to create the platform or service presented to the developer, reseller, or user, the notion of working with a composable system is still a very powerful one. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A PaaS or SaaS service provider gets the same benefits from a composable system that a user things, among Easier to assemble systems Cheaper system development More reliable operation A larger pool of qualified developers A logical design methodology You encounter the trend toward designing composable systems in cloud computing in the widespread adoption of what has come to be called the Service Oriented Architecture (SOA). |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The essence of a service oriented design is that services are constructed from a set of modules using standard communications and service interfaces. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| An example of a set of widely used standards describes the services themselves in terms of the Web Services Description Language (WSDL), data exchange between services using some form of XML, and the communications between the services using the SOAP protocol. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| There are, of course, alternative sets of standards. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Part Examining the Value Proposition Cross-Ref SOA is described in detail in Chapter |NUMBER|. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| n What specified is the nature of the module itself; it can be written in any programming language the developer wants. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| From the standpoint of the system, the module is a black box, and only the interface is well specified. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This independence of the internal workings of the module or component means it can be swapped out for a different model, relocated, or replaced at will, provided that the interface specification remains unchanged. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| That is a powerful benefit to any system or application provider as their products evolve. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Infrastructure Most large Infrastructure as a Service (IaaS) providers rely on virtual machine technology to deliver servers that can run applications. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Virtual servers described in terms of a machine image or instance have characteristics that often can be described in terms of real servers delivering a certain number of microprocessor (CPU) cycles, memory access, and network bandwidth to customers. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Virtual machines are containers that are assigned specific resources. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The software that runs in the virtual machines is what defines the utility of the cloud computing system. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Figure |URL| shows the portion of the cloud computing stack that is defined as the “server.” In the diagram, the API is shown shaded in gray because it is an optional component that always delivered with the server. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The VMM component is the Virtual Machine Monitor, also called a hypervisor. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This is the low-level software that allows different operating systems to run in their own memory space and manages for the virtual machines. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The notion of a virtual server presents to an application developer a new way of thinking about and programming applications. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| For example, when a programmer is creating software that requires several different tasks to be performed in parallel, he might write an application that creates additional threads of execution that must be managed by the application. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| When a developer creates an application that uses a cloud service, the developer can attach to the appropriate and allow the application itself to scale the program execution. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Thus, an application such as a threedimensional rendering that might take a long time for a single server to accomplish can be scaled in the cloud to many servers at once for a short period of time, accomplishing the task at a similar or lower price but at a much faster rate. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In future applications, developers will need to balance the architectural needs of their programs so their applications create new threads when it is appropriate or create new virtual machines. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Applications will also need to be mindful of how they use cloud resources, when it is appropriate to scale execution to the cloud, how to monitor the instances they are running, and when not to expand their usage of the cloud. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This will require a new way of thinking about application development, and the ability to scale correctly is something that will have to be architected into applications from the ground up. |ENDSENT|

|STARTSENT| APIs Management Core connectivity and delivery Abstraction Hardware Facilities Authentication Security cluster Images VMM Compute Network Storage HVAC Power Space Platforms A platform in the cloud is a software layer that is used to create higher levels of service. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| As you learned in Chapter |NUMBER| many different Platform as a Service (PaaS) providers offer services meant to provide developers with different capabilities. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In Chapter |NUMBER| PaaS is explored more thoroughly, but for now it is useful to cite three of the major examples that are provided in this |URL|’s |URL| Platform Windows Azure Platform Google Apps and the Google AppEngine These three services offer all the hosted hardware and software needed to build and deploy Web applications or services that are custom built by the developer within the context and range of capabilities that the platform allows. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Platforms represent nearly the full cloud software stack, missing only the presentation layer that represents the user interface. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This is the same portion of the cloud computing stack that is a virtual appliance and is shown in Figure |URL| What separates a platform from a virtual appliance is that the software that is installed is constructed from components and services and controlled through the API that the platform provider publishes. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| It makes sense for operating system vendors to move their development environments into the cloud with the same technologies that have been successfully used to create Web applications. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Thus, you might find a platform based on a Sun xVM hypervisor virtual machine that includes a NetBeans Integrated Development Environment (IDE) and that supports the Sun GlassFish Part Examining the Value Proposition Web stack programmable using Perl or Ruby. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| For Windows, Microsoft would be similarly interested in providing a platform that allowed Windows developers to run on a Hyper-V VM, use the |URL| application framework, support one of its enterprise applications such as SQL Server, and be programmable within Visual is essentially what the Azure Platform does. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This approach allows someone to develop a program in the cloud that can be used by others. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Platforms often come replete with tools and utilities to aid in application design and deployment. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Depending upon the vendor, you may find developer tools for team collaboration, testing tools, instrumentation for measuring program performance and attributes, versioning, database and Web service integration, and storage tools. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Most platforms begin by establishing a developer community to support the work done in the environment. |ENDSENT|

|STARTSENT| User interface Presentation mobility Presentation platform Data Video Voice Embedded Mobile PC APIs Applications Various by vendor The Application Programming Interface is one of the key differentiators separating cloud computing from the older models of Internet applications, because it is the means for instantiating resources needed to support applications. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| An API can control data flow, communications, and other important aspects of the cloud application. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Unfortunately, each cloud vendor has their own cloud API, none of them are standard, and the best you can hope for is that eventually the major cloud venAPIs will interoperate and exchange data. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| For now, the use of proprietary APIs results in vendor lock-in, which is why you are advised to choose systems that implement APIs based on open standards. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Virtual Appliances Applications such as a Web server or database server that can run on a virtual machine image are referred to as virtual appliances. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The name virtual appliance is a little misleading because it conjures up the image of a machine that serves a narrow purpose. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Virtual appliances are software installed on virtual modules that are meant to run a particular machine instance or image type. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A virtual appliance is a platform instance. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Therefore, virtual appliances occupy the middle of the cloud computing stack (refer to Figure |URL| A virtual appliance is a common deployment object in the cloud, and it is one area where there is considerable activity and innovation. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| One of the major advantages of a virtual appliance is that you can use the appliances as the basis for assembling more complex services, the appliance being one of your standardized components. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Virtual appliances remove the need for application configuration and maintenance from your list of system management chores. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Part Examining the Value Proposition You run across virtual appliances in IaaS systems such as Elastic Compute Cloud which is discussed in detail in Chapter |NUMBER|. |ENDSENT|

|STARTSENT| Amazon has negotiated licenses from these vendors that are part of your per-use pricing when you run these applications on their servers. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Virtual appliances are far easier to install and run than an application that you must set up yourself. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| However, virtual appliances are also much larger than the application themselves would be because they are usually bundled with the operating system on which they are meant to run. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| An application that is |NUMBER| or might require a virtual appliance that is to in size. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Usually, when a virtual appliance is created, the operating system is stripped of all excess functionality that required by the appliance, because the appliance is meant to be used as is. |ENDSENT|

|STARTSENT| n Communication Protocols Cloud computing arises from services available over the Internet communicating using the standard Internet protocol suite underpinned by the HTTP and HTTPS transfer protocols. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The other protocols and standards that expose compute and data resources in the cloud either format data or communications in packets that are sent over these two transport protocols. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In order to engage in interprocess communication (IPC) processes, many protocols have been applied to distributed networking over the years. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Various forms of RPC (Remote Procedure Call) implementations (including DCOM, Java RMI, and CORBA) attempt to solve the problem of engaging services and managing transactions over what is essentially a stateless network. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The first of the truly Web-centric RPC technologies was XML-RPC, which uses platformindependent XML data to encode program calls that are transported over HTTP, the networking transport to which nearly everyone is connected. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Note You can find a full description of the common Internet protocol standards in Networking Bible by Barrie Sosinsky, Wiley, |NUMBER|. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| These protocols form the basis for much of the discussion in any good networking textbook. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| n As Internet computing became more firmly entrenched over the last decade, several efforts began to better define methods for describing and discovering services and resources. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The most widely used message-passing standard at the moment is the Simple Object Access Protocol (SOAP), which essentially replaces XML-RPC. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| SOAP uses XML for its messages and uses RPC and HTTP for message passing. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| SOAP forms the basis for most of the Web services stacks in use today. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| If you examine the XML file used in a SOAP transaction, you find that it contains a message and the instructions on how to use the message. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The message has a set of rules that are translated into application instances and datatypes, and it defines the methods that must be used to initiate procedure calls and then return a response. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Several standards have emerged to allow the discovery and description of Web-based resources. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The most commonly used model for discovery and description used with SOAP messaging is the Web Services Description Language (WSDL), a World Wide Web Consortium |URL| Internet standard. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| WSDL lets a Web service advertise itself in terms of a collection of endpoints or ports associated with a specific network address (URL) that can be Part Examining the Value Proposition addressed using XML messages to provide a service. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In WSDL, a service is a container that performs a set of functions that are exposed to Web protocols. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Taken together, the protocol and port are a binding to which messages are passed and operations are performed. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A bound service is one that responds to any valid HTTP request sent to it. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The important thing to remember about WSDL is that it defines a Web public interface. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Cross-Ref Chapter |NUMBER| which describes Service Oriented Architecture, continues the discussion of these various components in building an application in the cloud from a component-based architecture. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| n Using WSDL and SOAP, a number of extensions were created that allow various Web services to describe additional sets of properties and methods that they could provide. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| These extensions fall under the name or the “WS-star” specifications. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A number of extensions are in common use, with the following being the most widely WS-Addressing WS-Discovery WS-Eventing WS-Federation WS-MakeConnection WS-Messaging WS-MetadataExchange WS-Notification WS-Policy WS-ResourceFramework WS-Security WS-Transfer WS-Trust These different specifications provide a standard means of adding metadata to a SOAP message by modifying the message header while maintaining the message body structure. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In this way, a standard method for metadata exchange is piggybacked onto the WSDL XML message. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Each of these different specifications is in a different state of development. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| You use these various services in your daily work. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| For example, the Web Services Dynamic Discovery specification (WS-Discovery) is a specification for multicast discovery on a LAN (Local Area Network) that is extended to Web services, most often as SOAP over UDP (User Datagram Protocol). |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| When you open the Network Neighborhood in Windows and use the People Near Me feature, WS-Discovery goes into action and shows you discoverable resources. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Chapter |NUMBER|: Understanding Cloud Architecture These services carried over XML messages using the SOAP protocol access remote server applications in ways that are becoming increasingly complex. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Whereas earlier methods for provided a means through a gateway like CGI to access media content on servers, the current data communications burden servers with accepting and processing very complex requests or engaging their clients in sophisticated negotiations that seek to minimize the amount of processing that must be done and the information that must be exchanged as the response. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| None of this type of rich media servicing was ever envisaged in the construction of the Internet, and all of it is essentially a kludge. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Over the years, a variety of platform-specific RPC specifications, such as DCOM (Distributed Common Object Model) and CORBA (Common Object Response Broker Architecture), were developed to allow software components that ran on different computers to interoperate with one another. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| As SOAP and were developing, those protocols began to build into their specifications server application features from these other technologies in a more platform-independent protocol. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| What was really needed was a method for standardizing resources on the Web, which is where the idea of REST comes in. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| REST stands for Representational State Transfer, and it owes its original description to the work of Roy Fielding, who was also a co-developer of the HTTP protocol. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| REST assigns a global identifier to a resource so there is a uniform method for accessing information sources. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| That identifier is a URI expressed in HTTP form. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Given a resource then at a known address, various network clients in the form of what are called user agents can then communicate with that resource using HTTP commands (requests) to exchange information in the form of documents or files. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Typical data transfers might use XML, text, an image file, a JSON document, or some other standard or agreed upon format to perform the data exchange. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A transaction following the rules of REST is therefore considered to be RESTful, and this is the basis for cloud computing transactions to be initiated, processed, and completed in most modern implementations. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| While REST is heavily used, it is not the only data interchange standard that is used by cloud services. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Another example of a data exchange standard is the Atom or Atom Publishing Protocol (APP). |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Atom is a syndication format that allows for HTTP protocols to create and update information. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| |URL| Data Services Framework is another system for transferring data using a RESTful transaction and standard HTTP commands. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Cloud services span the gamut of computer audio and video streaming, instant messaging, and so forth. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Each of these areas uses protocols developed for network use and adapted for use by Web services. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The impact of cloud computing on network communication is to encourage the use of open-network protocols in place of proprietary protocols. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| For example, in the area of instant messaging, which is a major cloud service, the SIMPLE protocol (which stands for the Session Initiated Protocol for Instant Messaging and Presence Leveraging Extensions) is in widespread use today. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| SIMPLE is based on the IETF Session Initiation Protocol (SIP) standard and is an open standard. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Although most early IM (Instant Messaging) services used proprietary standards, many IM services now support SIMPLE because without this support, it would be hard for the different services to interoperate. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Similarly, in the area of VoIP, you find that the open XMPP or the Extensible Messaging and Presence Protocol is used. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Part Examining the Value Proposition Applications Although the cloud computing stack encompasses many details that describe how clouds are constructed, it is not a perfect vehicle for expressing all the considerations that one must account for in any deployment. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| An important omission arises from the nature of distributed Web applications and the design of Internet protocols as a stateless service. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The Internet was designed to treat each request made to a server as an independent transaction. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Therefore, the standard HTTP commands are all atomic in GET to read data, PUT to writedata, and so on. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| While stateless servers are easier to architect and stateless transactions are more resilient and can survive outages, much of the useful work that computer systems need to accomplish are stateful. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| the classic example. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| When you go to a reservation system to purchase something, you query inventory, reserve the item, and then pay for it. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In a multiuser system, if you have a stateful system, you cannot know whether the item you reserved has already been taken by another user before you can enter your payment for the item. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Should you decide you want the item at some later time, it is much easier to restore the item to inventory and return payments or make other adjustments if you can roll back all the steps as a transactional unit. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Much of the really hard development efforts that have gone into making the Web useful in commerce have centered around creating mechanisms to change a set of stateless transactions into stateful ones. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The development of transaction servers, message queuing servers, and other middleware is meant to bridge this problem. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Cloud computing is no exception to this problem, and to an extent it amplifies the problem by not only making transactions stateless but also virtualizing resources so transactions are always occurring in physically different locations. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In cloud computing, a variety of constructs are brought to bear to solve these issues, but these are the two most important The notion of process flow can be choreographed as a service The use of what is referred to as a service bus that controls cloud components In time, other methods for establishing transactional integrity may be developed that are better suited to cloud computing, but these are the standard methods that are now part of the Service Oriented Architecture. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Chapter |NUMBER| takes up this topic in more detail, but it is something you should certainly keep in mind as you read through the intervening chapters. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Connecting to the Cloud Clients can connect to a cloud service in a number of different ways. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| These are the two most common A Web browser A proprietary application Chapter |NUMBER|: Understanding Cloud Architecture These applications can be running on a server, a PC, a mobile device, or a cell phone. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| What these devices have in common with either of these application types is that they are exchanging data over an inherently insecure and transient medium. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| There are three basic methods for securely connecting over a Use a secure protocol to transfer data such as SSL (HTTPS), FTPS, or IPsec, or connect using a secure shell such as SSH to connect a client to the cloud. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Create a virtual connection using a virtual private network (VPN), or with a remote data transfer protocol such as Microsoft RDP or Citrix ICA, where the data is protected by a tunneling mechanism. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Encrypt the data so that even if the data is intercepted or sniffed, the data will not be meaningful. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The best client connections use two or more of these techniques to communicate with the cloud. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In current browser technology, clients rely on the Web service to make available secure connections, but in the future, it is likely that cloud clients will be hardened so the client itself enforces a secure connection. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| If ever logged into a hotel connection and browsed the network, you may find that often you can access systems on the network that been protected with a firewall; an improperly configured firewall connection to the cloud is even worse. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| That has led people to drag portable routers with them, which provide a personal hardware firewall; many of these devices have VPN built directly into them. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Other solutions include using VPN software; here are three recommended AnchorFree Hotspot Shield (|URL| Gbridge (|URL| a third-party VPN based on GoogleTalk infrastructure Gbridge is an interesting solution that illustrates the use of VPN over a cloud connection. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| To use this product, you need to log into the GoogleTalk (or Gtalk) network and connect to another computer using your Google account. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Gbridge allows additional people to join a connection when invited and supports collaborative features such as desktop sharing using the Virtual Network Computing (VNC) software, chat, live folder browsing, folder synchronization, and automated backup. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Gbridge also works with applications deployed using Google Apps, allowing you to securely connect to these applications using a VPN. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Figure |URL| shows browsing a folder over a VPN connection using SecureShares feature. |ENDSENT|

|STARTSENT| The primary differentiation between these devices is whether or not they are capable of running video and animation (particularly Adobe Flash). |ENDSENT|

|STARTSENT| Chromium The Browser as an Operating System The Google Chrome OS is a Linux open-source operating system designed to be a robust cloud client. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Unlike many other Linux distributions, Chrome is not a software installation, but is shipped installed on validated hardware from Google-approved OEMs (Original Equipment Manufacturers), just as the Android operating system is shipped on a variety of phones. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The intent is to have a tightly coupled hardware offering that supports features in the Chrome OS and that would be highly efficient. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Early designs have shown Chrome running on tablet designs that would position it as an Apple iPad competitor running on netbook-type devices in the range. |ENDSENT|

|STARTSENT| n The expectation is that the first versions of Chrome systems will appear in late |NUMBER| perhaps in both consumer and enterprise offerings. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| There is also an open-source version of this cloud client called Chromium (|URL| which shares the same code base. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The Chromium architecture is built as a three-tier system with a hardware layer, the browser and window manager, and a set of system software and utilities. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The Chrome OS has been described as a hardened operating system because it incorporates a sandbox architecture for running applications and also performs automatic updates. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Also included in the system is a version of remote desktop connection software that creates an encrypted connection like RDP, ICA, or a VNC client. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The Chrome OS hardware specification includes a Trusted Platform Module, which provides for a “trusted bootpath” along with a hardware switch that can be used to boot the system into a developer model. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In that mode, some of the security features are turned off, allowing the user to reset the system. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Demonstrations of early prototypes of Chrome and Chromium OS systems have shown that they are capable of nearly instantaneous startup. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Chromium Linux kernel has adopted the Upstart (|URL| event-based replacement for the init daemon, which is used to launch services concurrently, restore stalled jobs, and perform delayed system startup. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The fast boot time is possible because the device is devoid of most of the devices in modern PCs. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Chromium has also adopted a set of security routines in firmware that run during startup and store the information necessary to perform verified system restoration. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Essentially, the Chrome OS looks like the Chrome browser. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Chrome is interesting because Google has essentially stripped down the operating system to run one specific application that connects to the Internet. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The user interface is similar to the Chrome Web browser and includes a media player that plays views JPEGs, and plays media content both online and offline. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Adobe Flash is integrated directly into the Chrome OS, just as it is in the Chrome browser. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| When you launch Chrome, you see links to the major Google cloud applications such as Gmail, Google Apps, and YouTube, along with other major sites such as Facebook, Hulu, Pandora, Twitter, and others. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Figure |URL| shows an early demonstration of the Chrome OS, its multi-tab interface, and its application launcher utility. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| From this same demonstration is shown the Google Reader application with a page from Alice in Wonderland, displayed in Figure |URL| Chapter |NUMBER|: Understanding Cloud Architecture Google will include on Chromium the Google Cloud Print service that allows an application to print to any connected printer without accessing a printer driver. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This system frees Chromium from having to develop hardwareand OS-specific print subsystems. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Instead, a proxy is installed in Chrome that registers a printer with the service, and this proxy manages print jobs for the user. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The Chrome OS devices that appear, as well as the competitors such as the Apple iPad and a host of other similar devices from other system vendors, signal a sea change in the manner in which users access the cloud, and they represent the impact on the manner in which many users perform their daily work. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| anyone’s guess how impactful these introductions will be, but it is clear that they are not simply another competitor to Windows and Macintosh desktop-oriented systems. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| They represent the move into a cloud-based future where applications run and data is stored remotely. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Their success is likely to be contingent upon how fast consumers and businesses become comfortable with the idea of outsourcing these functions. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In time, the transition is probably inevitable because the economies of scale and efficiency that cloud computing offers is too compelling to ignore. |ENDSENT|

|STARTSENT| Summary In this chapter, you learned about the various architectural layers that make up the cloud computing stack. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Cloud computing may be seen to be an extension of older Internet standards, but it includes some new architecture. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In particular, infrastructure components were described, as were platform components. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Platform services are software-based and can include a class of applications referred to as virtual appliances. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The focus of the chapter was how all the different parts of cloud computing work together. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Many of the important standards are aimed at managing transactions in the cloud and making components work together. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This chapter took an initial look at SOAP, XML, and the various WSDL services. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The chapter ended by considering the development of a new class of cloud-connected clients. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| These clients, which are often hardware and software solutions like the Google Chrome OS, may have major impact in changing the model by which people connect to the Internet and get their work done. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| They have many advantages, but we will have to wait to see how readily consumers and businesses are willing to adopt this new computing paradigm. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In the next chapter, each of the different Internet service models is more closely described. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| IN THIS CHAPTER Learning about different service types Creating clouds with Infrastructure as a Service Working with Software as a Service Developing applications on a Platform as a Service Securing cloud transactions with Identity as a Service Understanding Services and Applications by Type This chapter describes some of the different types of cloud computing models, categorized as a set of service models. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| You may think of cloud computing applications as being composed of a set of layers upon which distributed applications may be built or hosted. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| These layers include Infrastructure, Platform, and Software. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Depending on the type and level of service being offered, a client can build on these layers to create cloud-based applications. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The service models described as a Service (IaaS), Software as a Service (SaaS), and Platform as a Service useful in categorizing not only cloud computing capabilities, but specific vendor offerings, products, and services. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Infrastructure as a Service allows for the creation of virtual computing systems or networks. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Software as a Service represents a hosted application that is universally available over the Internet, usually through a browser. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| With Software as a Service, the user interacts directly with the hosted software. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| SaaS may be seen to be an alternative model to that of shrink-wrapped software and may replace much of the boxed software that we buy today. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Platform as a Service is a cloud computing infrastructure that creates a development environment upon which applications may be build. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| PaaS provides a model that can be used to create or augment complex applications such as Customer Relation Management (CRM) or Enterprise Resource Planning (ERP) systems. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| PaaS offers the benefits of cloud computing and is often componentized and based on a service-oriented architecture model. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| As cloud computing matures, several service types are being introduced and overlaid upon these architectures. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The most fully developed of these service types is Identity as a Service (IDaaS). |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Identity as a Service provides authentication and authorization services on distributed networks. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Infrastructure and Part Examining the Value Proposition supporting protocols for IDaaS are described in this chapter. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Other service types such as Compliance as a Service (CaaS), provisioning, monitoring, communications, and many vertical services yet to be fully developed are touched upon in this chapter. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Defining Infrastructure as a Service (IaaS) You can broadly partition cloud computing into four layers that form a cloud computing ecosystem, as shown in Figure |URL| The Application layer forms the basis for Software as a Service (SaaS), while the Platform layer forms the basis for Platform as a Service (PaaS) models that are described in the next two sections. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Infrastructure as a Service (IaaS) creates what may be determined to be a utility computing model, something that you can tap into and draw from as you need it without significant limits on the scalability of your deployment. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| You pay only for what you need when you need it. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| IaaS may be seen to be an incredibly disruptive technology, one that can help turn a small business into a large business nearly overnight. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This is a most exciting prospect; one that is fueling a number of IaaS startups during one of the most difficult recessions of recent memory. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Infrastructure as a Service (IaaS) is a cloud computing service model in which hardware is virtualized in the cloud. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In this particular model, the service vendor owns the servers, storage, network infrastructure, and so forth. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The developer creates virtual hardware on which to develop applications and services. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Essentially, an IaaS vendor has created a hardware utility service where the user provisions virtual resources as required. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| FIGURE |URL| The cloud computing ecosystem Business Process (SOA) Application Services Platform Services Infrastructure Services Chapter |NUMBER|: Understanding Services and Applications by Type The developer interacts with the IaaS model to create virtual private servers, virtual private storage, virtual private networks, and so on, and then populates these virtual systems with the applications and services it needs to complete its solution. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In IaaS, the virtualized resources are mapped to real systems. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| When the client interacts with an IaaS service and requests resources from the virtual systems, those requests are redirected to the real servers that do the actual work. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| IaaS workloads The fundamental unit of virtualized client in an IaaS deployment is called a workload. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A workload simulates the ability of a certain type of real or physical server to do an amount of work. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The work done can be measured by the number of Transactions Per Minute (TPM) or a similar metric against a certain type of system. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In addition to throughput, a workload has certain other attributes such as Disk measured in Per Second IOPS, the amount of RAM consumed under load in MB, network throughput and latency, and so forth. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In a hosted application environment, a cliapplication runs on a dedicated server inside a server rack or perhaps as a standalone server in a room full of servers. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In cloud computing, a provisioned server called an instance is reserved by a customer, and the necessary amount of computing resources needed to achieve that type of physical server is allocated to the needs. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Figure |URL| shows how three virtual private server instances are partitioned in an IaaS stack. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The three workloads require three different sizes of small, medium, and large. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A client would reserve a machine equivalent required to run each of these workloads. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The IaaS infrastructure runs these server instances in the data center that the service offers, drawing from a pool of virtualized machines, RAID storage, and network interface capacity. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| These three layers are expressions of physical systems that are partitioned as logical units. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| LUNs, the cloud interconnect layer, and the virtual application software layer are logical constructs. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| LUNs are logical storage containers, the cloud interconnect layer is a virtual network layer that is assigned IP addresses from the IaaS network pool, and the virtual application software layer contains software that runs on the physical VM that have been partitioned from physical assets on the private cloud. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| From an architectural standpoint, the client in an IaaS infrastructure is assigned its own private network. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The Amazon Elastic Computer Cloud described in detail in Chapter |NUMBER| behaves as if each server is its own separate you create your own Virtual Private Cloud (an add-on feature), which provides a workaround to this problem. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| When you scale your deployment, you are adding additional networks to your infrastructure, which makes it easy to logically scale an deployment, but imposes additional network overhead because traffic must be routed between logical networks. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Amazon Web routing limits broadcast and multicast traffic because (Data Link) networking is not supported. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Rackspace Cloud |URL| follows the AWS IP assignment model. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Other IaaS infrastructures such as the one |URL| (|URL| offers or a traditional VMWare cloud-assigned networks on a per-user basis, which allows for Level |NUMBER| networking options. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The most prominent Level |NUMBER| protocols that you might use are tunneling options, because they enable VLANs. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Part Examining the Value Proposition FIGURE |URL| A virtual private server partition in an IaaS cloud Virtual Machine Layer Logical Unit Number (LUN) Cloud Layer Interconnection Layer RAID Layer Virtual Application Software Layer Network Interface Layer Ethernet Consider a transactional eCommerce system, for which a typical stack contains the following Web server Application server File server Database Transaction engine This eCommerce system has several different workloads that are queries against the database, processing of business logic, and serving up Web pages. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Chapter |NUMBER|: Understanding Services and Applications by Type The classic example of an IaaS service model is |URL|’s Amazon Web Services (AWS). |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| AWS has several data centers in which servers run on top of a virtualization platform (Xen) and may be partitioned into logical compute units of various sizes. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Developers can then apply system images containing different operating systems and applications or create their own system images. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Storage may be partitions, databases may be created, and a range of services such a messaging and notification can be called upon to make distributed application work correctly. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Cross-Ref Amazon Web Services offers a classic Service Oriented Architecture (SOA) approach to IaaS. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| You learn more about AWS in Chapter |NUMBER|; a description of the Service Oriented Architecture approach to building distributed applications is described in Chapter |NUMBER|. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| n Pods, aggregation, and silos Workloads support a certain number of users, at which point you exceed the load that the instance sizing allows. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| When you reach the limit of the largest virtual machine instance possible, you must make a copy or clone of the instance to support additional users. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A group of users within a particular instance is called a pod. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Pods are managed by a Cloud Control System (CCS). |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In AWS, the CCS is the AWS Management Console. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Sizing limitations for pods need to be accounted for if you are building a large cloud-based application. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Pods are aggregated into pools within an IaaS region or site called an availability zone. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In very large cloud computing networks, when systems fail, they fail on a basis, and often on a basis. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| For IaaS infrastructure, the availability zones are organized around the data centers in Northern California, Northern Virginia, Ireland, and Singapore. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A failover system between zones gives IaaS private clouds a very high degree of availability. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Figure |URL| shows how pods are aggregated and virtualized in IaaS across zones. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| When a cloud computing infrastructure isolates user clouds from each other so the management system is incapable of interoperating with other private clouds, it creates an information silo, or simply a silo. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Most often, the term silo is applied to PaaS offerings such as |URL| or QuickBase, but silos often are an expression of the manner in which a cloud computing infrastructure is architected. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Silos are the cloud computing equivalent of compute They are processing domains that are sealed off from the outside. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| When you create a private virtual network within an IaaS framework, the chances are high that you are creating a silo. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Silos impose restrictions on interoperability that runs counter to the open nature of build-componentized service-oriented applications. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| However, that is not always a bad thing. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A silo can be its own ecosystem; it can be protected and secured in ways that an open system be. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Silos just as flexible as open systems and are subject to vendor lock-in. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Part Examining the Value Proposition FIGURE |URL| Pods, aggregation, and failover in IaaS Pod Cloud Control System Workloads Zone |NUMBER| Zone |NUMBER| Zone |NUMBER| Zone |NUMBER| Pod |NUMBER| Failover Pod |NUMBER| Failover Failover Command Defining Platform as a Service (PaaS) The Platform as a Service model describes a software environment in which a developer can create customized solutions within the context of the development tools that the platform provides. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Platforms can be based on specific types of development languages, application frameworks, or other constructs. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A PaaS offering provides the tools and development environment to deploy applications on another application. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Often a PaaS tool is a fully integrated development environment; that is, all the tools and services are part of the PaaS service. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| To be useful as a cloud computing offering, PaaS systems must offer a way to create user interfaces, and thus support standards such as HTLM, JavaScript, or other rich media technologies. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In a PaaS model, customers may interact with the software to enter and retrieve data, perform actions, get results, and to the degree that the vendor allows it, customize the platform involved. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The customer takes no responsibility for maintaining the hardware, the software, or the development of the applications and is responsible only for his interaction with the platform. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The vendor is responsible for all the operational aspects of the service, for maintenance, and for managing the lifecycle. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The one example that is most quoted as a PaaS offering is App Engine platform, which is described in more detail in Chapter |NUMBER|. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Developers program against the App Engine using published APIs. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The tools for working within the development framework, as well as the structure of the file system and data stores, are defined by Google. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Another example of a PaaS offering is Chapter |NUMBER|: Understanding Services and Applications by Type |URL| |URL|’s developer platform for its SaaS offerings, described in the next section. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| |URL| is an example of an add-on development environment. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A developer might write an application in a programming language like Python using the Google API. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The vendor of the PaaS solution is in most cases the developer, who is offering a complete solution to the customer. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Google itself also serves as a PaaS vendor within this system, because it offers many of its Web service applications to customers as part of this service model. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| You can think of Google Maps, Google Earth, Gmail, and the myriad of other PaaS offerings as conforming to the PaaS service model, although these applications themselves are offered to customers under what is more aptly described as the Software as a Service (SaaS) model that is described below. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The difficulty with PaaS is that it locks the developer (and the customer) into a solution that is dependent upon the platform vendor. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| An application written in Python against API using the Google App Engine is likely to work only in that environment. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| There is considerable vendor lock-in associated with a PaaS solution. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Defining Software as a Service (SaaS) The most complete cloud computing service model is one in which the computing hardware and software, as well as the solution itself, are provided by a vendor as a complete service offering. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| It is referred to as the Software as a Service (SaaS) model. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| SaaS provides the complete infrastructure, software, and solution stack as the service offering. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A good way to think about SaaS is that it is the cloud-based equivalent of shrink-wrapped software. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Software as a Service (SaaS) may be succinctly described as software that is deployed on a hosted service and can be accessed globally over the Internet, most often in a browser. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| With the exception of the user interaction with the software, all other aspects of the service are abstracted away. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Every computer user is familiar with SaaS systems, which are either replacements or substitutes for locally installed software. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Examples of SaaS software for end-users are Google Gmail and Calendar, QuickBooks online, Zoho Office Suite, and others that are equally well known. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| SaaS applications come in all shapes and sizes, and include custom software such as billing and invoicing systems, Customer Relationship Management (CRM) applications, Help Desk applications, Human Resource (HR) solutions, as well as myriad online versions of familiar applications. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Many people believe that SaaS software is not customizable, and in many SaaS applications this is indeed the case. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| For user-centric applications such as an office suite, that is mostly true; those suites allow you to set only options or preferences. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| However, many other SaaS solutions expose Application Programming Interfaces (API) to developers to allow them to create custom composite applications. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| These APIs may alter the security model used, the data schema, workflow characteristics, and other fundamental features of the expression as experienced by the user. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Examples of an SaaS platformwith an exposed API are |URL| and |URL| So SaaS does not necessarily mean that the software is static or monolithic. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Part Examining the Value Proposition SaaS characteristics All Software as a Service (SaaS) applications share the following |NUMBER|. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The software is available over the Internet globally through a browser on demand. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The typical license is subscription-based or usage-based and is billed on a recurring basis. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In a small number of cases a flat fee may be changed, often coupled with a maintenance fee. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Table |URL| shows how different licensing models compare. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The software and the service are monitored and maintained by the vendor, regardless of where all the different software components are running. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| There may be executable client-side code, but the user responsible for maintaining that code or its interaction with the service. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Reduced distribution and maintenance costs and minimal end-user system costs generally make SaaS applications cheaper to use than their shrink-wrapped versions. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Such applications feature automated upgrades, updates, and patch management and much faster rollout of changes. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| SaaS applications often have a much lower barrier to entry than their locally installed competitors, a known recurring cost, and they scale on demand (a property of cloud computing in general). |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| All users have the same version of the software so each software is compatible with |NUMBER|. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| SaaS supports multiple users and provides a shared data model through a single-instance, multi-tenancy model. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The alternative of software virtualization of individual instances also exists, but is less common. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| TABLE |URL| Shrink-Wrapped versus SaaS Licensing Licensing Location Shrink-Wrapped Software Owned Locally installed Management Local IT staff Hybrid Model SaaS Subscription (flat fee) Available through an application Application Service Provider (ASP) Metered subscription Cloud based Cloud vendor through a Service Level Agreement Chapter |NUMBER|: Understanding Services and Applications by Type Open SaaS and SOA A considerable amount of SaaS software is based on open source software. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| When open source software is used in a SaaS, you may hear it referred to as Open SaaS. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The advantages of using open source software are that systems are much cheaper to deploy because you have to purchase the operating system or software, there is less vendor lock-in, and applications are more portable. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The popularity of open source software, from Linux to APACHE, MySQL, and Perl (the LAMP platform) on the Internet, and the number of people who are trained in open source software make Open SaaS an attractive proposition. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The impact of Open SaaS will likely translate into better profitability for the companies that deploy open source software in the cloud, resulting in lower development costs and more robust solutions. |ENDSENT|

|STARTSENT| A mashup is an application that can display a Web page that shows data and supports features from two or more sources. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Annotating a map such as Google maps is an example of a mashup. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Mashups are considered one of the premier examples of Web |URL| and that is technoloability to support social network systems. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A mashup requires three separate An interactive user interface, which is usually created with Ajax, JavaScript, or CSS. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Web services that can be accessed using an API, and whose data can be bound and transported by Web service protocols such as SOAP, REST, XML/RPC, and Data transfer in the form of XML, KML (Keyhole Markup Language), JSON (JavaScript Object Notation), or the like. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Mashups are an incredibly useful hybrid Web application, one that SaaS is a great enabler for. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The Open Mashup Alliance (OMA; see |URL| is a non-profit industry group dedicated to supporting technologies that implement enterprise mashups. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This group supports the developing standard, the Enterprise Mashup Markup Language (EMML), which is a Domain Specific Language (DSL). |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This group predicts that the use of mashups will grow by a factor of |NUMBER| within just a few years. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Gartner Group predicts that approximately |NUMBER| percent of all software sold by |NUMBER| will use the SAAS model, offered either by vendors or an intermediary party, sometimes referred to as an aggregator. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| An aggregator bundles SaaS applications from different vendors and presents them as part of a unified platform or solution. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Note a notion that SaaS will eventually replace all locally installed software. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| However, owning software has several advantages that greatly inhibit this You exposed to the risk of an SaaS company going out of business; you dependent upon the vagaries of an Internet connection; you subject to the often much slower processing speed of a distributed computing model (compared to your local system). |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| I believe the introduction of SaaS applications will eventually drive down the price of major applications such as Microsoft Office and Adobe Photoshop because the most important functionality contained in commercial packages becomes available at equal quality online for a much lower cost. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| n SaaS examples abound, and while many SaaS offerings are based on proprietary software, a cloud computing service is required to be highly interoperable with other services and therefore easily replaced by a newer or better version of that function. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| When you think about this difference, visualize the situation involved for large enterprise applications such as CRM and ERP, which involve large application suites containing multiple interacting data stores. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| SaaS software based on the Service Oriented Architecture described in Chapter |NUMBER| has the potential of decoupling this integration, with all the attendant benefits. |ENDSENT|
