|STARTSENT| Part Examining the Value Proposition Defining Identity as a Service (IDaaS) The establishment and proof of an identity is a central network function. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| An identity service is one that stores the information associated with a digital entity in a form that can be queried and managed for use in electronic transactions. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Identity services have as their core a data store, a query engine, and a policy engine that maintains data integrity. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Distributed transaction systems such as internetworks or cloud computing systems magnify the difficulties faced by identity management systems by exposing a much larger attack surface to an intruder than a private network does. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Whether it is network traffic protection, privileged resource access, or some other defined right or privilege, the validated authorization of an object based on its identity is the central tenet of secure network design. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In this regard, establishing identity may be seen as the key to obtaining trust and to anything that an object or entity wants to claim ownership of. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Services that provide digital identity management as a service have been part of internetworked systems from Day One. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Like so many concepts in cloud computing, IDentity as a Service is a FLAVor (Four Letter Acronym) of the month, applied to services that already exist. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The Domain Name Service can run on a private network, but is at the heart of the Internet as a service that provides identity authorization and lookup. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The name servers that run the various Internet domains .ORG, .MIL, .RU, and so on) are IDaaS servers. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| DNS establishes the identity of a domain as belonging to a set of assigned addresses, associated with an owner and that information, and so forth. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| If the identification is the assigned IP number, the other properties are its metadata. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| You can categorize a myriad of services as IDaaS that run in the cloud. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| However, when most experts in the area of IDaaS define an identity service, they narrow the definition so the service must operate as a component according to the rules of a Service Oriented Architecture, as is defined in Chapter |NUMBER|. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This narrower definition restricts IDaaS to newer software services, services that interoperate, and therefore services that are standards based. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| best to keep this narrower definition in mind when you discuss IDaaS in a modern context. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| What is an identity? |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| An identity is a set of characteristics or traits that make something recognizable or known. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In computer network systems, it is digital identity that most concerns us. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A digital identity is those attributes and metadata of an object along with a set of relationships with other objects that makes an object identifiable. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Not all objects are unique, but by definition a digital identity must be unique, if only trivially so, through the assignment of a unique identification attribute. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| An identity must therefore have a context in which it exists. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This description of an identity as an object with attributes and relationships is one that programwould recognize. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Databases store information and relationships in tables, rows, and columns, and the identity of information stored in this way conforms to the notion of an entity and a alternatively under the notion of an object role model database architects are always wrestling with the best way of reducing their data set to a basic set of identities. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| You can extend this notion to the idea of an identity having a profile and profiling services such as Facebook as being an extension of the notion of Identity as a Service in cloud computing. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Chapter |NUMBER|: Understanding Services and Applications by Type An identity can belong to a person and may include the Things you Biological characteristics such as age, race, gender, appearance, and so forth Things you Biography, personal data such as social security numbers, PINs, where you went to school, and so on Things you A pattern of blood vessels in your eye, your fingerprints, a bank account you can access, a security key you were given, objects and possessions, and more Things you relate Your family and friends, a software license, beliefs and values, activities and endeavors, personal selections and choices, habits and practices, an iGoogle account, and more To establish your identity on a network, you might be asked to provide a name and password, which is called a single-factor authentication method. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| More secure authentication requires the use of at least two-factor authentication; for example, not only name and password (things you know) but also a transient token number provided by a hardware key (something you have). |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| To get to multifactor authentication, you might have a system that examines a biometric factor such as a fingerprint or retinal blood vessel of which are essentially unique things you are. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Multifactor authentication requires the outside use of a network security or trust service, and it is in the deployment of trust services that our first and most common IDaaS applications are employed in the cloud. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Of course, many things have digital identities. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| User and machine accounts, devices, and other objects establish their identities in a number of ways. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| For user and machine accounts, identities are created and stored in domain security databases that are the basis for any network domain, in directory services, and in data stores in federated systems. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Network interfaces are identified uniquely by Media Access Control (MAC) addresses, which alternatively are referred to as Ethernet Hardware Addresses (EHAs). |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| It is the assignment of a network identity to a specific MAC address that allows systems to be found on networks. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The manner in which Microsoft validates your installation of Windows and Office is called Windows Product Activation and creates an identification index or profile of your system, which is instructive. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| During activation, the following unique data items are A software product key and product ID The uniquely assigned Global Unique Identifier or GUID PC manufacturer CPU type and serial number BIOS checksum Network adapter and its MAC address Display adapter SCSCI and IDE adapters RAM amount Hard drive and volume serial number Part Examining the Value Proposition Optical drive Region and language settings and user locale From this information, a code is calculated, checked, and entered into the registration database. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Each of these uniquely identified hardware attributes is assigned a weighting factor such that an overall sum may be calculated. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| If you change enough and CPU, display adapter, RAM amount, and hard trigger a request for a reactivation based on system changes. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This activation profile is also required when you register for the Windows Genuine Advantage program. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Windows Product Activation and Windows Genuine Advantage are cloud computing applications, albeit proprietary ones. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Whether people consider these applications to be services is a point of contention. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Networked identity service classes To validate Web sites, transactions, transaction participants, clients, and network forms of identity been deployed on networks. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Ticket or token providing services, certificate servers, and other trust mechanisms all provide identity services that can be pushed out of private networks and into the cloud. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Identity protection is one of the more expensive and complex areas of network computing. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| If you think about it, requests for information on identity by personnel such as HR, managers, and others; by systems and resources for access requests; as identification for network traffic; and the myriad other requirements mean that a significant percentage of all network traffic is supporting an identification service. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Literally hundreds of messages on a network every minute are checking identity, and every Ethernet packet contains header fields that are used to identify the information it contains. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| As systems become even more specialized, it has become increasingly difficult to find the security experts needed to run an ID service. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| So Identity as a Service or the related hosted (managed) identity services may be the most valuable and cost effective distributed service types you can subscribe to. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Identity as a Service (IDaaS) may include any of the Authentication services (identity verification) Directory services Federated identity Identity governance Identity and profile management Policies, roles, and enforcement Provisioning (external policy administration) Registration Risk and event monitoring, including audits Single sign-on services (pass-through authentication) Chapter |NUMBER|: Understanding Services and Applications by Type The sharing of any or all of these attributes over a network may be the subject of different government regulations and in many cases must be protected so that only justifiable parties may have access to the minimal amount that may be disclosed. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This level of access defines what may be called an identity relationship. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Note The Burton Group (|URL| a well-known computer industry analyst firm located in Midvale, Utah, has a trademark on the term IaaS as defined as Identity as a Service for use in the publication of their research in this area. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The Burton Group is a well-known authority in the field of network infrastructure, particularly directory services and more recently in cloud computing. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In this book, I use the term IaaS as applied to Infrastructure as a Service and use IDaaS to identify Identity as a Service. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| n Identity system codes of conduct Certain codes of conduct must be observed legally, and if not legally at the moment, then certainly on a moral basis. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Cloud computing services that observe these codes do so at their peril. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In working with IDaaS software, evaluate IDaaS applications on the following User control for Users control their identity and must consent to the use of their information. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Minimal The minimal amount of information should be disclosed for an intended use. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Justifiable Only parties who have a justified use of the information contained in a digital identity and have a trusted identity relationship with the owner of the information may be given access to that information. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Directional An ID system must support bidirectional identification for a public entity so that it is discoverable and a unidirectional identifier for private entities, thus protecting the private ID. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Interoperability: A cloud computing ID system must interoperate with other identity services from other identity providers. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Unambiguous human An IDaaS application must provide an unambiguous mechanism for allowing a human to interact with a system while protecting that user against an identity attack. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Consistency of An IDaaS service must be simple to use, consistent across all its uses, and able to operate in different contexts using different technologies. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| IDaaS interoperability Identity as a Service provides an easy mechanism for integrating identity services into individual applications with minimal development effort, by allowing the identification logic and storage of an attributes to be maintained externally. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| IDaaS applications may be separated from other distributed security systems by their compliance with SOA standards (as described in Chapter |NUMBER| “Understanding Service Oriented Architecture”), particularly if you want to have these services interoperate and be federated. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Part Examining the Value Proposition Therefore, cloud computing IDaaS applications must rely on a set of developing industry standards to provide interoperability. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The following are among the more important of these User centric authentication (usually in the form of information The OpenID and CardSpace specifications support this type of data object. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The XACML Policy This is a general-purpose authorization policy language that allows a distributed ID system to write and enforce custom policy expressions. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| XACML can work with SAML; when SAML presents a request for ID authorization, XACML checks the ID request against its policies and either allows or denies the request. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The SPML Provisioning This is an XML language that is used to integrate and interoperate service provisioning requests. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| SPML is a standard of Provision Services Technical Committee (PSTC) that conforms to the SOA architecture. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The XDAS Audit The Distributed Audit Service provides accountability for users accessing a system, and the detection of security policy violations when attempts are made to access the system by unauthorized users or by users accessing the system in an unauthorized way. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Figure |URL| shows how these different standards form an identity service framework. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| FIGURE |URL| Open standards that support an IDaaS infrastructure for cloud computing Authentication (InforCards and OpenID) Identity Providers (OpenID and InforCards) Authorization Audit Provisioning The Identity Governance Framework (IGF) is a standards initiative of the Liberty Alliance (|URL| that is concerned with the exchange and control of identity information using standards such as WS-Trust, ID-WSF, SAML, and LDAP directory services. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The Liberty Alliance was established by an industry group in |NUMBER| with the purpose of Chapter |NUMBER|: Understanding Services and Applications by Type promoting open identity interchanges through policy standards that applications can use to enforce privacy as well as to allow privacy auditing. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In |NUMBER| this group released its Client Attribute Requirements Markup Language (CARML) and a set of IGF Privacy Constraints that forms the basis of the open source project called Aristotle (|URL| ProjectAris), which has as its goal the creation of an API for identity interchange. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| User authentication OpenID is a developing industry standard for authenticating “end users” by storing their digital identity in a common format. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| When an identity is created in an OpenID system, that information is stored in the system of any OpenID service provider and translated into a unique identifier. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Identifiers take the form of a Uniform Resource Locator (URL) or as an Extensible Resource Identifier (XRI) that is authenticated by that OpenID service provider. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Any software application that complies with the standard accepts an OpenID that is authenticated by a trusted provider. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A very impressive group of cloud computing vendors serve as identity providers (or OpenID providers), including AOL, Facebook, Google, IBM, Microsoft, MySpace, Orange, PayPal, VeriSign, LiveJournal, Ustream, Yahoo!, and others. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The OpenID standard applies to the unique identity of the URL; it is up to the service provider to store the information and specify the forms of authentication required to successfully log onto the system. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Thus an OpenID authorization can include not only passwords, but smart cards, hardware keys, tokens, and biometrics as well. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| OpenID is supported by the OpenID Foundation |URL| a organization that promotes the technology. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| These are samples of trusted providers and their URL Blogger: or MySpace: |URL| Google: |URL| Google |URL| Microsoft: |URL| MyOpenID: Orange: |URL| or simply |URL| Verisign: WordPress: Yahoo! |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| : |URL| After you have logged onto a trusted provider, that logon may provide you access to other Web sites that support OpenID. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| When you request access to a site through your browser (or another application that is referred to as a user-agent), that site serves as the “relying party” and requests of the server or server-agent that it verify the identifier. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| You need to log onto these other Web sites, if your OpenID is provided. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Most trusted providers require that you indicate which Web sites you want to share your OpenID identifier with and the information is submitted automatically to the next site. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Part Examining the Value Proposition CardSpace is a Microsoft software client that is part of the Identity Metasystem and built into the Web Services Protocol Stack. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This stack is built on the OASIS standards (WS-Trust, WS-Security, WS-SecurityPolicy, and WS-MetadataExchange), so any application that conforms with the OASIS WSstandards can interoperate with CardSpace. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| CardSpace was introduced with Frameworks |URL| and can be installed on Windows XP, Server |NUMBER| and later. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| It is installed by default on Windows Vista and Windows |NUMBER|. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| CardSpace offers another way of authenticating users in the cloud. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| An Information Card may be requested with an HTML tag, and the trusted Identity Provider then creates an encrypted and digitally signed token using the Security Token Service (STS) that is part of a WS-Trust reply mechanism. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| CardSpace may be seen as an alternative mechanism to the use of OpenID and SAML and is used to sign into those services as well as Windows Live ID accounts. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Cross-Ref See Chapter |NUMBER| for more information on Windows Live. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| n Figure |URL| shows a personal Identification Card that is stored locally on a Windows |NUMBER| system. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Managed Information Cards are stored on a network service and can be made available to other cloud services upon demand. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| FIGURE |URL| This is a private CardSpace Identification Card. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Managed Identification Cards that store similar information are stored on a network service and can be shared to the cloud. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Chapter |NUMBER|: Understanding Services and Applications by Type Note IBM and Novell both support Information Cards under the Web Service Protocol Stack, as well as SAML and OpenID through an industry initiative known at the Higgins Open Source Identity Framework |URL| which uses the interface metaphor of an i-Card. |ENDSENT|

|STARTSENT| Before leaving the subject of digital identity services and formats, it is appropriate to mention some file format standards such as vCard, which stores identity data in the form of an electronic business card. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Less frequently encountered is the vCard derivative hCard. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| vCard was an industry initiative in the as a means for identifying parties in e-mail exchanges. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| FIGURE |URL| The Higgins Open Source Identity Framework uses an i-Card metaphor and interoperable identity service APIs to create a vendor-neutral cloud-based authentication service. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Part Examining the Value Proposition As e-mail platforms such as Lotus Notes and MS Exchange broadened the notion of e-mail to include calendars and appointments, the vCalendar format was created, which eventually was developed into iCalendar. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The current version |URL| of vCard is part of the vCardDAV working group within the IETF and through RFC |NUMBER| and RFC |NUMBER| is undergoing the process of standardization. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| vCard is more of an interchange file format for an identity than it is an identity trustauthorization service, which is why it is mentioned in passing here. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| To read more about vCard and vCalendar, go to |URL| Authorization markup languages Information requests and replies in cloud computing are nearly always in the form of XML replies or requests. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| XML files are text files and are self-describing. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| That is, XML files contain a schema that describes the data it contains or contains a point to another text file with its schema. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A variety of specialized XML files are in the identity framework, the ones of note being XACML and SAML, shown in Figure |URL| The eXtensible Access Control Markup Language (XACML) is an OASIS standard (see |URL| for a set of policy statements written in XML that support an authentication process. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A policy in XACML describes a subject element that requests an action from a resource. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| These three elements operate within an environment that also can be described in terms of an Action element. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Subject and Action elements (which are terms of art in XACML) are elements that can have one or more attributes. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Resources (which are services, system components, or data) have a single attribute, which is usually its URL. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The location at which policy is managed is referred to as the Policy Administration Point (PAP). |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Policy requests are passed through to the location where the policy logic can be executed, referred to as the Policy Decision Point (PDP). |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The result of the policy is transmitted through the PAP to the resource that acts on and enforces the PDP policy decision, which is referred to as the Policy Enforcement Point (PEP). |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| An XACML engine also may access a resource that provides additional information that can be used to determine policy logic, called a Policy Information Point (PIP). |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Examples of PIP services are LDAP or Active Directory servers. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A request for identification goes to the XACML engine, where it becomes a directive from the Policy Decision Point to the Policy Enforcement Point called an obligation. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The main method for exchanging information between an authentication and authorization service in a Service Oriented Architecture is the Security Assertion Markup Language (SAML). |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In SAML, a service provider passes a statement or set of statements (called assertions) to an identity provider that must be evaluated. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The identity provider must determine if the principle or user requesting access is registered with the identity service and is who he claims to be. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| SAML in most instances operates as a mechanism; it makes no demands on the identification service as to how the identity is authenticated. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Should the identity provider validate the identity of the principle in the assertion, it passes a local authorization to the service provider, which then enforces an access-control judgment based on the authorization. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Chapter |NUMBER|: Understanding Services and Applications by Type FIGURE |URL| SAML integrates with XACML to implement a policy engine in a Service Oriented Architecture to support identity services authorization. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Enforcement Policy Point Attribute Response Attribute Response Attribute Response Request Attribute Request Attribute Request Attribute LA uthority R esponse Attribute Assertion Attribute Assertion Attribute Assertion LRequest Authority Attribute Assertion Attribute Assertion Attribute Assertion X A C M L P olicy A ssertion X A C M L P olicy A ssertion X A C M L P olicy A ssertion Attribute Assertion Attribute Assertion XACML Assertion Attribute Authority Policy Decision Point Administration Policy Point Attribute Repository Policy Repository Part Examining the Value Proposition A SAML assertion is a security statement in the SAML file that makes a claim regarding authentication, attributes, or authorization. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The statement is of this Assertion X created at Time T by User U about Subject S is true when Conditions C are TRUE. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| It is up to the identity provider to parse this statement and determine its validity. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The SAML protocol request is often referred to as a query; the three different supported query types are an authentication query, an attribute query, and an authorization decision query. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| SAML requests use a SOAP binding; that is, the SAML request or response is embedded in a SOAP wrapper within an HTTP message. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| SAML is used to provide a mechanism for a Web Browser Single Sign On (SSO). |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In this instance, a Web browser is the user agent, which requests access to a resource that is authorized by a SAML service provider. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The service provider takes a request from a user for access to the resource and sends an authentication request to the SAML identity provider directly from the initiating user agent (Web browser). |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Figure |URL| shows the SAML Single Sign On mechanism. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The Service Provisioning Markup Language (SPML) is another of the OASIS open standards developed to provide for service provisioning. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Provisioning is the process by which a resource is prepared for use, reserved, accessed, used, and then released when the transaction is completed. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A classic example of provisioning a resource is the reservation and use of a phone line or a Virtual Private Network. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A provisioning system has three types of A Requesting Authority (RA) is the client, the Provisioning Service Point (PSP) is the cloud component that receives the request and returns a response to the RA, and a Provisioning Service Targets (PST) is the software application upon which the provisioning action is performed. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The SPML provisioning system (which can be thought of as an architectural layer) means that identity information need only be entered into these three components once. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| SPML is used to prepare Web services and applications for use, signal that the resource is available for use and waiting for instructions, and signal when the use or transaction has been completed. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| With SPML, a system can provide automated user and system access, enforce access rights, and make cloud computing services available across network systems. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Without a provisioning system, a cloud computing system can be very inefficient and potentially unreliable. |ENDSENT|

|STARTSENT| XHTML ID response SAML Service Provider Service Requester (User Agent) ID Identity Provider Internetwork Resource Defining Compliance as a Service (CaaS) Cloud computing by its very nature spans different jurisdictions. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The laws of the country of a origin may not match the laws of the country where the request is processed, and possible that neither laws match the laws of the country where the service is provided. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Compliance is much more than simply providing an anonymous service token to an identity so they can obtain access to a resource. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Compliance is a complex issue that requires considerable expertise. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Part Examining the Value Proposition While Compliance as a Service (CaaS) appears in discussions, few examples of this kind of service exist as a general product for a cloud computing architecture. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A Compliance as a Service application would need to serve as a trusted third party, because this is a type of service. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| CaaS may need to be architected as its own layer of a SOA architecture in order to be trusted. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A CaaS would need to be able to manage cloud relationships, understand security policies and procedures, know how to handle information and administer privacy, be aware of geography, provide an incidence response, archive, and allow for the system to be queried, all to a level that can be captured in a Service Level Agreement. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| a tall order, but CaaS has the potential to be a great value-added service. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In order to implement CaaS, some companies are organizing what might be referred to as “vertical clouds,” clouds that specialize in a vertical market. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Examples of vertical clouds that advertise CaaS capabilities include the athenahealth (|URL| for the medical industry bankserv (|URL| for the banking industry ClearPoint PCI for merchant transactions under the Payment Card Industry Data Security Standard FedCloud (|URL| for government Rackserve PCI Compliant Cloud (|URL| another PCI CaaS service) much easier to envisage a CaaS system built inside a private cloud where the data is under the control of a single entity, thus ensuring that the data is under that secure control and that transactions can be audited. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Indeed, most of the cloud computing compliance systems to date have been built using private clouds. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| It is easy to see how CaaS could be an incredibly valuable service. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A well-implemented CaaS service could measure the risks involved in servicing compliance and ensure or indemnify customers against that risk. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| CaaS could be brought to bear as a mechanism to guarantee that an e-mail conformed to certain standards, something that could be a new electronic service of a network of national postal something that could help bring an end to the scourge of spam. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Summary In this chapter, you learned about cloud computing service types. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Service types are models upon which distributed applications are created and hosted. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The main service models in cloud computing are Infrastructure, Platform, and Software. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Vendors offer services based on these different service models called Infrastructure as a Service (IaaS), Software as a Service (SaaS), and Platform as a Service (PaaS), which are helpful in understanding how products and services are organized. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Chapter |NUMBER|: Understanding Services and Applications by Type Infrastructure as a Service is a hardware model in which you can create virtual computing systems or networks and deploy your applications on those servers. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Software as a Service is a hosted application that is the cloud equivalent of a traditional desktop application. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Platform as a Service is a development environment that builds upon an existing cloud computing application infrastructure. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Other service types are possible. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| You learned about Identity as a Service (IDaaS), which enables secure transactions on a distributed network. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In time many vertical services for cloud computing will appear. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Chapter |NUMBER| “Understanding Abstraction and Virtualization,” considers some of the more important characteristics of cloud computing networks and applications. |ENDSENT|

|STARTSENT| The key to creating a pool is to provide an abstraction mechanism so that a logical address can be mapped to a physical resource. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Computers use this technique for placing files on disk drives, and cloud computing networks use a set of techniques to create virtual servers, virtual storage, virtual networks, and perhaps one day virtual applications. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Abstraction enables the key benefit of cloud shared, ubiquitous access. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In this chapter, you learn about how load balancing can be used to create high performance cloud-based solutions. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| |URL|’s network is an example of this approach. |ENDSENT|

|STARTSENT| An example of this type of approach is hypervisors that create virtual machine technologies. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Several important cloud computing approaches use a strictly hardwarebased approach to abstraction. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| I describe vSphere infrastructure in some detail, along with some of the unique features and technologies that VMware has developed to support this type of cloud. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Finally, I describe some approaches to making applications portable. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Application portability is a difficult proposition, and work to make applications portable is in its infancy. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Two approaches are described, the Simple API and Virtual Application Appliance (VAA). |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| VAAs are containers that abstract an application from the operating system, and they offer the potential to make an application portable from one platform to another. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Part Using Platforms Using Virtualization Technologies The dictionary includes many definitions for the word “cloud.” A cloud can be a mass of water droplets, gloom, an obscure area, or a mass of similar particles such as dust or smoke. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| When it comes to cloud computing, the definition that best fits the context is “a collection of objects that are grouped together.” It is that act of grouping or creating a resource pool that is what succinctly differentiates cloud computing from all other types of networked systems. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Not all cloud computing applications combine their resources into pools that can be assigned on demand to users, but the vast majority of cloud-based systems do. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The benefits of pooling resources to allocate them on demand are so compelling as to make the adoption of these technologies a priority. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Without resource pooling, it is impossible to attain efficient utilization, provide reasonable costs to users, and proactively react to demand. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In this chapter, you learn about the technologies that abstract physical resources such as processors, memory, disk, and network capacity into virtual resources. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| When you use cloud computing, you are accessing pooled resources using a technique called virtualization. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Virtualization assigns a logical name for a physical resource and then provides a pointer to that physical resource when a request is made. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Virtualization provides a means to manage resources efficiently because the mapping of virtual resources to physical resources can be both dynamic and facile. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Virtualization is dynamic in that the mapping can be assigned based on rapidly changing conditions, and it is facile because changes to a mapping assignment can be nearly instantaneous. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| These are among the different types of virtualization that are characteristic of cloud Access: A client can request access to a cloud service from any location. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Application: A cloud has multiple application instances and directs requests to an instance based on conditions. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| CPU: Computers can be partitioned into a set of virtual machines with each machine being assigned a workload. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Alternatively, systems can be virtualized through ing technologies. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Storage: Data is stored across storage devices and often replicated for redundancy. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| To enable these characteristics, resources must be highly configurable and flexible. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| You can define the features in software and hardware that enable this flexibility as conforming to one or more of the following mobility P|NUMBER|V: Physical to Virtual V|NUMBER|V: Virtual to Virtual V|NUMBER|P: Virtual to Physical P|NUMBER|P: Physical to Physical D|NUMBER|C: Datacenter to Cloud Chapter |NUMBER|: Understanding Abstraction and Virtualization C|NUMBER|C: Cloud to Cloud C|NUMBER|D: Cloud to Datacenter D|NUMBER|D: Datacenter to Datacenter The techniques used to achieve these different types of virtualization are the subject of this chapter. |ENDSENT|

Bittman, |DATE|, Research Note virtualization is a key enabler of the first four of five key attributes of cloud Service-based: A service-based architecture is where clients are abstracted from service providers through service interfaces. |ENDSENT|
