|STARTSENT| Internet The services provided by cloud computing are based on Internet protocols and formats. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Load Balancing and Virtualization One characteristic of cloud computing is virtualized network access to a service. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| No matter where you access the service, you are directed to the available resources. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The technology used to distribute service requests to resources is referred to as load balancing. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Load balancing can be implemented in hardware, as is the case with BigIP servers, or in software, such as the Apache extension, the Pound load balancer and reverse proxy software, and the Squid proxy and cache daemon. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Load balancing is an optimization technique; it can be used to increase utilization and throughput, lower latency, reduce response time, and avoid system overload. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The following network resources can be load Network interfaces and services such as DNS, FTP, and HTTP Connections through intelligent switches Processing through computer system assignment Storage resources Access to application instances Without load balancing, cloud computing would very difficult to manage. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Load balancing provides the necessary redundancy to make an intrinsically unreliable system reliable through managed redirection. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| It also provides fault tolerance when coupled with a failover mechanism. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Load balancing is nearly always a feature of server farms and computer clusters and for high availability applications. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Part Using Platforms A load-balancing system can use different mechanisms to assign service direction. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In the simplest load-balancing mechanisms, the load balancer listens to a network port for service requests. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| When a request from a client or service requester arrives, the load balancer uses a scheduling algorithm to assign where the request is sent. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Typical scheduling algorithms in use today are round robin and weighted round robin, fastest response time, least connections and weighted least connections, and custom assignments based on other factors. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A session ticket is created by the load balancer so that subsequent related traffic from the client that is part of that session can be properly routed to the same resource. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Without this session record or persistence, a load balancer would not be able to correctly failover a request from one resource to another. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Persistence can be enforced using session data stored in a database and replicated across multiple load balancers. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Other methods can use the browser to store a client-side cookie or through the use of a rewrite engine that modifies the URL. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Of all these methods, a session cookie stored on the client has the least amount of overhead for a load balancer because it allows the load balancer an independent selection of resources. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The algorithm can be based on a simple round robin system where the next system in a list of systems gets the request. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Round robin DNS is a common application, where IP addresses are assigned out of a pool of available IP addresses. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Google uses round robin DNS, as described in the next section. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Advanced load balancing The more sophisticated load balancers are workload managers. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| They determine the current utilization of the resources in their pool, the response time, the work queue length, connection latency and capacity, and other factors in order to assign tasks to each resource. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Among the features you find in load balancers are polling resources for their health, the ability to bring standby servers online (priority activation), workload weighting based on a capacity (asymmetric loading), HTTP traffic compression, TCP offload and buffering, security and authentication, and packet shaping using content filtering and priority queuing. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| An Application Delivery Controller (ADC) is a combination load balancer and application server that is a server placed between a firewall or router and a server farm providing Web services. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| An Application Delivery Controller is assigned a virtual IP address (VIP) that it maps to a pool of servers based on application specific criteria. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| An ADC is a combination network and application layer device. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| You also may come across ADCs referred to as a content switch, multilayer switch, or Web switch. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| These vendors, among others, sell ADC Brocade Communication Systems (|URL| Chapter |NUMBER|: Understanding Abstraction and Virtualization An ADC is considered to be an advanced version of a load balancer as it not only can provide the features described in the previous paragraph, but it conditions content in order to lower the workload of the Web servers. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Services provided by an ADC include data compression, content caching, server health monitoring, security, SSL offload and advanced routing based on current conditions. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| An ADC is considered to be an application accelerator, and the current products in this area are usually focused on two areas of network optimization, and an application or framework optimization. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| For example, you may find that are tuned to accelerate |URL| or AJAX applications. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| An architectural layer containing ADCs is described as an Application Delivery Network (ADN), and is considered to provide WAN optimization services. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Often an ADN is comprised of a pair of redundant ADCs. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The purpose of an ADN is to distribute content to resources based on application specific criteria. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| ADN provide a caching mechanism to reduce traffic, traffic prioritization and optimization, and other techniques. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| ADN began to be deployed on Content Delivery Networks (CDN) in the late where it added the ability to optimize applications (application fluency) to those networks. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Most of the ADC vendors offer commercial ADN solutions. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In addition to the ADC vendors in the list above, these are additional ADN vendors, among Akamai Technologies (|URL| cloud is a good example of the use of load balancing, so in the next section consider how Google handles the many requests that they get on a daily basis. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The Google cloud According to the Web site tracking firm Alexa (|URL| Google is the single most heavily visited site on the Internet; that is, Google gets the most hits. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The investment Google has made in infrastructure is enormous, and the Google cloud is one of the largest in use today. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| It is estimated that Google runs over a million servers worldwide, processes a billion search requests, and generates twenty petabytes of data per day. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Part Using Platforms Google is understandably reticent to disclose much about its network, because it believes that its infrastructure, system response, and low latency are key to the success. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Google never gives datacenter tours to journalists, disclose where its datacenters are located, and obfuscates the locations of its datacenters by wrapping them in a corporate veil. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Thus, the discretely named Tetra LLC (limited liability company) owns the land for the Council Bluffs, Iowa, site, and Lapis LLC owns the land for the Lenoir, North Carolina, site. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This makes Google infrastructure watching something akin to a sport to many people. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| So what follows is what we think we know about infrastructure and the basic idea behind how Google distributes its traffic by pooling IP addresses and performing several layers of load balancing. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Google has many datacenters around the world. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| As of |DATE|, Rich Miller of |URL| wrote that Google had at least |NUMBER| major installations in the United States and many more around the world. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Google supports over |NUMBER| country specific versions of the Google index, and each localization is supported by one or more datacenters. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| For example, Paris, London, Moscow, Sao Paolo, Tokyo, Toronto, Hong Kong, Beijing and others support their counlocale. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Germany has three centers in Berlin, Frankfurt, and Munich; the Netherlands has two at Groningen and Eemshaven. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The countries with multiple datacenters store index replicas and support network peering relationships. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Network peering helps Google have low latency connections to large Internet hubs run by different network providers. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| You can find a list of sites as of |NUMBER| from FAQ at |URL| |URL| Based on current locations and the statements, datacenters are sited based on the following factors (roughly in order of |NUMBER|. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Availability of cheap and, if possible, renewable energy |NUMBER|. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The relative locations of other Google datacenters such that the site provides the lowest latency response between sites |NUMBER|. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Location of nearby Internet hubs and peering sites |NUMBER|. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A source of cooling water |NUMBER|. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The ability to purchase a large area of land surrounding the site Speculation on why Google purchases large parcels of land ranges from creating a buffer zone between the datacenter and surrounding roads and towns or possibly to allow for building wind farms when practical. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Tax concessions from municipalities that lower overhead Google maintains a pool of hundreds of IP addresses, all of which eventually resolve to its Mountain View, California, headquarters. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| When you initiate a Google search, your query is sent to a DNS server, which then queries DNS servers. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The Google DNS servers examine the pool of addresses to determine which addresses are geographically closest to the query origin and uses a round robin policy to assign an IP address to that request. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The request usually goes to the nearest Chapter |NUMBER|: Understanding Abstraction and Virtualization datacenter, and that IP address is for a cluster of Google servers. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This DNS assignment acts as a first level of IP virtualization, a pool of network addresses have been load balanced based on geography. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A Google cluster can contain thousands of servers. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Google servers are racks of commodity (low cost) or servers containing |NUMBER| to |NUMBER| servers per rack with one switch per rack. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Each switch is connected to a core gigabit switch. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Google servers run a customized version of Linux with applications of several types. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| When the query request arrives at its destination, a Google cluster is sent to a load balancer, which forwards that request to a Squid proxy server and Web cache dameon. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This is the second level of IP distribution, based on a measure of the current system loading on proxy servers in the cluster. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The Squid server checks its cache, and if it finds a match to the query, that match is returned and the query has been satisfied. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| If there is no match in the Squid cache, the query is sent to an individual Google Web Server based on current Web server utilizations, which is the third level of network load balancing, again based on utilization rates. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| It is the Google Web Servers that perform the query against the Google index and then format the results into an HTML page that is returned to the requester. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This procedure then performs two more levels of load balancing based on utilization rates. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| secret sauce is its in-memory inverted index and page rank algorithm. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| GoogleBot (a spider or robot) crawls the Web and collects document information. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Some details of the search and store algorithm are known. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Google looks at the title and first few hundred words and builds a word index from the result. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Indexes are stored on an index server. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Some documents are stored as snapshots (PDF, DOC, XLS, and so on), but lots of information is not addressed in the index. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Each document is given a unique ID and the content of the document is disassembled into segments called shards, subjected to a data compression scheme and stored on a document server. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The entire index is maintained in system memory partitioned over each instance of the replicas. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A page rank is created based on the significant links to that page. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Queries are divided into word lists, and the Google algorithm examines the words and the relationships of one word to another. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Those word relationships are mapped against the main index to create a list of documents, a feature called an inverted index. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In an inverted index, words are mapped to documents, which can be done very quickly when the index is fully kept in memory. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The Web server takes the result of a query and composes the Web page from that result. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Ads included on the page are from ad servers, which provide AdSense and AdWords services. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The query also is presented to a spelling server to provide suggestions for alternative spellings to include in the search result. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Certain keywords, data input patterns, and other strings are recognized as having special operational significance. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| For example entering “|NUMBER| plus |NUMBER|” initiates calculator program, and a ten-digit number returns a reverse phone lookup using the phonebook program. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| These programs are supported by special application servers. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Part Using Platforms Google use hardware virtualization; it performs server load balancing to distribute the processing load and to get high utilization rates. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The workload management software transfers the workload from a failed server over to a redundant server, and the failed server is taken offline. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Multiple instances of various Google applications are running on different hosts, and data is stored on redundant storage systems. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Understanding Hypervisors Load balancing virtualizes systems and resources by mapping a logical address to a physical address. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Another fundamental technology for abstraction creates virtual systems out of physical systems. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| If load balancing is like playing a game of hot potato, then virtual machine technologies is akin to playing slice and dice with the potato. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Given a computer system with a certain set of resources, you can set aside portions of those resources to create a virtual machine. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| From the standpoint of applications or users, a virtual machine has all the attributes and characteristics of a physical system but is strictly software that emulates a physical machine. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A system virtual machine (or a hardware virtual machine) has its own address space in memory, its own processor resource allocation, and its own device using its own virtual device drivers. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Some virtual machines are designed to run only a single application or process and are referred to as process virtual machines. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A virtual machine is a computer that is walled off from the physical computer that the virtual machine is running on. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This makes virtual machine technology very useful for running old versions of operating systems, testing applications in what amounts to a sandbox, or in the case of cloud computing, creating virtual machine instances that can be assigned a workload. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Virtual machines provide the capability of running multiple machine instances, each with their own operating system. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| From the standpoint of cloud computing, these features enable VMMs to manage application provisioning, provide for machine instance cloning and replication, allow for graceful system failover, and provide several other desirable features. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The downside of virtual machine technologies is that having resources indirectly addressed means there is some level of overhead. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Virtual machine types A low-level program is required to provide system resource access to virtual machines, and this program is referred to as the hypervisor or Virtual Machine Monitor (VMM). |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A hypervisor running on bare metal is a Type |NUMBER| VM or native VM. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Examples of Type |NUMBER| Virtual Machine Monitors are LynxSecure, RTS Hypervisor, Oracle VM, Sun xVM Server, VirtualLogix VLX, VMware ESX and ESXi, and Wind River VxWorks, among others. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The operating system loaded into a virtual machine is referred to as the guest operating system, and there is no constraint on running the same guest on multiple VMs on a physical system. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Type |NUMBER| VMs have no host operating system because they are installed on a bare system. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| An operating system running on a Type |NUMBER| VM is a full virtualization because it is a complete simulation of the hardware that it is running on. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Chapter |NUMBER|: Understanding Abstraction and Virtualization Note Not all CPUs support virtual machines, and many that do require that you enable this support in the BIOS. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| For example, AMD-V processors (code named Pacifica) and Intel VT-x (code named Vanderpool) were the first of these |NUMBER|-bit offerings that added this type of support. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| n Some hypervisors are installed over an operating system and are referred to as Type |NUMBER| or hosted VM. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Examples of Type |NUMBER| Virtual Machine Monitors are Containers, KVM, Microsoft Hyper V, Parallels Desktop for Mac, Wind River Simics, VMWare Fusion, Virtual Server |NUMBER| Xen, Windows Virtual PC, and VMware Workstation |URL| and Server, among others. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This is a very rich product category. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Type |NUMBER| virtual machines are installed over a host operating system; for Microsoft Hyper-V, that operating system would be Windows Server. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In the section that follows, the Xen hypervisor (which runs on top of a Linux host OS) is more fully described. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Xen is used by Amazon Web Services to provide Amazon Machine Instances (AMIs). |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Figure |URL| shows a diagram of Type |NUMBER| and Type |NUMBER| hypervisors. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| On a Type |NUMBER| VM, a software interface is created that emulates the devices with which a system would normally interact. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This abstraction is meant to place many operations outside the virtual environment, which makes it both programmatically easier and more efficient to execute device than it would be inside a virtual environment. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This type of virtualization is sometimes referred to as paravirtualization, and it is found in hypervisors such as Hyper-V and Xen. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| It is the host operating system that is performing the through a para-API. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| FIGURE |URL| vSphere cloud computing infrastructure model Guest OS Guest OS Guest OS Guest OS Guest OS Guest OS Hypervisor Hypervisor Host Operating System System Hardware System Hardware Type |NUMBER| Hypervisor Type |NUMBER| Hypervisor Part Using Platforms Figure |URL| shows the difference between emulation, paravirtualization, and full virtualization. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In emulation, the virtual machine simulates hardware, so it can be independent of the underlying system hardware. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A guest operating system using emulation does not need to be modified in any way. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Paravirtualization requires that the host operating system provide a virtual machine interface for the guest operating system and that the guest access hardware through that host VM. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| An operating system running as a guest on a paravirtualization system must be ported to work with the host interface. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Finally, in a full virtualization scheme, the VM is installed as a Type |NUMBER| Hypervisor directly onto the hardware. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| All operating systems in full virtualization communicate directly with the VM hypervisor, so guest operating systems do not require any modification. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Guest operating systems in full virtualization systems are generally faster than other virtualization schemes. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The Virtual Machine Interface (VMI) open standard (|URL| that VMware has proposed is an example of a paravirtualization API. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The latest version of VMI is |URL| and it ships as a default installation with many versions of the Linux operating system. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Note Wikipedia maintains a page called “Comparison of platform virtual machines” at |URL| The page contains a table of features of the most common Virtual Machine Managers. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| n You are probably familiar with process or application virtual machines. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Most folks run the Java Virtual Machine or .NET Framework VM (called the Common Language Runtime or CLR) on their computers. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A process virtual machine instantiates when a command begins a process, the VM is created by an interpreter, the VM then executes the process, and finally the VM exits the system and is destroyed. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| During the time the VM exists, it runs as a high-level abstraction. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| FIGURE |URL| Emulation, paravirtualization, and full virtualization types Guest Kernel Kernel Kernel Guest Kernel Kernel Kernel Software Software Software Software Software Software Virtual Environment Host Kernel Kernel Kernel Software Software Software VMVMVM Host VMVM VM Kernel Kernel Kernel Software Software Software VM Control Guest Kernel Kernel Kernel Boot OS Kernel Kernel Kernel Software Software Software Software Software Software Virtual Environment VM Control System Hardware System Hardware Type |NUMBER| Hypervisor Emulation Paravirtualization Full Virtualization Chapter |NUMBER|: Understanding Abstraction and Virtualization Applications running inside an application virtual machine are generally slow, but these programs are very popular because they provide portability, offer rich programming languages, come with many advanced features, and allow platform independence for their programs. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Although many cloud computing applications provide process virtual machine applications, this type of abstraction really suitable for building a large or high-performing cloud network, with one exception. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The exception is the process VMs that enable a class of parallel cluster computing applications. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| These applications are high-performance systems where the virtual machine is operating one process per cluster node, and the system maintains the necessary intra-application communications over the network interconnect. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Examples of this type of system are the Parallel Virtual Machine (PVM; see |URL| and the Message Passing Interface (MPI; see |URL| Some people do not consider these application VMs to be true virtual machines, noting that these applications can still access the host operating system services on the specific system on which they are running. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The emphasis on using these process VMs is in creating a high-performance networked supercomputer often out of heterogeneous systems, rather than on creating a ubiquitous utility resource that characterizes a cloud network. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Some operating systems such as Sun Solaris and IBM AIX |URL| support a feature known as operating system virtualization. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This type of virtualization creates virtual servers at the operating system or kernel level. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Each virtual server is running in its own virtual environment (VE) as a virtual private server (VPS). |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Different operating systems use different names to describe these machine instances, each of which can support its own guest OS. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| However, unlike true virtual machines, VPS must all be running the same OS and the same version of that OS. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Sun Solaris |NUMBER| uses VPS to create what is called Solaris Zones. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| With IBM AIX, the VPS is called a System Workload Partition (WPAR). |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This type of virtualization allows for a dense collection of virtual machines with relatively low overhead. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Operating system virtualization provides many of the benefits of virtualization previously noted in this section. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| VMware vSphere VMware vSphere is a management infrastructure framework that virtualizes system, storage, and networking hardware to create cloud computing infrastructures. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| vSphere is the branding for a set of management tools and a set of products previously labeled VMware Infrastructure. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| vSphere provides a set of services that applications can use to access cloud resources, including VMware A service that aggregates servers into an assignable pool VMware A service that aggregates storage resources into an assignable pool VMware A service that creates and manages virtual network interfaces Application Such as HA (High Availability) and Fault Tolerance vCenter A provisioning, management, and monitoring console for VMware cloud infrastructures Figure |URL| shows an architectural diagram of a vSphere cloud infrastructure. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Part Using Platforms FIGURE |URL| vSphere cloud computing infrastructure model Clients vSphere Client vSphere Web Access vSphere SDK Other Client vCenter Server Availability Scalability Security vCompute vNetwork vStorage Application Services Infrastructure Services vSphere Managed Cloud Aggregated Servers VMs) Aggregated Network Aggregated Storage Storage Network (FC or IP) Chapter |NUMBER|: Understanding Abstraction and Virtualization A vSphere cloud is a pure infrastructure play. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The virtualization layer that abstracts processing, memory, and storage uses the VMware ESX or ESXi virtualization server. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| ESX is a Type |NUMBER| hypervisor; it installs over bare metal (a clean system) using a Linux kernel to boot and installs the vmkernel hypervisor (virtualization kernel and support files). |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| When the system is rebooted, the vmkernel loads first, and then the Linux kernel becomes the first guest operating system to run as a virtual machine on the system and contains the service console. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| VMware is a very highly developed infrastructure and the current leader in this industry. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A number of important add-on products are available for cloud computing applications. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| These are among the more notable Virtual Machine File System A high-performance cluster file system for an cluster. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| VMotion: A service that allows for the migration of a virtual machine from one physical server to another physical server while the virtual server runs continuously and without any interruption of ongoing transactions. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The ability to live migrate virtual machines is considered to be a technological tour de force and a differentiator from other virtual machine system vendors. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Storage A product that can migrate files from one datastore to another datastore while the virtual machine that uses the datastore continues to run. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Virtual A feature that allows a virtual machine to run on two or more physical processors at the same time. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Distributed Resource Scheduler A system for provisioning virtual machines and load balancing processing resources dynamically across the different physical systems that are in use. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A part of the DRS called the distributed power management (DPM) module can manage the power consumption of systems. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| vNetwork Distributed Switch A capability to maintain a network runtime state for virtual machines as they are migrated from one physical system to another. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| DVS also monitors network connections, provides firewall services, and enables the use of thirdparty switches such as the Cisco Nexus to manage virtual networks. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| You can get a better sense of how the different resources are allocated by vSphere into a virtual set of components by examining Figure |URL| Physical computers can be standalone hosts or a set of clustered systems. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In either case, a set of virtual machines can be created that is part of a single physical system or spans two or more physical systems. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| You can define a group of VMs as a Resource Pool (RP) and, by doing so, manage those virtual machines as a single object with a single policy. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Resource Pools can be placed into a hierarchy or nested and can inherit properties of their parent RP. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| As more hosts or cluster nodes are added or removed, vSphere can dynamically adjust the provisioning of VMs to accommodate the policy in place. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This fine tuning of pooled resources is required to accommodate the needs of cloud computing networks. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Part Using Platforms FIGURE |URL| Virtual infrastructure elements Network Network Network Cluster Resource Pool VM VM VM VM Resource Pool Datastores Host Network Network Network VM VM VM Resource Pool The datastore shown at the center of Figure |URL| is a shared storage resource. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| These storage resources can be either Direct Attached Storage (DAS) of a server using SCSI, SAS, or SATA connections, Fibre Channel disk iSCSI disk or Network Attached Storage (NAS) disk arrays. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Although the lines drawn between the datastore and different VMs indicate a direct connection, with the exception of DAS, the other storage types are shared storage solutions. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Storage virtualization is most commonly achieved through a mapping mechanism where a logical storage address is translated into a physical storage address. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Block-based storage such as those used Chapter |NUMBER|: Understanding Abstraction and Virtualization in SANs use a feature called a Logical Unit Identifier (LUN) with specific addresses stored in the form of an offset called the Logical Block Address (LBA). |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The address space mapping then maps the address of the logical or virtual disk (vdisk) to the logical unit on a storage controller. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Storage virtualization may be done in software or in hardware, and it allows requests for virtualized storage to be redirected as needed. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Similarly, network virtualization abstracts networking hardware and software into a virtual network that can be managed. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A virtual network can create virtual network interfaces (VNICs) or virtual LANs (VLANS) and can be managed by a hypervisor, operating system, or external management console. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In a virtualized infrastructure such as the one presented in this section, internal network virtualization is occurring and the hypervisor interacts with networking hardware to create a pseudo-network interface. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| External network virtualization can be done using network switches and VLAN software. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The key feature that makes virtual infrastructure so appealing for organizations implementing a cloud computing solution is flexibility. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Instantiating a virtual machine is a very fast process, typically only a few seconds in length. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| You can make machine images of systems in the configuration that you want to deploy or take snapshots of working virtual machines. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| These images can be brought on-line as needed. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Understanding Machine Imaging In the preceding sections, you have seen how the abstractions that cloud computing needs can be achieved through redirection and virtualization. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A third mechanism is commonly used to provide system portability, instantiate applications, and provision and deploy systems in the cloud. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This third mechanism is through storing the state of a systems using a system image. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Cross-Ref Backing up to the cloud often involves imaging or snapshot applications; this process is described in Chapter |NUMBER| “Working with Cloud-Based Storage.” n A system image makes a copy or a clone of the entire computer system inside a single container such as a file. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The system imaging program is used to make this image and can be used later to restore a system image. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Some imaging programs can take snapshots of systems, and most allow you to view the files contained in the image and do partial restores. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Note The one open standard for storing a system image is the Open Virtualization Format (OVF; see |URL| that is published by the Distributed Task Format (DMTF; |URL| Some notable virtualization vendors, such as VMware, Microsoft, Citrix, and Oracle (Sun), are supporting this effort. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| n Part Using Platforms A prominent example of a system image and how it can be used in cloud computing architectures is the Amazon Machine Image (AMI) used by Amazon Web Services to store copies of a virtual machine. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Because this is a key feature of Elastic Compute Cloud and is discussed in detail in Chapter |NUMBER| I briefly mention it here. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| An AMI is a file system image that contains an operating system, all appropriate device drivers, and any applications and state information that the working virtual machine would have. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| When you subscribe to AWS, you can choose to use one of its hundreds of canned AMIs or to create a custom system and capture that image to an AMI. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| An AMI can be for public use under a free distribution license, for with operating systems such as Windows, or shared by an user with other users who are given the privilege of access. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Cross-Ref Refer to Chapter |NUMBER| “Using Amazon Web Services,” for more information about AMIs and their uses in the service. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| n The AMI file system is not a standard image of a system that is common to many disk imaging programs. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| AMI omits the kernel image and stores a pointer to a particular kernel that is part of the AWS kernel library. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Among the choices are Red Hat Linux, Ubuntu, Microsoft Windows, Solaris, and others. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Files in AMI are compressed and encrypted, and an XML file is written that describes the AMI archive. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| AMIs are typically stored in your Amazon (Simple Storage System) buckets as a set of chunks. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Machine images are sometimes referred to as “virtual that are meant to run on virtualization platforms. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| AWS runs on the Xen hypervisor, for example. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The term virtual appliance is meant to differentiate the software image from an operating virtual machine. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The system image contains the operating system and applications that create an environment. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Most virtual appliances are used to run a single application and are configurable from a Web page. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Virtual appliances are a relatively new paradigm for application deployment, and cloud computing is the major reason for the interest in them and for their adoption. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This area of WAN application portability and deployment, and of WAN optimization of an application based on demand, is one with many new participants. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Certeon (|URL| Expand Networks |URL| and Replify (|URL| are three vendors offering optimization appliances for infrastructure. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Porting Applications Cloud computing applications have the ability to run on virtual systems and for these systems to be moved as needed to respond to demand. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Systems (VMs running applications), storage, and network assets can all be virtualized and have sufficient flexibility to give acceptable distributed WAN application performance. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Developers who write software to run in the cloud will undoubtedly want the ability to port their applications from one cloud vendor to another, but that is a much more difficult proposition. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Cloud computing is a relatively new area of technology, and the major vendors have technologies that interoperate with one another. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Chapter |NUMBER|: Understanding Abstraction and Virtualization The Simple Cloud API If you build an application on a platform such as Microsoft Azure, porting that application to Amazon Web Services or GoogleApps may be difficult, if not impossible. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In an effort to create an interoperability standard, Zend Technologies has started an open source initiative to create a common application program interface that will allow applications to be portable. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The initiative is called the Simple API for Cloud Application Services (|URL| and the effort has drawn interest from several major cloud computing companies. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Among the founding supporters are IBM, Microsoft, Nivanix, Rackspace, and GoGrid. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Simple Cloud API has as its goal a set of common interfaces File Storage Currently Amazon Windows Azure Blob Storage, Nirvanix, and Local storage is supported by the Storage API. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| There are plans to extend this API to Rackspace Cloud Files and GoGrid Cloud Storage. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Document Storage Amazon SimpleDB and Windows Azure Table Storage are currently supported. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Local document storage is planned. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Simple Queue Amazon SQS, Windows Azure Queue Storage, and Local queue services are supported. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Zend intends to add the interface to their open source PHP Framework (|URL| |URL| as the Zend_Cloud framework component. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Vendors such as Microsoft and IBM are supplying adapters that will use part of the Simple Cloud API for their cloud application services. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| AppZero Virtual Application Appliance Applications that run in datacenters are captive to the operating systems and hardware platforms that they run on. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Many datacenters are a veritable Ark of computing. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| So moving an application from one platform to another nearly as simple as moving a machine image from one system to another. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The situation is further complicated by the fact that applications are tightly coupled with the operating systems on which they run. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| An application running on Windows, for example, isolated from other applications. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| When the application loads, it often loads or uses different Dynamic Link Libraries (DLL), and it is through the sharing or modification of DLLs that Windows applications get themselves in trouble. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Further modifications include modifying the registry during installation. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| These factors make it difficult to port applications from one platform to another without lots of careful work. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| If you are a Platform as a Service (PaaS) application developer, you are packaging a complete software stack that includes not only your application, but the operating system and application logic and rules as well. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Vendor lock-in for you application is assured. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The ability to run an application from whatever platform you want is not one of the characteristics of cloud computing, but you can imagine that it is a very attractive proposition. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| While the Simple Cloud API is useful for applications written in PHP, other methods may be needed to make applications easily portable. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| One company working on this problem is AppZero |URL| and its solution is called the Virtual Application Appliance (VAA). |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Part Using Platforms The AppZero solution creates a virtual application appliance as an architectural layer between the Windows or the UNIX operating system and applications. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The virtualization layer serves as the mediator for file memory and application calls and response to DLLs, which has the effect of sandboxing the application. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The running application in AppZero changes none of the registry entries or any of the files on the Windows Server. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| VAA creates a container that encapsulates the application and all the dependencies within a set of files; it is essentially an Application Image for a specific OS. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Dependencies include DLL, service settings, necessary configuration files, registry entries, and machine and network settings. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This container forms an installable server-side application stack that can be run after installation, but has no impact on the underlying operating system. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| VAAs are created using the AppZero Creator wizard, managed with the AppZero Admin tool, and may be installed using the AppZero Director, which creates a VAA runtime application. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| If desired, an application called AppZero Dissolve removes the VAA virtualization layer from the encapsulated application and installs that application directly into the operating system. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Note aspx) and VMware ThinApp (|URL| are two application delivery platforms, but their main focus is on desktop installations and not on server deployment in the cloud. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| n Installations can be done over the network after the AppZero application appliance is installed. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Therefore, with this system, you could run applications on the same Windows Server and eliminate one application from interfering with another; applications would be much more easily ported from one Windows system to another. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| approach provides the necessary abstraction layer that frees an application from its platform dependence. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| An interesting use of VAAs involves segmenting an application into several VAAs, some of which are read-only runtime components, while others can be modified. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| When backing up or replicating VAAs in a cloud, you would need to synchronize only those VAAs that are modified. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In many instances, the portion of an application that changes is only a very small component of large applications, which means that this technique can greatly reduce the amount of data required to replicate a VM in the cloud. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| AppZero envisages using VAAs to create what it calls a stateless cloud. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In a stateless cloud, the applistate information is stored on a network share where it is available to run on different cloud systems as needed. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This approach allows the cloud system to run with a VM containing a clean operating system (like AWS does now) and provisioned by the VAA. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This approach should greatly reduce the number of complete system images that cloud vendors and cloud users should need to store to support their work; it also should make the running of applications on secure, well-performing VEs easier to achieve. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Chapter |NUMBER|: Understanding Abstraction and Virtualization Summary In this chapter, you learned about some of the more important characteristics of cloud computing networks and applications, including ubiquitousness and on-demand service. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| To enable a cloud service, you need to create a pool of resources you can call on. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The key techniques for enabling this are abstraction and virtualization. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Abstraction maps a logical identity or address to a physical identity or address. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Changes to the underlying systems, therefore, do not affect the client requesting a service. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Several different methods for abstraction have been considered. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A widely used technique is load balancing. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| With load balancing, system requests are directed to appropriate systems on demand. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| All large cloud networks use some form of load balancing. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| You learned about some of the details of load balancing for queries. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Another technology virtualizes hardware. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| You learned about the different types of software that can serve as a virtualization layer for operating systems accessing the underlying hardware. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| As an example of hardware virtualization vSphere infrastructure was considered. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| vSphere can create virtual machines, virtual datastores, and virtual networks, and move these resources about while the system is active. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| vSphere is a potent cloud-building technology. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| System imaging also can be useful in creating and instantiating machine instances. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A brief explanation of Amazon Machine Instances was given. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Finally, the topic of application portability was considered. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Applications are hard to move from platform to platform, because they are bound up with the operating system on which they run. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Eventually, applications will be as portable as virtual machines. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A cloud programming interface was described, as was an application delivery appliance. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In Chapter |NUMBER| “Capacity Planning,” the idea of system workloads is described. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Understanding this concept allows you to scale your systems correctly, choose the right type of infrastructure, and do availability planning. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Some of the key performance metrics for cloud computing “right sizing” are described. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| IN THIS CHAPTER Learning about capacity planning for the cloud Capturing baselines and metrics Determining resources and their ceilings Scaling your systems appropriately Capacity Planning Capacity planning seeks to match demand to available resources. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Capacity planning examines what systems are in place, measures their performance, and determines patterns in usage that enables the planner to predict demand. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Resources are provisioned and allocated to meet demand. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Although capacity planning measures performance and in some cases adds to the expertise needed to improve or optimize performance, the goal of capacity planning is to accommodate the workload and not to improve efficiency. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Performance tuning and optimization is not a primary goal of capacity planners. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| To successfully adjust a capacity, you need to first understand the workload that is being satisfied and characterize that workload. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A system uses resources to satisfy cloud computing demands that include processor, memory, storage, and network capacity. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Each of these resources has a utilization rate, and one or more of these resources reaches a ceiling that limits performance when demand increases. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| It is the goal of a capacity planner to identify the critical resource that has this resource ceiling and add more resources to move the bottleneck to higher levels of demand. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Scaling a system can be done by scaling up vertically to more powerful systems or by scaling out horizontally to more but less powerful systems. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This is a fundamental architectural decision that is affected by the types of workloads that cloud computing systems are being asked to perform. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This chapter presents some of these tradeoffs. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Part Using Platforms Network capacity is one of the hardest factors to determine. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Network performance is affected by network at the server, network traffic from the cloud to Internet service providers, and over the last mile from ISPs to homes and offices. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| These factors are also considered. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Capacity Planning Capacity planning for cloud computing sounds like an oxymoron. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Why bother doing capacity planning for a resource that is both ubiquitous and limitless? |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The reality of cloud computing is rather different than the ideal might suggest; cloud computing is neither ubiquitous, nor is it limitless. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Often, performance can be highly variable, and you pay for what you use. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| That said, capacity planning for a cloud computing system offers you many enhanced capabilities and some new challenges over a purely physical system. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A capacity planner seeks to meet the future demands on a system by providing the additional capacity to fulfill those demands. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Many people equate capacity planning with system optimization (or performance tuning, if you like), but they are not the same. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| System optimization aims to get more production from the system components you have. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Capacity planning measures the maximum amount of work that can be done using the current technology and then adds resources to do more work as needed. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| If system optimization occurs during capacity planning, that is all to the good; but capacity planning efforts focus on meeting demand. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| If that means the capacity planner must accept the inherent inefficiencies in any system, so be it. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Note Capacity and performance are two different system attributes. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| With capacity, you are concerned about how much work a system can do, whereas with performance, you are concerned with the rate at which work gets done. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| n Capacity planning is an iterative process with the following |NUMBER|. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Determine the characteristics of the present system. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Measure the workload for the different resources in the CPU, RAM, disk, network, and so forth. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Load the system until it is overloaded, determine when it breaks, and specify what is required to maintain acceptable performance. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Knowing when systems fail under load and what is responsible for the failure is the critical step in capacity planning. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Predict the future based on historical trends and other factors. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Deploy or tear down resources to meet your predictions. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Iterate Steps |NUMBER| through |NUMBER| repeatedly. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Chapter |NUMBER|: Capacity Planning Defining Baseline and Metrics The first item of business is to determine the current system capacity or workload as a measurable quantity over time. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Because many developers create cloud-based applications and Web sites based on a LAMP solution stack, use those applications for our example in this chapter. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| LAMP stands Linux, the operating system Apache HTTP Server (|URL| the Web server based on the work of the Apache Software Foundation MySQL (|URL| the database server developed by the Swedish company MySQL AB, owned by Oracle Corporation through its acquisition of Sun Microsystems PHP (|URL| the Hypertext Preprocessor scripting language developed by The PHP Group Note Either Perl or Python is often substituted for PHP as the scripting language used. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| n These four technologies are open source products, although the distributions used may vary from cloud to cloud and from machine instance to machine instance. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| On Amazon Web Services, machine instances are offered for both Red Hat Linux and for Ubuntu. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| LAMP stacks based on Red Hat Linux are more common than the other distributions, but SUSE Linux and Debian are also common. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Variants of LAMP are available that use other operating systems such as the Macintosh, OpenBSD (OpAMP), Solaris (SAMP), and Windows (WAMP). |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Although many other common applications are in use, LAMP is good to use as an example because it offers a system with two applications (APACHE and MySQL) that can be combined or run separately on servers. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| LAMP is one of the major categories of Amazon Machine Instances that you can create on the Amazon Web Service (see Chapter |NUMBER|). |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Baseline measurements assume that a capacity planner is working with a system that has a Web site based on APACHE, and assume the site is processing database transactions using MySQL. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| There are two important overall workload metrics in this LAMP Page views or hits on the Web site, as measured in hits per second Transactions completed on the database server, as measured by transactions per second or perhaps by queries per second In Figure |URL| the historical record for the Web server page views over a hypothetical day, week, and year are graphed. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| These graphs are created by summing the data from the different servers Part Using Platforms contained in the performance Web logs of the site or measuring throughput from the system based on an intervening service (such as a proxy server). |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| What Figure |URL| shows is a measure of the overall workload of the Web site involved. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Tip Your performance logs are a primary source of data that everyone should have available for planning purposes, but they are not the only source of performance measurements. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A number of companies offer services that can monitor your Web performance. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| For example, sites such as Alertra (|URL| |URL| and SiteUpTime (|URL| can monitor your Web pages to determine their response, latency, uptime, and other characteristics. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Gomez and Keynote expose your site data visually as a set of dashboard widgets. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Because these are third-party services, many Web services use these sites as the compliance monitor for Service Level Agreements (SLAs). |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| n Notice several things about the graphs in Figure |URL| A typical daily log (shown on top) shows two spikes in demand, one that is centered around |TIME| EST when users on the east coast of the United States use the site heavily and another at around |TIME| EST (three hours later; |TIME| PST) when users on the west coast of the United States use the site heavily. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The three-hour time difference is also the difference between Eastern Standard Time and Pacific Standard Time. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| These daily performance spikes occur on workdays, but the spikes always of equal demand, as you can see from the weekly graph, shown in the middle of Figure |URL| On weekends (Saturday and Sunday), the demand rises through the middle of the day and then ebbs later. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Some days show a performance spike, as shown on the Tuesday morning section of the weekly graph. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A goal of capacity planning (and an important business goal) is to correlate these performance spikes and dips with particular events and causations. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Also, at some point your traffic patterns may change, so you definitely want to evaluate these statistics on an ongoing basis. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The yearly graph, at the bottom of Figure |URL| shows that the daily averages and the daily peaks rise steadily over the year and, in fact, double from January at the start of the year to December at year end. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Knowing this, a capacity planner would need to plan to serve twice the traffic while balancing the demands of peak versus average loads. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| However, it may not mean that twice the resources need to be deployed. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The amount of resources to be deployed depends upon the characterization of the Web servers involved, their potential utilization rates, and other factors. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Caution In predicting trends, it is important that the time scale be selected appropriately. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A steady sure rise in demand over a year is much more accurate in predicting future capacity requirements than a sharp spike over a day or a week. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Forecasting based on small datasets is notoriously inaccurate. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| You accurately predict the future (no one can), but you can make good guesses based on your intuition. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| n The total workload might be served by a single server instance in the cloud, a number of virtual server instances, or some combination of physical and virtual servers. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Chapter |NUMBER|: Capacity Planning FIGURE |URL| A Web workload measured on a day, a week, and over the course of a year Time Sun Mon Tu Wed Th Fri Sat Sun Day Jan Daily Averages Daily Averages Daily Averages June Month Jan A number of important characteristics are determined by these baseline WT, the total workload for the system per unit time To obtain WT, you need to integrate the area under the curve for the time period of interest. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| WAVG, the average workload over multiple units of time To obtain WAVG, you need to sum various WTs and divide by the number of unit times involved. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| You may also want to draw a curve that represents the mean work done. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Part Using Platforms WMAX, the highest amount of work recorded by the system This is the highest recorded system utilization. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In the middle graph of Figure |URL| it would be the maximum number recorded on Tuesday morning. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| WTOT, the total amount of work done by the system, which is determined by the sum of WT A similar set of graphs would be collected to characterize the database servers, with the workload for those servers measured in transactions per second. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| As part of the capacity planning exercise, the workload for the Web servers would be correlated with the workload of the database servers to determine patterns of usage. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The goal of a capacity planning exercise is to accommodate spikes in demand as well as the overall growth of demand over time. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Of these two factors, the growth in demand over time is the most important consideration because it represents the ability of a business to grow. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A spike in demand may or may not be important enough to an activity to attempt to capture the full demand that the spike represents. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| System metrics Notice that in the previous section, you determined what amounts to application-level statistics for your site. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| These measurements are an aggregate of one or more Web servers in your infrastructure. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Capacity planning must measure system-level statistics, determining what each system is capable of, and how resources of a system affect system-level performance. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In some instances, the capacity planner may have some influence on system architecture, and the impact of system architecture on applicationand system-level statistics may be examined and altered. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Because this is a rare case, focus on the next step, which defines system performance. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A machine instance (physical or virtual) is primarily defined by four essential CPU Memory (RAM) Disk Network connectivity Each of these resources can be measured by tools that are but for which tools that are their counterparts exist for all operating systems. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Indeed, many of these tools were written specifically to build the operating systems themselves, but another story. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In UNIX, you might use the sar command to display the level of CPU activity. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| sar is installed in Linux as part of the sysstat package. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In Windows, a similar measurement may be made using the Task Manager, the data from which can be dumped to a performance log graphed. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Some tools give you a historical record of performance, which is particularly useful in capacity planning. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| For example, the popular Linux performance measurement tool RRDTool (the Round Robin Database tool; |URL| is valuable in this regard. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Chapter |NUMBER|: Capacity Planning RRDTool is a utility that can capture time-dependent performance data from resources such as a CPU load, network utilization (bandwidth), and so on and store the data in a circular buffer. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| It is commonly used in performance analysis work. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A time interval in RRDTool is called a step, with the value in a step referred to as a primary data point (PDP). |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| When a function is applied to a data point (average, minimum, maximum, and so on), the function is referred to as a Consolidation Function (CF), and the value obtained is a Consolidated Data Point (CDP). |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| An interval is stored in the Round Robin Archive (RRA), and when that interval is filled, it is replaced by new step data. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| RRDTool includes a graphical front end for displaying performance results visually. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| RRDTool is widely used for a number of different purposes. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Figure |URL| shows some of the examples from a gallery of RRDTool graphs found at |URL| FIGURE |URL| RRDTool lets you create historical graphs of a wide variety of performance data. |ENDSENT|
