|STARTSENT| When you create a CloudFront implementation, a CloudFront domain name is registered for your domain name in the form and objects in the CloudFront domain can be mapped to your own domain. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| You store your source files on CloudNet servers in Amazon buckets and then use the CloudFront API to register the bucket with the CloudNet distribution. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Then in your applications, Web pages, and links, you reference the distribution location. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| CloudFront represents the last of the Amazon Web Services that store and serve objects and files. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| To store data in a way that makes it searchable and organizes it, Amazon offers two different database services that are covered in the next section. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Part Using Platforms Understanding Amazon Database Services Amazon offers two different types of database Amazon SimpleDB, which is non-relational, and Amazon Relational Database Service (Amazon RDS), both of which were in beta at the time of this writing. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Dynamic data access is a central element of Web services, particularly “Web |URL|” services, so although AMIs support several of the major databases, it surprising that they would create their own databases as part of the AWS Service Oriented Architecture. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Amazon SimpleDB Amazon SimpleDB is an attempt to create a high performance data store with many database features but without the overhead. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This is analogous to the goals used to create the Amazon Simple Storage System The service is meant to be low touch, in that it abstracts many of the common concerns of database administrators for hardware requirements, software maintenance, indexing, and performance optimization. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| To create a high performance “simple” database, the data store created is flat; that is, it is tional and joins are not supported. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Data stored in SimpleDB domains require maintenances of a schema and is therefore easily scalable and highly available because replication is built into the system. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Data is stored as collections of items with attribute-value pairs, and the system is akin to using the database function within a spreadsheet. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| To support replication, a set of two consistency functions are part of SimpleDB that check data across the different copies. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Transactions are performed as a set of conditional PUTS and DELETES, and you can INSERT, REPLACE, or DELETE values for item attributes. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| These transaction capabilities do not enable features like ROLLBACK, but they allow you to create solutions that maintain optimistic concurrency control and will perform an INSERT based on the value of a counter or timestamp. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| You grow a SimpleDB database by scaling out and creating additional data domains, and SimpleDB integrates with instances and storage. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Data objects stored in can be queried in SimpleDB, returning information about the metadata and pointers to the location. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Data in SimpleDB is automatically indexed and may be queried as needed. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The API is relatively simple, consisting of domain creation, put and get attributes, and SELECT statements. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| According to Amazon, query performance is near the level you would see for a database on a LAN, as access through a browser. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Although a SimpleDB database is replicated and therefore made highly available and fault tolerant, the service lacks many of the speed enhancements available to relational systems. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A data domain may be located geographically in any of regions. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The design goal was to remove as much of the database system maintenance as possible. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In a Web services architecture, many applications require the performance level of a relational database. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Among the featured uses of SimpleDB are data logging, online gaming, and metadata indexing. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| SimpleDB would not be the best choice for a high-volume transaction system. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Data transfers within regions between SimpleDB and other AWS services are free. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Service charges accrue based on SimpleDB Machine Hours and inter-regional data transfers. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Chapter |NUMBER|: Using Amazon Web Services The three areas of use for SimpleDB that Amazon Web Services highlights logging |URL| online gaming |URL| and metadata indexing |URL| Amazon Relational Database Service (RDS) Amazon Relational Database Service is a variant of the |URL| database system, but one that is somewhat simplified. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The purpose of RDS is to allow database applications that already exist to be ported to RDS and placed in an environment that is relatively automated and easy to use. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| RDS automatically performs functions such as backups and is deployable throughout AWS zones using the AWS infrastructure. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In RDS, you start by launching a database instance in the AWS Management Console and assigning the DB Instance class and size of the data store. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The DB Instance is then connected to your MySQL database. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Any database tool that works with MySQL |URL| will work with RDS. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Additionally, you can monitor your database usage as part of Amazon CloudWatch. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Table |URL| shows the different Instance Classes for an Amazon RDS database. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Pricing is based on machine hour rates by class, by amount of storage per month, and per million requests. |ENDSENT|

|STARTSENT| Part Using Platforms Among the important features of RDS is the automated backup system for data in the database as well as for the MySQL transaction logs. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Backups can be saved for up to eight days. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In addition to backup, RDS supports database snapshots. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A DB Snapshot is stored as a full database backup and is retained until you specifically delete it from your storage container. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Snapshots may be scheduled or may be manually initiated by an administrator. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The deployment of RDS databases can be spread among multiple availability zones for increased fault tolerance and data availability. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| These so-called “Multi-AZ Deployments” can be automatically replicated and maintain a standby replica in another availability zone, with automatic failover when a database disruption is detected. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The conversion of a single location RDS database to a Multi-DB deployment may be accomplished with a single API call. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Other API calls support instance creation and maintenance, snapshots, and restores. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Choosing a database for AWS In choosing a database solution for your AWS solutions, consider the following factors in making your Choose SimpleDB when index and query functions do not require relational database support. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Use SimpleDB for the lowest administrative overhead. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Select SimpleDB if you want a solution that autoscales on demand. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Choose SimpleDB for a solution that has a very high availability. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Use RDS when you have an existing MySQL database that could be ported and you want to minimize the amount of infrastructure and administrative management required. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Use RDS when your database queries require relation between data objects. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Chose RDS when you want a database that scales based on an API call and has a pricing model. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Select Amazon Database AMI when you want access to an enterprise relational database or have an existing investment in that particular application. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Use Amazon Database AMI to retain complete administrative control over your database server. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Summary In this chapter, Amazon Web Services (AWS) were described. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| AWS is the most successful example of a Service Oriented Architecture (SOA) that provides an Infrastructure as a Service (IaaS) cloud computing solution. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| With AWS, you can create virtual private servers using the Elastic Cloud Compute service, dynamically size your servers and distribute them throughout the world, and create an application infrastructure that allows for very sophisticated and scalable applications. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Chapter |NUMBER|: Using Amazon Web Services The process for creating an Amazon Machine Instance (AMI) was described, as was the provisioning of various resources such as storage and databases for those instances. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The range of services that AWS supports is wide and includes Content Delivery Networks (CDNs), messaging and notification systems, load balancing and replication, and many other services as well. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| AWS is among the most important developer platforms for building cloud computing applications, and the range of services and their point of development was described here. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Chapter |NUMBER| “Using Microsoft Web Services,” describes the range of developer and user tools based in large part on Microsoft proprietary technologies such as Framework, |URL| and the Azure platform. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| cloud computing effort is considerable and falls midway between the approach taken by Google, which delivers applications that impact users, and |URL| which delivers services that provide cloud computing infrastructure. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In short, Amazon Web Services provide something for everyone. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| IN THIS CHAPTER Understanding developing cloud computing strategy Learning about the Windows Azure hosting service Exploring application development using the Windows Azure Platform Viewing the applications and services that are part of Windows Live Using Microsoft Cloud Services Microsoft has a very extensive cloud computing portfolio under active development. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Efforts to extend Microsoft products and third-party applications into the cloud are centered around adding more capabilities to existing Microsoft tools. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| approach is to view cloud applications as software plus service. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In this model, the cloud is another platform and applications can run locally and access cloud services or run entirely in the cloud and be accessed by browsers using standard Service Oriented Architecture (SOA) protocols. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Microsoft calls their cloud operating system the Windows Azure Platform. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| You can think of Azure as a combination of virtualized infrastructure to which the Framework has been added as a set of Services. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The Windows Azure service itself is a hosted environment of virtual machines enabled by a fabric called Windows Azure AppFabric. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| You can host your application on Azure and provision it with storage, growing it as you need it. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Windows Azure service is an Infrastructure as a Service offering. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A number of services interoperate with Windows Azure, including SQL Azure (a version of SQL Server), SharePoint Services, Azure Dynamic CRM, and many of Windows Live Services comprising what is the Windows Azure Platform, which is a Platform as a Service cloud computing model. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Eventually, many more services will be added, encompassing the whole range of offerings. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This architecture positions Microsoft to either extend its product into the Web or to license its products, whichever way the cloud computing marketplace develops. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| From position and that of its developers, Windows Azure has lots of advantages. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Windows Live Services is a collection of applications and services that run on the Web. |ENDSENT|

|STARTSENT| Exploring Microsoft Cloud Services Microsoft CEO Steve Balmer recently said at a University of Washington speech that Microsoft was “betting our company” on the cloud. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Balmer also claimed that about |NUMBER| percent of Microsoft employees were currently working on cloud-related projects and that the number was expected to rise to about |NUMBER| percent within a year. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Plans to integrate cloud-based applications and services into the Microsoft product portfolio dominates the thinking at Microsoft and is playing a central role in the ongoing product development. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The starting place for cloud computing efforts may be found at |URL| shown in Figure |URL| Microsoft has a vast array of cloud computing products and initiatives, and a number of industryleading Web applications. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Although services like America Online Instant Messenger (AIM) may garner mindshare in the United States, surprisingly Microsoft Messenger is the market leader in many other countries. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Product by product in any category you can event managers, photo galleries, image editors, movie making, and so has a Web application for it. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Some of these products are also-rans, some are good, some are category leaders, and a few of them are really unique. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| What is also true is that Web apps are under very active development. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Microsoft sees its on-line application portfolio as a way of extending its desktop applications to make the company pervasive and to extend its lives well into the future. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Going forward, Microsoft sees its future as providing the best Web experience for any type of device, which means that it structures its development environment so the application alters its behavior depending upon the device. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| For a mobile device, that would mean adjusting the user interface to accommodate the small screen, while for a PC the Web application would take advantage of the PC hardware to accelerate the application and add richer graphics and other features. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| That means Microsoft is pushing cloud development in terms of applications serving as both a service and an application. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This light, both a particle and a itself in the way Microsoft is currently structuring its Windows Live Web products. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Eventually, the company intends to create a Microsoft app store to sell cloud applications to users. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Microsoft Live is only one part of the Microsoft cloud strategy. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The second part of the strategy is the extension of the Framework and related development tools to the cloud. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| To enable developers to extend their applications into the cloud, or to build style applications that run completely in the cloud, Microsoft has created a set of services, which it now refers to as the Windows Azure Platform. |ENDSENT|

|STARTSENT| Part Using Platforms The software plus services approach Microsoft has a very different vision for cloud services than either Amazon or Google does. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In case, AWS is a pure infrastructure play. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| AWS essentially rents you a (virtual) computer on which to run your application. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| An Amazon Machine Image can be provisioned with an operating system, an enterprise application, or application stack, but that provisioning is not a prerequisite. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| An AMI is your machine, and you can configure it as you choose. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| AWS is a deployment enabler. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| approach with its Google App Engine (GAE) is to offer a cloud-based development platform on which you can add your program, provided that the program speaks the Google App Engine API and uses objects and properties from the App Engine framework. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Google makes it possible to program in a number of languages, but you must write your applications to conform to infrastructure. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Google Apps lets you create a saleable cloud-based application, but that application can only work within the Google infrastructure, and the application is not easily ported to other environments. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Microsoft sees the cloud as being a complimentary platform to its other platforms. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The company envisages a scenario where a Microsoft developer with an investment in an application wants to extend that availability to the cloud. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Perhaps the application runs on a server, desktop, or mobile device running some form of Windows. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Microsoft calls this approach software plus services. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The Windows Azure Platform allows a developer to modify his application so it can run in the cloud on virtual machines hosted in Microsoft datacenters. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Windows Azure serves as a cloud operating system, and the suitably modified application can be hosted on Azure as a runtime application where it can make use of the various Azure Services. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Additionally, local applications running on a server, desktop, or mobile device can access Windows Azure Services through the Windows Services Platform API. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Given that Microsoft owns the Office application market as well as the desktop OS market, this approach makes lots of sense. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| It is also quite possible that a hybrid application that can reside either locally or in the cloud will have lots of appeal not only to developers but to users who would prefer more control over their data and more security than the cloud might offer. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The Azure Platform With architecture (shown in Figure |URL| an application can run locally, run in the cloud, or some combination of both. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Applications on Azure can be run as applications, as background processes or services, or as both. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The Windows Azure service itself is shown as the oval in Figure |URL| and is a cloud-based operating system with a fabric infrastructure of virtual machines hosted in Microsoft datacenters. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The Azure Windows Services Platform API uses the industry standard REST, HTTP, and XML protocols that are part of any Service Oriented Architecture cloud infrastructure to allow applications to talk to Azure. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Developers can install a client-side managed class library that contains functions that can make calls to the Azure Windows Services Platform API as part of their applications. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| These Chapter |NUMBER|: Using Microsoft Cloud Services API functions have been added to Microsoft Visual Studio as part of Integrated Development Environment (IDE). |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| There are plans to add IPsec connectivity to Azure in the near future. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| IPsec refers to the Internet Protocol Security protocol suite for creating a secure Internet connection between two endpoints. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| IPsec provides for authenticated communication using sessionbased negotiation and the exchange of cryptographic keys to enable encrypted communication to be sent and decrypted. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| IPsec is an IETF standard that is in wide use. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The Azure Service Platform hosts runtime versions of Framework applications written in any of the languages in common use, such as Visual Basic, C#, Java, and any application that has been compiled for Common Language Runtime (CLR). |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Azure also can deploy Web-based applications built with |URL| the Windows Communication Foundation (WCF), and PHP, and it supports automated deployment technologies. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Microsoft also has released SDKs for both Java and Ruby to allow applications written in those languages to place calls to the Azure Service Platform API to the AppFabric Service. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The Windows Azure service Windows Azure is a virtualized Windows infrastructure run by Microsoft on a set of datacenters around the world. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In Figure |URL| the dashed oval encloses the portion of the Windows Azure Platform that is Azure is, the portion of the platform that is the IaaS part, which is shown in more detail in Figure |URL| Six main elements are part of Windows Application: This is the runtime of the application that is running in the cloud. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Compute: This is the load-balanced Windows server computation and policy engine that allows you to create and manage virtual machines that serve either in a Web role and a Worker role. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A Web role is a virtual machine instance running Microsoft IIS Web server that can accept and respond to HTTP or HTTPS requests. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A Worker role can accept and respond to requests, but run IIS in that virtual machine. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Worker roles can communicate with Azure Storage or through direct connections to clients. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Storage: This is a non-relational storage system for large-scale storage. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Azure Storage Service lets you create drives, manage queues, and store BLOBs (Binary Large Objects). |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| You manipulate content in Azure Storage using the REST API, which is based on standard HTTP requests and is therefore platform-independent. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Stored data can be read using GETs, written with PUTs, modified with POSTs, and removed with DELETE requests. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Azure Storage plays the same role in Azure that Amazon Simple Storage Service plays in Amazon Web Services. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| For relational database services, SQL Azure may be used. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Fabric: This is the Windows Azure Hypervisor, which is a version of Hyper-V that runs on Windows Server |NUMBER|. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Config: This is a management service. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Virtual These are instances of Windows that run the applications and services that are part of a particular deployment. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Part Using Platforms FIGURE |URL| The Windows Azure Platform extends applications running on other platforms to the cloud using Microsoft infrastructure and a set of enterprise services. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| AppFabric SQL Azure SharePoint Services Application Windows Azure Windows Services Platform API Dynamic CRM Services Live Services Application Servers Desktops Mobile Others Platforms Chapter |NUMBER|: Using Microsoft Cloud Services FIGURE |URL| Windows Azure is a virtualized infrastructure that provides configurable virtual machines, independent storage, and a configuration interface. |ENDSENT|

|STARTSENT| Part Using Platforms The portion of the Azure environment that creates and manages a virtual resource pool is called the Fabric Controller. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Applications that run on Azure are memory-managed, load-balanced, replicated, and backed up through snapshots automatically by the Fabric Controller. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Windows Azure AppFabric aspx) is a Service Bus and Access Control facility based on technology for client requests to Web services on Azure. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Previously, these services were called Microsoft Services. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Azure AppFabric supports the standard Service Oriented Architecture (SOA) protocols such as REST and SOAP and the WSprotocols. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The function of a service bus in an SOA is to expose distributed services as an endpoint with a specific URI that clients can request services from, as shown in Figure |URL| A particular set of endpoints and its associated Access Control rules for an application is referred to as the service namespace. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Each namespace is assigned a management key that is part of the security mechanism. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The Service Bus service registry makes endpoints discoverable, if so configured. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Azure AppFabric manages requests by locating the service, communicating the request, and making the necessary connection possible by performing network address translation, opening appropriate ports in any intervening firewalls. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| AppFabric manages the transaction to ensure that it is completed and that a response is sent to the client. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A service bus also can serve to negotiate the exchange of information between a client and the service. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Azure AppFabric acts as an SOA service bus, as shown in Figure |URL| AppFabric can provide a negotiated traversal of services through firewalls and NATs as a relay service using the Service rendezvous address. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A rendezvous address not only includes the service URI, but also includes the namespace of the service bus. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Alternatively, if both applications comply to Services a direct connection between the applications can be used instead with the required NAT traversal information for the direct connection provided by the relay service of the Service Bus. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| NAT (Network Address Traversal) is a system for creating and maintaining Internet connections for TCP or UDP traffic where the connection point is hidden behind a router or a firewall and routing is performed by one of several possible mechanisms. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Cross-Ref In Chapter |NUMBER| “Understanding Service Oriented Architecture,” the role of a service bus in a Service Oriented Architecture is more fully explored. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| n The Access Control portion of Azure AppFabric is a claims access control system that provides a token-based trust mechanism for identity management. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| An application or user, as shown on the right of Figure |URL| presents a claim for a service from an application on the left. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The Access Control examines the request, and if it finds it to be valid, it grants a security token to the client. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Chapter |NUMBER|: Using Microsoft Cloud Services FIGURE |URL| Azure AppFabric service pathways Windows Azure Windows Azure Windows Azure Platform Platform Platform Azure AppFabric Service Bus Firewall |NUMBER| Firewall |NUMBER| Negotiated Negotiated Negotiated Data Transfer Data Transfer Data Transfer Service Direct Connection Service Direct Connection Service Direct Connection Application |NUMBER| Application |NUMBER| These steps are associated with Access |NUMBER|. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The client requests authentication from Access Control. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Access Control creates a token based on the stored rules for server application. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A token is signed and returned to the client application. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The client presents the token to the service application. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The server application verifies the signature and uses the token to decide what the client application is allowed to do. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Access Control allows one application to trust the identity of another application. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This mechanism can federate with identity providers such as Active Directory Federation Services (ADFS to create distributed systems based on SOA. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Note “AppFabric” is also used by Microsoft for the name of its local server deployment technology called Windows Windows Server AppFabric enables Web data caching for application data and provides managed services using WindowsWorkflow Foundation and the Windows Communication Foundation. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| There are plans to integrate Windows Server AppFabric into the Azure platform AppFabic. |ENDSENT|

|STARTSENT| Security Token Granted Client User Microsoft likes to refer to the Azure AppFabric as an “Internet Service Bus” to differentiate it from the standard Enterprise Service Bus (ESB) that you find in SOA architectures. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| AppFabric has all the same components of an ESB, namely service orchestration, federated identity, access control, a namespace, service registry, and a messaging fabric, but it locates these components in the cloud. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Often ESBs are located on LANs. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| According to Microsoft, this approach abstracts away from application developers the challenges related to NAT traversal, DDNS (Dynamic DNS), and UPnP. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| ESBs are described in Chapter |NUMBER|; please refer to that chapter for further discussion on this topic. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Azure Content Delivery Network The Windows Azure Content Delivery Network (CDN) is a worldwide content caching and delivery system for Windows Azure blob content. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Currently, more than |NUMBER| Microsoft datacenters are hosting this service in Australia, Asia, Europe, South America, and the United States, referred to as endpoints. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| CDN is an edge network service that lowers latency and maximizes bandwidth by delivering content to users who are nearby. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Any storage account can be enabled for CDN. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In order to share information stored in an Azure blob, you need to place the blob in a public blob container that is accessible to anyone using an anonymous sign-in. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The Azure portal lists the domain name of the blob container in the form You also can register a custom domain name for a Windows Azure CDN endpoint. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| For content in a public container named “Box” in the storage account named “MyAccount,” a user would access the content with one of the following Windows Azure Blob services http://<MyAccount>.|URL| Windows Azure CDN http://<guid>.|URL| Chapter |NUMBER|: Using Microsoft Cloud Services When the Blob service URL is used, the request is redirected to the closest CDN endpoint to the client. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The CDN service searches that location and serves the content; if the content found, the CDN retrieves the Blob from the Blob service, caches the content, and then serves it to the user. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Parameters can be set that determine how long content is cached TTL), with the default being |NUMBER| hours. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| SQL Azure SQL Azure is a cloud-based relational database service that is based on Microsoft SQL Server. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Initially, this service was called SQL Server Data Service. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| An application that uses SQL Azure Database can run locally on a server, PC, or mobile device, in a datacenter, or on Windows Azure. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Data stored in an SQL Azure database is accessed using the Tabular Data Stream (TDS) protocol, the same protocol used for a local SQL Server database. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| SQL Azure Database supports TransactSQL statements. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Azure data is replicated three times for data protection and writes are checked for consistency. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| SQL Azure eventually will support the Microsoft Sync Framework providing a facility for SQL Azure Databases to synchronize their data with local databases. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| There is a current limit of for each SQL Azure Database. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Queries against a single database are unified. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| However, if the storage size exceeds the limit, then data must be partitioned into logical sets and queries need to be structured to account for this partitioning. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| For example, names in a database might have to be partitioned A-K, L-R, and S-Z. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| SQL Azure Database is a shared database environment, and limitations are placed on how long a query can run or how many resources a query can use. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Note Microsoft hopes to create a cloud-based global data marketplace using SQL Azure for stored information, a project that it has codenamed “Dallas.” Applications will then be able to access both private and public domain data such as imagery, census data, statistical data, and other premium content using REST protocols. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| You can read about plans for Dallas at |URL| From the standpoint of any application, an SQL Azure Database looks like and behaves like a local database with a few exceptions. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The current exceptions are that the SQL Common Language Runtime (CLR) and support for spatial data were not included, although support will be added later for them. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The biggest difference is that because SQL Azure is managed in the cloud, there are no administrative controls over the SQL engine. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| You shut the system down, nor can you directly interact with the SQL Servers. |ENDSENT|

|STARTSENT| Summary In this chapter, I described Microsoft cloud computing strategy. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Microsoft seeks to extend its products into the cloud using a software plus service approach. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In this model, the cloud is yet another platform, and applications can run locally and access cloud services, run in the cloud and be made available through SOA standard protocols, or some combination of both. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| cloud operating system is called Windows Azure. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Windows Azure is a hosted environment of virtualized systems tied together in a fabric using a service called AppFabric. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This is offered to developers in the form of an Infrastructure as a Service model similar to Amazon Web Services. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| To Windows Azure is added a cloud-enabled version of the Framework originally called Services, which are now part of Azure AppFabric. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This approach lets developers extend their applications into the cloud using development tools that they already possess with the minimum amount of reconfiguration. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Microsoft has added a number of additional services and the entire offering is now a Platform as a Service cloud model that Microsoft calls the Windows Azure Platform. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The other major component of cloud computing strategy is a collection of user applications and related services called Windows Live. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Some Windows Live applications are client-side applications, many others are Web-based applications, some are mobile apps, and an important subset of these services is available to developers through the Windows Live Messenger Connect APIs. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The various offering in Windows Live were discussed in this chapter. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In Chapter |NUMBER| “Managing the Cloud,” you learn about some of the management tools used to work with cloud applications and methods used for application deployment. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Part III Exploring Cloud Infrastructures IN THIS PART Chapter |NUMBER| Managing the Cloud Chapter |NUMBER| Understanding Cloud Security IN THIS CHAPTER Learning about network management software Viewing the essential monitoring features Using lifecycle management techniques Discovering emerging network management interoperability standards Managing the Cloud Cloud computing deployments must be monitored and managed in order to be optimized for best performance. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| To the problems associated with analyzing distributed network applications, the cloud adds the complexity of virtual infrastructure. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This is one of the most active areas of product development in the entire cloud computing industry, and this chapter introduces you to the different products in this nascent area. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Cloud management software provides capabilities for managing faults, configuration, accounting, performance, and security; this is referred to as FCAPS. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Many products address one or more of these areas, and through network frameworks, you can access all five areas. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Framework products are being repositioned to work with cloud systems. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Your management responsibilities depend on the particular service model for your cloud deployment. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Cloud management includes not only managing resources in the cloud, but managing resources on-premises. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The management of resources in the cloud requires new technology, but management of resources on-premises allows vendors to use well-established network management technologies. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The lifecycle of a cloud application includes six defined parts, and each must be managed. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In this chapter, the tasks associated with each stage are described. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Efforts are underway to develop cloud management interoperability standards. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| One effort you learn about in this chapter is the (Distributed Management Task Force) Open Cloud Standards Incubator. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The goal of these efforts is to develop management tools that work with any cloud type. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Another group called the Cloud Commons is developing a technology called the Service Measurement Index (SMI). |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| SMI aims to deploy methods for measuring various aspects of cloud performance in a standard way. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Part Exploring Cloud Infrastructures Administrating the Clouds The explosive growth in cloud computing services has led many vendors to rename their products and reposition them to get in on the gold rush in the clouds. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| What was once a network management product is now a cloud management product. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Nevertheless, this is one area of technology that is very actively funded, comes replete with interesting startups, has been the focus of several recent strategic acquisitions, and has resulted in some interesting product alliances. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| join the party and see what all the fuss is about. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| These fundamental features are offered by traditional network management Administration of resources Configuring resources Enforcing security Monitoring operations Optimizing performance Policy management Performing maintenance Provisioning of resources Network management systems are often described in terms of the acronym FCAPS, which stands for these Fault Configuration Accounting Performance Security Most network management packages have one or more of these characteristics; no single package provides all five elements of FCAPS. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| To get the complete set of all five of these management areas from a single vendor, you would need to adopt a network management framework. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| These large network management frameworks were industry leaders several years BMC PATROL, CA Unicenter, IBM Tivoli, HP OpenView, and Microsoft System Center. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Network framework products have been sliced and diced in many different ways over the years, and they are rebranded from time to time. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Today, for example, BMC PATROL is now part of BMC ProactiveNet Performance Management (|URL| HP Chapter |NUMBER|: Managing the Cloud The impact that cloud computing is having on network frameworks is profound. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| These five vendors have (or soon will have) products for cloud management. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Computer Associates, for example, has completely repositioned its network management portfolio as an IT Management Software as a Service. |ENDSENT|

|STARTSENT| The management service is ubiquitous. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Communication between the cloud and other systems uses cloud networking standards. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| To monitor an entire cloud computing deployment stack, you monitor six different |NUMBER|. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| End-user services such as HTTP, TCP, and others |NUMBER|. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Browser performance on the client |NUMBER|. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Application monitoring in the cloud, such as Apache, MySQL, and so on |NUMBER|. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Cloud infrastructure monitoring of services such as Amazon Web Services, GoGrid, Rackspace, and others |NUMBER|. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Machine instance monitoring where the service measures processor utilization, memory usage, disk consumption, queue lengths, and other important parameters |NUMBER|. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Network monitoring and discovery using standard protocols like the Simple Network Management Protocol (SNMP), Configuration Management Database (CMDB), Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI), and the like important to note that there are really two aspects to cloud Managing resources in the cloud Using the cloud to manage resources on-premises When you move to a cloud computing architecture from a traditional networked model like server or a three-tier architecture, many of the old management tasks for processes going on in the cloud become irrelevant or nearly impossible to manage because the tools to effectively manage resources of various kinds fall outside of your own purview. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In the cloud, the particular service model you are using directly affects the type of monitoring you are responsible for. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Consider the case of an Infrastructure as a Service vendor such as Amazon Web Services or Rackspace. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| You can monitor your usage of resources either through their native monitoring tools like Amazon CloudWatch or Rackspace Control Panel or through the numerous third-party tools that work with these APIs. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In IaaS, you can alter aspects of your deployment, such as the number of machine instances you are running or the amount of storage you have, but you have very limited control over many important aspects of the operation. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| For example, your network bandwidth is locked into the type of instance you deploy. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Even if you can provision more bandwidth, you likely have no control over how network traffic flows into and out of the system, whether there is packet prioritization, how routing is done, and other important characteristics. |ENDSENT|

|STARTSENT| Chapter |NUMBER|: Managing the Cloud Lifecycle management Cloud services have a defined lifecycle, just like any other system deployment. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A management program has to touch on each of the six different stages in that |NUMBER|. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The definition of the service as a template for creating instances Tasks performed in Phase |NUMBER| include the creation, updating, and deletion of service templates. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Client interactions with the service, usually through an SLA (Service Level Agreement) contract This phase manages client relationships and creates and manages service contracts. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The deployment of an instance to the cloud and the runtime management of instances Tasks performed in Phase |NUMBER| include the creation, updating, and deletion of service offerings. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The definition of the attributes of the service while in operation and performance of modifications of its properties The chief task during this management phase is to perform service optimization and customization. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Management of the operation of instances and routine maintenance During Phase |NUMBER| you must monitor resources, track and respond to events, and perform reporting and billing functions. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Retirement of the service End of life tasks include data protection and system migration, archiving, and service contract termination. |ENDSENT|

|STARTSENT| Emerging Cloud Management Standards As it stands now, different cloud service providers use different technologies for creating and managing cloud resources. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| As the area matures, cloud providers are going to be under considerable Chapter |NUMBER|: Managing the Cloud pressure from large cloud users like the federal government to conform to standards and make their systems interoperable with one another. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| No entity is likely to want to make a major investment in a service that is a silo or from which data is difficult to stage or to extract. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| To this end, a number of large industry players such as VMware, IBM, Microsoft, Citrix, and HP have gotten together to create standards that can be used to promote cloud interoperability. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In the section that follows, you learn about the work of the DMTF in this area. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Another effort just getting underway has been started by CA (the company formerly known as Computer Associates) in association with Carnegie Mellon called the Cloud Commons. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This effort is aimed at creating an industry community and working group, and promoting a set of monitoring standards that were part of cloud technology portfolio but are now open sourced. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| DMTF cloud management standards The Distributed Management Task Force (DMTF; see |URL| is an industry organization that develops industry system management standards for platform interoperability. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Its membership is a who” in computing, and since its founding in |NUMBER| the group has been responsible for several industry standards, most notably the Common Information Model (CIM). |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The DMTF organizes itself into a set of working groups that are tasked with specifying standards for different areas of technology. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A recent standard called the Virtualization Management Initiative (VMAN) was developed to extend CIM to virtual computer system management. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| VMAN has resulted in the creation of the Open Virtualization Format (OVF), which describes a standard method for creating, packaging, and provisioning virtual appliances. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| OVF is essentially a container and a file format that is open and both hypervisorand Since OVF was announced in |NUMBER| vendors such as VirtualBox, AbiCloud, IBM, Red Hat, and VMWare have announced or introduced products that use OVF. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| It was, therefore, a natural extension of the work that DMTF does in virtualization to solve management issues in cloud computing. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| DMTF has created a working group called the Open Cloud Standards Incubator (OCSI) to help develop interoperability standards for managing interactions between and in public, private, and hybrid cloud systems. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The group is focused on describing resource management and security protocols, packaging methods, and network management technologies. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The Web site of the Cloud Management group (|URL| cloud) is shown in Figure |URL| cloud management efforts are really in their initial stages, but the group has broad industry support. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Part of the task is to provide industry education, so you can find a number of white papers and technology briefs published on this site. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| an effort worth checking back with over time. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Although the work has not yet been joined by Amazon or |URL| a set of open standards that extend the use of industry standard as the Common Information Model (CIM), the Open Virtualization Format (OVF), and the cloud are going to be hard for vendors to resist. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Part Exploring Cloud Infrastructures FIGURE |URL| DMTF (|URL| has a large and important effort underway for developing cloud interoperability management standards. |ENDSENT|

|STARTSENT| Summary Cloud management is an important and growing area of technology. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In this chapter, you learned about some of the products being offered or developed to address common management problems. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Among the management tasks are deployment, monitoring, configuration, optimization, and often security. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Nearly all network management software vendors are repositioning their products to work with cloud systems. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Some network management is available from within the cloud service platforms. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Many of the software systems utilize the service API to manage, monitor, and control resources. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The use of virtualization has spawned many new products in this area. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In Chapter |NUMBER| you learn about security used in cloud computing. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This is an extension of our discussion on network management, because security is another means of controlling access through network policies. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Understanding Cloud Security IN THIS CHAPTER Reviewing cloud security concerns Understanding how cloud data can be secured Planning for security in your system Learning how identity is used to allow secure cloud access Cloud computing has lots of unique properties that make it very valuable. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Unfortunately, many of those properties make security a singular concern. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Many of the tools and techniques that you would use to protect your data, comply with regulations, and maintain the integrity of your systems are complicated by the fact that you are sharing your systems with others and many times outsourcing their operations as well. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Cloud computing service providers are well aware of these concerns and have developed new technologies to address them. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Different types of cloud computing service models provide different levels of security services. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| You get the least amount of built in security with an Infrastructure as a Service provider, and the most with a Software as a Service provider. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This chapter presents the concept of a security boundary separating the and responsibilities. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Adapting your on-premises systems to a cloud model requires that you determine what security mechanisms are required and mapping those to controls that exist in your chosen cloud service provider. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| When you identify missing security elements in the cloud, you can use that mapping to work to close the gap. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Storing data in the cloud is of particular concern. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Data should be transferred and stored in an encrypted format. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| You can use proxy and brokerage services to separate clients from direct access to shared cloud storage. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Logging, auditing, and regulatory compliance are all features that require planning in cloud computing systems. |ENDSENT|

|STARTSENT| Part Exploring Cloud Infrastructures Securing the Cloud The Internet was designed primarily to be resilient; it was not designed to be secure. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Any distributed application has a much greater attack surface than an application that is closely held on a Local Area Network. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Cloud computing has all the vulnerabilities associated with Internet applications, and additional vulnerabilities arise from pooled, virtualized, and outsourced resources. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In the report “Assessing the Security Risks of Cloud Computing,” Jay Heiser and Mark Nicolett of lighted the following areas of cloud computing that they felt were uniquely Auditing Data integrity e-Discovery for legal compliance Privacy Recovery Regulatory compliance Your risks in any cloud deployment are dependent upon the particular cloud service model chosen and the type of cloud on which you deploy your applications. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In order to evaluate your risks, you need to perform the following |NUMBER|. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Determine which resources (data, services, or applications) you are planning to move to the cloud. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Determine the sensitivity of the resource to risk. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Risks that need to be evaluated are loss of privacy, unauthorized access by others, loss of data, and interruptions in availability. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Determine the risk associated with the particular cloud type for a resource. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Cloud types include public, private (both external and internal), hybrid, and shared community types. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| With each type, you need to consider where data and functionality will be maintained. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Take into account the particular cloud service model that you will be using. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Different models such as IaaS, SaaS, and PaaS require their customers to be responsible for security at different levels of the service stack. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| If you have selected a particular cloud service provider, you need to evaluate its system to understand how data is transferred, where it is stored, and how to move data both in and out of the cloud. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| You may want to consider building a flowchart that shows the overall mechanism of the system you are intending to use or are currently using. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| One technique for maintaining security is to have “golden” system image references that you can return to when needed. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The ability to take a system image off-line and analyze the image for Chapter |NUMBER|: Understanding Cloud Security vulnerabilities or compromise is invaluable. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The compromised image is a primary forensics tool. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Many cloud providers offer a snapshot feature that can create a copy of the entire environment; this includes not only machine images, but applications and data, network interfaces, firewalls, and switch access. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| If you feel that a system has been compromised, you can replace that image with a known good version and contain the problem. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Many vendors maintain a security page where they list their various resources, certifications, and credentials. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| One of the more developed offerings is the AWS Security Center, shown in Figure |URL| where you can download some backgrounders, white papers, and case studies related to the Amazon Web security controls and mechanisms. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| FIGURE |URL| The AWS Security Center (|URL| is a good place to start learning about how Amazon Web Services protects users of its IaaS service. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The security boundary In order to concisely discuss security in cloud computing, you need to define the particular model of cloud computing that applies. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This nomenclature provides a framework for understanding what security is already built into the system, who has responsibility for a particular security mechanism, and where the boundary between the responsibility of the service provider is separate from the responsibility of the customer. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Part Exploring Cloud Infrastructures All of Chapter |NUMBER| was concerned with defining what cloud computing is and defining the lexicon of cloud computing. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| There are many definitions and acronyms in the area of cloud computing that will probably not survive long. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The most commonly used model based on |URL| National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST; |URL| deployment models from service models and assigns those models a set of service attributes. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Deployment models are cloud community, hybrid, private, and public clouds. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Service models follow the SPI Model for three forms of service Software, Platform, and Infrastructure as a Service. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In the NIST model, as you may recall, it was not required that a cloud use virtualization to pool resources, nor did that model require that a cloud support multi-tenancy. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| It is just these factors that make security such a complicated proposition in cloud computing. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Chapter |NUMBER| also presented the Cloud Security Alliance (CSA; |URL| |URL| cloud computing stack model, which shows how different functional units in a network stack relate to one another. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| As you may recall from Chapter |NUMBER| this model can be used to separate the different service models from one another. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| CSA is an industry working group that studies security issues in cloud computing and offers recommendations to its members. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The work of the group is open and available, and you can download its guidance from its home page, shown in Figure |URL| FIGURE |URL| The Cloud Security Alliance (CSA) home page at |URL| offers a number of resources to anyone concerned with securing his cloud deployment. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Chapter |NUMBER|: Understanding Cloud Security The CSA partitions its guidance into a set of operational Governance and enterprise risk management Legal and electronic discovery Compliance and audit Information lifecycle management Portability and interoperability Traditional security, business continuity, and disaster recovery Datacenter operations Incidence response, notification, and remediation Application security Encryption and key management Identity and access management Virtualization You can download the current work in these areas from the different sections of its Web site. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| One key difference between the NIST model and the CSA is that the CSA considers multi-tenancy to be an essential element in cloud computing. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Multi-tenancy adds a number of additional security concerns to cloud computing that need to be accounted for. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In multi-tenancy, different customers must be isolated, their data segmented, and their service accounted for. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| To provide these features, the cloud service provider must provide a policy-based environment that is capable of supporting different levels and quality of service, usually using different pricing models. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Multi-tenancy expresses itself in different ways in the different cloud deployment models and imposes security concerns in different places. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Security service boundary The CSA functional cloud computing stack is the Cloud Reference Model. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This model, which was discussed in Chapter |NUMBER| is reproduced in Figure |URL| IaaS is the lowest level service, with PaaS and SaaS the next two services above. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| As you move upward in the stack, each service model inherits the capabilities of the model beneath it, as well as all the inherent security concerns and risk factors. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| IaaS supplies the infrastructure; PaaS adds application development frameworks, transactions, and control structures; and SaaS is an operating environment with applications, management, and the user interface. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| As you ascend the stack, IaaS has the least levels of integrated functionality and the lowest levels of integrated security, and SaaS has the most. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The most important lesson from this discussion of architecture is that each different type of cloud service delivery model creates a security boundary at which the cloud service responsibilities end and the responsibilities begin. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Any security mechanism below the security boundary must be built into the system, and any security mechanism above must be maintained by the customer. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| As you move up the stack, it becomes more important to make sure that the type and level of security is part of your Service Level Agreement. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Part Exploring Cloud Infrastructures FIGURE |URL| The CSA Cloud Reference Model with security boundaries shown Presentation Mobility Presentation Platform APIs Applications Data Metadata Content Integration Middleware SaaS Security Boundary SaaS Security Boundary SaaS Security Boundary PaaS Security Boundary PaaS Security Boundary PaaS Security Boundary SaaSSaaS SaaS APIs IaaS Security Boundary IaaS Security Boundary IaaS Security Boundary SaaSSaaS SaaS Core Connectivity Delivery PaaSPaaS PaaS IaaSIaaS IaaS Abstraction PaaSPaaS PaaS IaaSIaaS IaaS Hardware Facilities In the SaaS model, the vendor provides security as part of the Service Level Agreement, with the compliance, governance, and liability levels stipulated under the contract for the entire stack. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| For the PaaS model, the security boundary may be defined for the vendor to include the software framework and middleware layer. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In the PaaS model, the customer would be responsible for the security of the application and UI at the top of the stack. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The model with the least built-in security is IaaS, where everything that involves software of any kind is the problem. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Numerous definitions of services tend to muddy this picture by adding or removing elements of the various functions from any particular offering, thus blurring which party has responsibility for which features, but the overall analysis is still useful. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Chapter |NUMBER|: Understanding Cloud Security In thinking about the Cloud Security Reference Model in relationship to security needs, a fundamental distinction may be made between the nature of how services are provided versus where those services are located. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A private cloud may be internal or external to an organization, and although a public cloud is most often external, there is no requirement that this mapping be made so. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Cloud computing has a tendency to blur the location of the defined security perimeter in such a way that the previous notions of network firewalls and edge defenses often no longer apply. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This makes the location of trust boundaries in cloud computing rather ill defined, dynamic, and subject to change depending upon a number of factors. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Establishing trust boundaries and creating a new perimeter defense that is consistent with your cloud computing network is an important consideration. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The key to understanding where to place security mechanisms is to understand where physically in the cloud resources are deployed and consumed, what those resources are, who manages the resources, and what mechanisms are used to control them. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Those factors help you gauge where systems are located and what areas of compliance you need to build into your system. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Table |URL| lists some of the different service models and lists the parties responsible for security in the different instances. |ENDSENT|

|STARTSENT| To determine the particular security mechanisms you need, you must perform a mapping of the particular cloud service model to the particular application you are deploying. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| These mechanisms must be supported by the various controls that are provided by your service provider, your organization, or a third party. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| unlikely that you will be able to duplicate security routines that are possible on-premises, but this analysis allows you to determine what coverage you need. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Part Exploring Cloud Infrastructures A security control model includes the security that you normally use for your applications, data, management, network, and physical hardware. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| You may also need to account for any compliance standards that are required for your industry. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A compliance standard can be any government regulatory framework such as Payment Card Industry Data Security Standards (PCI-DSS), Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPPA), Act (GLBA), or the Act (SOX) that requires you operate in a certain way and keep records. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Essentially, you are looking to identify the missing features that would be required for an on-premises deployment and seek to find their replacements in the cloud computing model. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| As you assign accountability for different aspects of security and contract away the operational responsibility to others, you want to make sure they remain accountable for the security you need. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Securing Data Securing data sent to, received from, and stored in the cloud is the single largest security concern that most organizations should have with cloud computing. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| As with any WAN traffic, you must assume that any data can be intercepted and modified. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| why, as a matter of course, traffic to a cloud service provider and stored off-premises is encrypted. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This is as true for general data as it is for any passwords or account IDs. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| These are the key mechanisms for protecting data Access control Auditing Authentication Authorization Whatever service model you choose should have mechanisms operating in all four areas that meet your security requirements, whether they are operating through the cloud service provider or your own local infrastructure. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Brokered cloud storage access The problem with the data you store in the cloud is that it can be located anywhere in the cloud service system: in another datacenter, another state or province, and in many cases even in another country. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| With other types of system architectures, such as you could count on a firewall to serve as your security perimeter; cloud computing has no physical system that serves this purpose. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Therefore, to protect your cloud storage assets, you want to find a way to isolate data from direct client access. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Chapter |NUMBER|: Understanding Cloud Security One approach to isolating storage in the cloud from direct client access is to create layered access to the data. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In one scheme, two services are a broker with full access to storage but no access to the client, and a proxy with no access to storage but access to both the client and broker. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The location of the proxy and the broker is not important (they can be local or in the cloud); what is important is that these two services are in the direct data path between the client and data stored in the cloud. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Under this system, when a client makes a request for data, what |NUMBER|. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The request goes to the external service interface (or endpoint) of the proxy, which has only a partial trust. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The proxy, using its internal interface, forwards the request to the broker. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The broker requests the data from the cloud storage system. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The storage system returns the results to the broker. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The broker returns the results to the proxy. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The proxy completes the response by sending the data requested to the client. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Figure |URL| shows this storage “proxy” system graphically. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Note This discussion is based on a white paper called “Security Best Practices For Developing Windows Azure Applications,” by Andrew Marshall, Michael Howard, Grant Bugher, and Brian Harden that you can find at |URL| their presentation, the proxy service is called the Gatekeeper and assigned a Windows Server Web Role, and the broker is called the KeyMaster and assigned a Worker Role. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| n This design relies on the proxy service to impose some rules that allow it to safely request data that is appropriate to that particular client based on the identity and relay that request to the broker. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The broker does not need full access to the cloud storage, but it may be configured to grant READ and QUERY operations, while not allowing APPEND or DELETE. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The proxy has a limited trust role, while the broker can run with higher privileges or even as native code. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The use of multiple encryption keys can further separate the proxy service from the storage account. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| If you use two separate keys to create two different data for the untrusted communication between the proxy and broker services, and another a trusted zone between the broker and the cloud create a situation where there is further separation between the different service roles. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Part Exploring Cloud Infrastructures FIGURE |URL| In this design, direct access to cloud storage is eliminated in favor of a service. |ENDSENT|

|STARTSENT| Storage data reply Internet Cloud or Web Cloud Cloud Storage Even if the proxy service is compromised, that service does not have access to the trusted key necessary to access the cloud storage account. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In the multi-key solution, shown in Figure |URL| you have not only eliminated all internal service endpoints, but you also have eliminated the need to have the proxy service run at a reduced trust level. |ENDSENT|
