|STARTSENT| Storage data reply Cloud Storage Untrusted Storage Account, Key |NUMBER| Cloud or Web Cloud Trusted Storage Account, Key |NUMBER| Storage location and tenancy Some cloud service providers negotiate as part of their Service Level Agreements to contractually store and process data in locations that are predetermined by their contract. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Not all do. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| If you can Part Exploring Cloud Infrastructures get the commitment for specific data site storage, then you also should make sure the cloud vendor is under contract to conform to local privacy laws. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Because data stored in the cloud is usually stored from multiple tenants, each vendor has its own unique method for segregating one data from another. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| important to have some understanding of how your specific service provider maintains data segregation. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Another question to ask a cloud storage provider is who is provided privileged access to storage. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The more you know about how the vendor hires its IT staff and the security mechanism put into place to protect storage, the better. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Most cloud service providers store data in an encrypted form. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| While encryption is important and effective, it does present its own set of problems. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| When there is a problem with encrypted data, the result is that the data may not be recoverable. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| It is worth considering what type of encryption the cloud provider uses and to check that the system has been planned and tested by security experts. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Regardless of where your data is located, you should know what impact a disaster or interruption will have on your service and your data. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Any cloud provider that offer the ability to replicate data and application infrastructure across multiple sites cannot recover your information in a timely manner. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| You should know how disaster recovery affects your data and how long it takes to do a complete restoration. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Encryption Strong encryption technology is a core technology for protecting data in transit to and from the cloud as well as data stored in the cloud. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| It is or will be required by law. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The goal of encrypted cloud storage is to create a virtual private storage system that maintains confidentiality and data integrity while maintaining the benefits of cloud ubiquitous, reliable, shared data storage. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Encryption should separate stored data (data at rest) from data in transit. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Depending upon the particular cloud provider, you can create multiple accounts with different keys as you saw in the example with Windows Azure Platform in the previous section. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Microsoft allows up to five security accounts per client, and you can use these different accounts to create different zones. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| On Amazon Web Service, you can create multiple keys and rotate those keys during different sessions. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Although encryption protects your data from unauthorized access, it does nothing to prevent data loss. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Indeed, a common means for losing encrypted data is to lose the keys that provide access to the data. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Therefore, you need to approach key management seriously. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Keys should have a defined lifecycle. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Among the schemes used to protect keys are the creation of secure key stores that have restricted role-based access, automated key stores backup, and recovery techniques. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| a good idea to separate key management from the cloud provider that hosts your data. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| One standard for interoperable cloud-based key management is the OASIS Key Management Interoperability Protocol (KMIP; |URL| storage encryption and key management for shared storage. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Chapter |NUMBER|: Understanding Cloud Security Auditing and compliance Logging is the recording of events into a repository; auditing is the ability to monitor the events to understand performance. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Logging and auditing is an important function because it is not only necessary for evaluation performance, but it is also used to investigate security and when illegal activity has been perpetrated. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Logs should record system, application, and security events, at the very minimum. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Logging and auditing are unfortunately one of the weaker aspects of early cloud computing service offerings. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Cloud service providers often have proprietary log formats that you need to be aware of. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Whatever monitoring and analysis tools you use need to be aware of these logs and able to work with them. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Often, providers offer monitoring tools of their own, many in the form of a dashboard with the potential to customize the information you see through either the interface or programmatically using the API. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| You want to make full use of those built-in services. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Because cloud services are both multitenant and multisite operations, the logging activity and data for different clients may not only be co-located, they may also be moving across a landscape of different hosts and sites. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| You simply expect that an investigation will be provided with the necessary information at the time of discovery unless it is part of your Service Level Agreement. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Even an SLA with the appropriate obligations contained in it may not be enough to guarantee you will get the information you need when the time comes. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| It is wise to determine whether the cloud service provider has been able to successfully support investigations in the past. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| As it stands now, nearly all regulations were written without keeping cloud computing in mind. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A regulator or auditor likely to be familiar with the nature of running applications and storing data in the cloud. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Even so, laws are written to ensure compliance, and the client is held responsible for compliance under the laws of the governing bodies that apply to the location where the processing or storage takes place. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Therefore, you must understand the Which regulations apply to your use of a particular cloud computing service Which regulations apply to the cloud service provider and where the demarcation line falls for responsibilities How your cloud service provider will support your need for information associated with regulation How to work with the regulator to provide the information necessary regardless of who had the responsibility to collect the data Traditional service providers are much more likely to be the subject of security certifications and external audits of their facilities and procedures than cloud service providers. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| That makes the willingness for a cloud service provider to subject its service to regulatory compliance scrutiny an important factor in your selection of that provider over another. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In the case of a cloud service provider who shows reluctance to or limits the scrutiny of its operations, it is probably wise to use the Part Exploring Cloud Infrastructures service in ways that limit your exposure to risk. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| For example, although encrypting stored data is always a good policy, you also might want to consider not storing any sensitive information on that system. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| As it stands now, clients must guarantee their own regulatory compliance, even when their data is in the care of the service provider. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| You must ensure that your data is secure and that its integrity has not been compromised. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| When multiple regulatory entities are involved, as there surely are between site locations and different countries, then that burden to satisfy the laws of those governments is also your responsibility. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| For any company with clients in multiple countries, the burden of regulatory compliance is onerous. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| While organizations such as the EEC (European Economic Community) or Common Market provide some relief for European regulation, countries such as the United States, Japan, China, and others each have their own sets of requirements. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This makes regulatory compliance one of the most actively developing and important areas of cloud computing technology. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This situation is likely to change. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| On |DATE|, Massachusetts passed a law that requires companies that provide sensitive personal information on Massachusetts residents to encrypt data transmitted and stored on their systems. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Businesses are required to limit the amount of personal data collected, monitor data usage, keep a data inventory, and be able to present a security plan on how they will keep the data safe. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The steps require that companies verify that any third-party services they use conform to these requirements and that there be language in all SLAs that enforce these protections. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The law takes full effect in |DATE|. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Going forward, you want to ensure the You have contracts reviewed by your legal staff. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| You have a clause in your SLA. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| You review any third parties who are service providers and assess their impact on security and regulatory compliance. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| You understand the scope of the regulations that apply to your cloud computing applications and services. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| You consider what steps you must take to comply with the demands of regulations that apply. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| You consider adjusting your procedures to comply with regulations. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| You collect and maintain the evidence of your compliance with regulations. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| You determine whether your cloud service provider can provide an audit statement that is SAS |NUMBER| Type II-compliant. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The |NUMBER|/|NUMBER| standard for information security management systems has a roadmap for mission-critical services that you may want to discuss with your cloud service provider. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Amazon Web Services supports Type II Audits. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Chapter |NUMBER|: Understanding Cloud Security Becoming a cloud service provider requires a large investment, but as we all know, even large companies can fail. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| When a cloud service provider fails, it may close or more likely be acquired by another company. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| You likely use a service provider that you suspected of being in difficulty, but problems develop over years and cloud computing has a certain degree of vendor lockin to it. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| That is, when you have created a cloud-based service, it can be difficult or often impossible to move it to another service provider. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| You should be aware of what happens to your data if the cloud service provider fails. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| At the very least, you would want to make sure your data could be obtained in a format that could be accessed by on-premise applications. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The various attributes of cloud computing make it difficult to respond to incidents, but that mean you should consider drawing up security incidence response policies. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Although cloud computing creates shared responsibilities, it is often up to the client to initiate the inquiry that gets the ball rolling. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| You should be prepared to provide clear information to your cloud service provider about what you consider to be an incident or a breach in security and what are simply suspicious events. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Establishing Identity and Presence Chapter |NUMBER| introduced the concept of identities, some of the protocols that support them, and some of the services that can work with them. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Identities also are tied to the concept of accounts and can be used for contacts or “ID cards.” Identities also are important from a security standpoint because they can be used to authenticate client requests for services in a distributed network system such as the Internet or, in this case, for cloud computing services. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Identity management is a primary mechanism for controlling access to data in the cloud, preventing unauthorized uses, maintaining user roles, and complying with regulations. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The sections that follow describe some of the different security aspects of identity and the related concept of “presence.” For this conversation, you can consider presence to be the mapping of an authenticated identity to a known location. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Presence is important in cloud computing because it adds context that can modify services and service delivery. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Cloud computing requires the That you establish an identity That the identity be authenticated That the authentication be portable That authentication provide access to cloud resources When applied to a number of users in a cloud computing system, these requirements describe systems that must provision identities, provide mechanisms that manage credentials and authentication, allow identities to be federated, and support a variety of user profiles and access policies. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Automating these processes can be a major management task, just as they are for on-premises operations. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Part Exploring Cloud Infrastructures Identity protocol standards The protocols that provide identity services have been and are under active development, and several form the basis for efforts to create interoperability among services. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| OpenID |URL| (|URL| is the standard associated with creating an identity and having a third-party service authenticate the use of that digital identity. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| It is the key to creating Single Sign-On (SSO) systems. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Some cloud service providers have adopted OpenID as a service, and its use is growing. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In Chapter |NUMBER| you learned how OpenID is associated with contact cards such as vCards and InfoCards. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In that chapter, I briefly discussed how OpenID provides access to important Web sites and how some Web sites allow you to use your logins based on OpenID from another site to gain access to their site. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| OpenID specify the means for authentication of an identity, and it is up to the particular system how the authentication process is executed. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Authentication can be by a Challenge and Response Protocol (CHAP), through a physical smart card, or using a flying finger or evil eye through a biometric measurement. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In OpenIDL, the authentication procedure has the following |NUMBER|. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The end-user uses a program like a browser that is called a user agent to enter an OpenID identifier, which is in the form of a URL or XRI. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| An OpenID might take the form of |URL| The OpenID is presented to a service that provides access to the resource that is desired. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| An entity called a relaying party queries the OpenID identity provider to authenticate the veracity of the OpenID credentials. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The authentication is sent back to the relaying party from the identity provider and access is either provided or denied. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| According to a report by one of directors called “OpenID |NUMBER| Year in Review” by Brian over |NUMBER| billion OpenID accounts accepted by |NUMBER| million sites on the Internet. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The second protocol used to present identity-based claims in cloud computing is a set of authorization markup languages that create files in the form of being XACML and SAML. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| These protocols were described in Chapter |NUMBER| in detail, so I only mention them in passing here. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| SAML (Security Assertion Markup Language; |URL| is gaining growing acceptance among cloud service providers. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| It is a standard of OASIS and an XML standard for passing authentication and authorization between an identity provider and the service provider. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| SAML is a complimentary mechanism to OpenID and is used to create SSO systems. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Chapter |NUMBER|: Understanding Cloud Security Taken as a unit, OpenID and SAML are being positioned to be the standard authentication mechanism for clients accessing cloud services. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| It is particularly important for services such as mashups that draw information from two or more data services. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| An open standard called OAuth (|URL| provides a token service that can be used to present validated access to resources. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| OAuth is similar to OpenID, but provides a different mechanism for shared access. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The use of OAuth tokens allows clients to present credentials that contain no account information (userID or password) to a cloud service. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The token comes with a defined period after which it can no longer be used. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Several important cloud service providers have begun to make OAuth APIs available based on the OAuth |URL| standard, most notably Graph API and the Google Data API. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The DataPortability Project (|URL| is an industry working group that promotes data interoperability between applications, and the work touches on a number of the emerging standards mentioned in this section. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The Web site is shown in Figure |URL| FIGURE |URL| The home page of the DataPortability Project, an industry working group that promotes open identity standards Part Exploring Cloud Infrastructures A number of vendors have created server products, such as Identity and Access Managers (IAMs), to support these various standards. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Windows Azure identity standards The Windows Azure Platform uses a claims-based identity based on open authentication and access protocols and is a good example of a service implementing the standards described in the previous section. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| These standards may be used without modification on a system that is running in the cloud or on-premises, in keeping with S+S (software plus services) approach to cloud computing. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Windows Azure security draws on the following three Active Directory Federation Services |URL| Windows Azure AppFabric Access Control Service Windows Identity Foundation (WIF) The Windows Identity Foundation offers developers Visual Studio integration of WS-Federation and WS-Trust open standards. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| |URL| Web applications created with WIF integrate the Windows Communication Foundation SOAP service (WCF-SOAP) into a unified object model. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This allows WIF to have full access to the features of WS-Security and to work with tokens in the SAML format. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| WIF relies on third-party authentication and accepts authentication requests from these services in the form of a set of claims. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Claims are independent of where a user account or application is located, thus allowing claims to be used in single sign-on systems (SSO). |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Claims support both simple resource access and the Role Based Access Control (RBAC) policies that can be enforced by Windows group policies. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Active Directory Federation Services |URL| (AD FS) is a Security Token Service (STS) that allows users to authenticate their access to applications both locally and in the cloud with a claims-based identity. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Anyone who has an account in the local Windows directory can access an application; AD FS creates and retains trust relationships with federated systems. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| AD FS uses WS-Federation, WS-Trust, and SAML, which allows users to access a system based on IBM, Novell, SAP, and many other vendors. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The final piece of the Windows Azure Platform claims-based identity system is built directly into the AppFabric Access Control (AC) service. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| You may recall from Chapter |NUMBER| that AppFabric is a service bus for Azure components that supports REST Web services. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Included in AppFabric are authentication and claims-based authorization access. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| These can be simple logons or more complex schemes supported by AD FS. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| AC allows authorization to be located anywhere and allows developers to separate identity from their application. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The claims-based identity in AC is based on the OAuth Web Resource Authorization Protocol (OAuth WRAP), which works with various REST APIs. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The Oauth |URL| protocol seems to be gaining acceptance in the cloud computing industry, because SAML tokens can be accepted by many vendors. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Chapter |NUMBER|: Understanding Cloud Security Presence Presence is a fundamental concept in computer science. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| It is used on networks to indicate the status of available parties and their location. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Commands like the WHO command in Linux that list users logged into the network go all the way back to the first network operating systems. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Presence provides not only identity, but status and, as part of status, location. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The status is referred to as the presence state, the identity is the presentity, and the service that manages presence is called the presence service. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Many presence services rely on agents called watchers, which are small programs that relay a ability to connect. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Among the cloud computing services that rely on presence information are telephony systems such as VoIP, instant messaging services (IM), and systems such as GPS. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Presence is playing an important role in cell phones, particularly smart phones. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| When you access an application such as AroundMe on the Apple iPhone, which lists businesses, services, and restaurants in your vicinity, you are using an example of a presence service. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Figure |URL| shows the AroundMe app with some sample results. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The presence service is provided by the GPS locator inside the phone, which provides a location through (the service provider) to the application. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Presence is an essential and growing component of cloud-based services, and it adds a tremendous amount of value to the ubiquity that a cloud network offers. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| FIGURE |URL| The AroundMe iPhone app is an example of an application that makes use of a presence service. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Part Exploring Cloud Infrastructures As cloud computing becomes more pervasive and vendors attempt to create federated systems, emerging presence services will become more important. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Windows Identity Foundation (described in the previous section) created under the Geneva Framework project is one example of an attempt to create a claims-based presence system. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| WIF allows different systems to interoperate using a variety of authentication methods, including LDAP and Active Directory, OpenID, LiveID, Microsoft CardSpace, and Novell Digital Me. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The Internet Engineering Task Force (IETF) has developed a standard called the Extensible Messaging and Presence Protocol (XMPP) that can be used with a federation system called the Jabber Extensible Communications Platform (Jabber XCP) to provide presence information. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Among the services that use Jabber XCP are the Defense Information Systems Agency (DISA), Google Talk, Earthlink, Facebook, the National Weather Service, Twitter, the |URL| Marine Corps, and the |URL| Joint Forces Command (USJFCOM). |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Jabber XCP is popular because it is an extensible development platform that is platform-independent and supports several communications protocols, such as the Session Initiation Protocol for Instant Messaging and Presence Leveraging Extensions (SIMPLE) and Instant Messaging and Presence Service (IMPS). |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The notion of applying presence services over the standard Service Oriented Architecture (SOA) protocols such as is that in SOA all these protocols support unidirectional data exchange. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| You request a and a response is supplied. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| SOA architectures scale well and supply high-speed data transfers required by the collaboration services that are based on presence service technologies. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| SOA also has the problem of services that have trouble penetrating firewalls. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| It was these barriers that Jabber and XMPP were created to solve, and you will find that protocol incorporated into a number of cloud computing SaaS services. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| AOL, Apple, Google, IBM, and others are using this technology in some of their applications today. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Summary In this chapter, you learned about many of the issues concerning security and cloud computing. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This is a rapidly changing area of great importance to anyone considering deploying systems or storing data in the cloud. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Security may, in fact, be the single most important area of cloud computing that you need to plan for. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Depending upon the type of service you use, you may find many security services already built into your system. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| An issue you need to consider is how to protect data in transit to and stored in the cloud. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Data encryption, access restrictions, and data protection services were described. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Multi-tenancy, system virtualization, and other factors make monitoring, regulatory compliance, and incidence response more challenging than on-premises systems are. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A key concept for controlling access to cloud resources is identity management. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In Chapter |NUMBER| the standards used to create cloud systems are described. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| These standards create what is called the Service Oriented Architecture. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| You also learn how cloud systems can be built from many different interoperable modular parts. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Part IV Understanding Services and Applications IN THIS PART Chapter |NUMBER| Understanding Service Oriented Architecture Chapter |NUMBER| Moving Applications to the Cloud Chapter |NUMBER| Working with Cloud-Based Storage Chapter |NUMBER| Working with Productivity Software Chapter |NUMBER| Using Webmail Services Chapter |NUMBER| Communicating with the Cloud Chapter |NUMBER| Using Media and Streaming Understanding Service Oriented Architecture Service Oriented Architecture (SOA) describes a standard method for requesting services from distributed components and managing the results. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Because the clients requesting services, the components providing the services, the protocols used to deliver messages, and the responses can vary widely, SOA provides the translation and management layer in an architecture that removes the barrier for a client obtaining desired services. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| With SOA, clients and components can be written in different languages and can use multiple messaging protocols and networking protocols to communicate with one another. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| SOA provides the standards that transport the messages and makes the infrastructure to support it possible. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| SOA provides access to reusable Web services over a network, which makes this an important topic to cloud computing going forward. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| IN THIS CHAPTER Using Service Oriented Architecture Defining message-based transactions Understanding processes and transactions Managing SOA distributed applications You need SOA if you are creating a monolithic cloud application that performs a specific function such as backup, e-mail, Web page access, or instant messaging. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Many of the large and familiar cloud computing applications are monolithic and were built with proprietary often on top of open source software and hardware. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| However, as cloud computing applications expand their capability to provide additional and diverse services, SOA offers access to ready-made, modular, highly optimized, and widely shareable components that can minimize developer and infrastructure costs. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| For over a decade now Service Oriented Architecture has been part of a collaborative effort on the part of both large and small vendors to come up with a common solution to architecting complex business software processes efficiently. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| As cloud computing matures and the applications offered become more capable, the key to being competitive and offering users the capability to customize their environments lays in the standardization that Service Oriented Architecture offers. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The influence of SOA in cloud computing is therefore likely to grow. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Part Understanding Services and Applications This chapter provides the basis for understanding what SOA is, how SOA operates, what limitations and capabilities are part of the architecture, and the vocabulary that you need to know in this subject. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| SOA is an architecture, first and foremost, so in essence it is a blueprint for creating a system conforming to this standard. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The environment it creates is a virtual message-passing system with a loose coupling between clients and services. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The products that support SOA are a diverse lot. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| SOA components are meant to be modular and easily added to a business process, and this modularity makes them good candidates for Computer Aided Software Engineering (CASE) modeling tools. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This chapter describes the software used to support SOA and some of the important ways in which the architecture is interpreted. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Cloud computing is not the next evolutionary step beyond SOA, as some think because of longer history. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The two technologies are complementary. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Whereas SOA can be used to construct large and complex applications that scale both horizontally and vertically, cloud computing applications tend to be scaled vertically. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Horizontal scaling refers to applications with a large number of different business processes operating. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Vertical scaling refers to large applications with a limited number of business processes operating. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| SOA techniques may be applied in both instances. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Introducing Service Oriented Architecture Service Oriented Architecture (SOA) is a specification and a methodology for providing platformand language-independent services for use in distributed applications. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A service is a repeatable task within a business process, and a business task is a composition of services. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| SOA describes a message-passing taxonomy for a component-based architecture that provides services to clients upon demand. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Clients access a component that complies with SOA by passing a message containing metadata to be acted upon in a standard format. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The component acts on that message and returns a response that the client then uses for its own purpose. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A common example of a message is an XML file transported over a network protocol such as SOAP. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Usually service providers and service consumers do not pass messages directly to each other. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Implementations of SOA employ middleware software to play the role of transaction manager (or broker) and translator. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| That middleware can discover and list available services, as well as potential service consumers, often in the form of a registry, because SOA describes a distributed architecture security and trust services are built directly into many of these products to protect communication. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Middleware products also can be where the logic of business processes reside; they can be generalpurpose applications, industry-specific, private, or public services. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Middleware services manage lookup requests. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The Universal Description Discovery and Integration (UDDI) protocol is the one most commonly used to broadcast and discover available Web services, often passing data in the form of an Electronic Business using eXtensible Markup Language (ebXML) documents. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Service consumers find a Web service in a broker registry and bind their service requests to that specific service; if the broker supports several Web services, it can bind to any of the ones that are useful. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Chapter |NUMBER|: Understanding Service Oriented Architecture This architecture does not contain executable links that require access to a specific API. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The message presents data to the service, and the service responds. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| It is up to the client to determine if the service returned an appropriate result. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| An SOA is then seen as a method for creating an integrated process as a set of linked services. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The component exposes itself as an “endpoint” (a term of art in SOA) to the client. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The most commonly used message-passing format is an Extensible Markup Language (XML) document using Simple Object Access Protocol (SOAP), but many more are possible, including Web Services Description Language (WSDL), Web Services Security (WSS), and Business Process Execution Language for Web Services (WS-BPEL). |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| WSDL is commonly used to describe the service interface, how to bind information, and the nature of the service or endpoint. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The Service Component Definition Language (SCDL) is used to define the service component that performs the service, providing the component service information that is not part of the Web service and that therefore be part of WSDL. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Note Whatever protocol is used to negotiate a transaction, the formal definition of the transaction is referred to as the “contract.” Indeed, the notion of a contract implies a certain level of service that is available to clients and that may be part of any paid service in SOA. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| n Figure |URL| shows a protocol stack for an SOA architecture and how those different protocols execute the functions required in the Service Oriented Architecture. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In the figure, the box labeled Other Services could include Common Object Request Broker Architecture (CORBA), Representational State Transfer (REST), Remote Procedure Calls (RPC), Distributed Common Object Model (DCOM), Jini, Data Distribution Service (DDS), Windows Communication Foundation (WCF), and other technologies and protocols. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| It is this flexibility and neutrality that makes SOA so singularly useful in designing complex applications. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| These services and the manner in which they interact in regards to SOA have been codified by a number of standards organizations, and some of the more prominent efforts are described later in this chapter. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Tip To read the IBMs SOA Foundation White Paper, see |URL| SOA provides the framework needed to allow clients of any type to engage in a request-response mechanism with a service. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The specification of the manner in which messages are passed in SOA, or in which events are handled, are referred to as their contract. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The term is meant to imply that the client engages the service in a task that must be managed in a specified manner. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In real systems, contracts may specifically be stated with a Quality of Service parameter in a real paper contract. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Typically, SOA requires the use of an orchestrator or broker service to ensure that messages are correctly transacted. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| SOA makes no other demands on either the client (consumer) or the components (provider) of the service; it is concerned only with the interface or action boundary between the two. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This is the earliest definition of SOA architecture. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Part Understanding Services and Applications FIGURE |URL| A protocol stack for SOA showing the relationship of each protocol to its function Business Processes Quality of Service (QoS) Description Messaging Business Processes Execution Language for Web Services (WS-BPEL) Reliability Transactions Management Management Web Services Description Language (WSDL) SOAP SOAP Extensible Markup Language (XML) Extensible Markup Language (XML) Other Protocols and Services Components are often written to comply with the Service Component Architecture (SCA), a languageand technology-agnostic design specification that has wide, but not universal, industry support. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| SCA can use the services of components that are written in the Business Process Execution Language (BPEL), Java, XML, or Cobol, and can apply to and Fortran, as well as to the dynamic languages Python, Ruby, PHP, and others. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This allows components to be written in the easiest form that supports the business process that the component is meant to service. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| By wrapping data from legacy clients written in languages such as COBOL, SOA has greatly extended the life of many legacy applications. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Tip To read David white paper on SCA, go to |URL| Components are coded with their service logic and their dependencies, QoS is established, and the service is instantiated. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In the SCA model, data and messages are exchanged in a Service Data Object (SDO). |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This system of messaging using objects and services is sometimes referred to as a Data Access Service (DAS). |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Figure |URL| shows how components of different types can communicate using different protocols as part of SOA. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| When you combine Web services to create business processes, the integration must be managed. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Two main methods are used to combine Web orchestration and choreography. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In orchestration, a middleware service centrally coordinates all the different Web service operations, and all services send messages and receive messages from the orchestrator. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The logic of the compound business process is found at the orchestrator alone. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Figure |URL| shows how orchestration is managed. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Chapter |NUMBER|: Understanding Service Oriented Architecture FIGURE |URL| SOA allows for different component and client construction, as well as access to each using different protocols. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Java Client Client WS-BPEL Client SOAP REST RNI Java Component Component WS-BPEL Component Services (Providers) Enterprise Service Bus Enterprise Service Bus Enterprise Service Bus By contrast, a compound business process that uses choreography has no central coordination function. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In choreography, each Web service that is part of a business process is aware of when to process a message and with what client or component it needs to interact with. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Choreography is a collaborative effort where the logic of the business process is pushed out to the members who are responsible for determining which operations to execute and when to execute them, the structure of the messages to be passed and their timing, and other factors. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Figure |URL| illustrates the nature of choreography. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| What clear from Figure |URL| but is shown in Figure |URL| (orchestration) and Figure |URL| (choreography) is that business processes are conducted using a sequence, in parallel, or simply by being invoked (called to). |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| An execution language like WS-BPEL provides commands for defining logic using conditional statements, loops, variables, fault handlers, and other constructs. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Because a business process is a collection of activity graphs, complex processes are often shown as part of Unified Modeling Language (UML) diagrams. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| UML is the modeling language of the Object Management Group that provides a method for creating visual models for software in the form of |NUMBER| types of diagrams. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Some of the diagram types are structure, behavior, class, component, object, interaction, state, and sequence. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Tip You can find a primer on BPEL by Matjaz Juric on Web site at |URL| For information on SOA modeling, refer to ServiceOriented Analysis, Design, and Architecture, by Michael Bell, Wiley, |NUMBER| and later book SOA Modeling Patterns for Service-Oriented Discovery and Analysis, Wiley, |NUMBER|. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| n Part Understanding Services and Applications FIGURE |URL| An orchestrated business process uses a central controlling service or element, referred to as the orchestrator, conductor, or less frequently, the coordinator. |ENDSENT|

|STARTSENT| Invoke Web Service |NUMBER| Web Service |NUMBER| Most mature SOA implementations favor orchestration over choreography for a number of reasons. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| With orchestration a single central service manages the various processes, and changes to the business logic can be made in that one location. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The integration of Web services into the architecture is easier than with choreography because these services need to know anything about the business process. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Centralizing the business logic also makes it easier to put error handling mechanisms in place and to account for, manage, and analyze events that occur outside the business process that relate to a part of the process. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Event handling is part of event-driven SOA or SOA |URL| which extends Service Oriented Architecture to include both random and scheduled events that are triggered by a business process outside of a business process. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| One way of performing orchestration is through the use of an Enterprise Service Bus or ESB. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| An ESB provides a middleware software layer for event management with a messaging infrastructure. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| ESBs are described later in the section called “The Enterprise Service Bus.” An ESB required by SOA, but it is often used to create a compliant and efficient service architecture. |ENDSENT|
