|STARTSENT| Invoke Web Service |NUMBER| Event-driven SOA or SOA |URL| Event-driven SOA or SOA |URL| is an extension of the Service Oriented Architecture to respond to events that occur as a result of business processes or perhaps cause and influence a business process. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| For example, in a business process, sales at a certain Web site are processed. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| If the business process recognizes the rate at which sales are occurring, it could perform an analysis to determine what events might influence the buying decision. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This is the sort of analysis that event-driven SOA is meant to address. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| SOA |URL| can allow low-level events to trigger a business process, correlate events with information contained in the SOA design, inhibit a business process if the appropriate events appear, or invoke a reaction or response based on a trigger. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| To perform these tasks in SOA |URL| a Causal Vector Engine (CVE) with some built-in artificial intelligence must be added to the SOA design. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Events are analyzed in terms of event sequences, event relationships, and event timing to establish whether a certain condition has occurred. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The CVE then determines how to react to the condition using a set of rules that are built into the system. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Many CVE systems display events in a console in different contexts so that an observer can Part Understanding Services and Applications analyze the display and take appropriate actions. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A CVE application may include the ability to query event data in the same way that a stock ticker or trading application can query trading data. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The CVE application provides the same kind of heartbeat and correlation functionality that a stock trading application does. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| From the standpoint of the service requestor or consumer (client), the client simply needs to know the form required to initiate the action of the provider (service) and how to interpret the results returned from the service provider. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The nature of the processing is unknown, the location where the processing is done is unknown, and the various operating systems and applications involved are unknown. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The client is responsible for validating that the service returned the results that were expected. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The SOA component is essentially a black box to the client. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| That is, SOA makes no demands of the component other than to conform to the rules of a standard endpoint. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This level of abstraction offers operational advantages to Web service providers in that components can be continually upgraded, replaced, or moved to improve efficiencies without disrupting the clients that depend on those services, and the Quality of Service for that service can be accurately measured and delivered. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In SOA, the service has been virtualized. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Cross-Ref Communication protocols are discussed in detail in Chapter |NUMBER| “Understanding Cloud Architecture.” n Any network service that spans different application types is a candidate for componentization. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Consider a logon or authentication system. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| It would be wasteful to implement the same authentication functionality in several different applications when a single unified module could serve the same purpose. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A single sign-on system for an accounting package, payroll module, or production database replaces three separate modules with attendant efficiencies in the amount of code that needs to be written and managed and the level of system overhead that is involved. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| SOA provides the rules so each application can access the authentication module in its own way, as required. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| What you gain with SOA is the ability to add significant capabilities with a fraction of the cost or effort and to federate applications if you desire. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| What you lose with SOA is the ability to perform fundamental customization of the service itself when that service is provided by a third party. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The Enterprise Service Bus In Figure |URL| those aforementioned hypothetical three different applications are shown interfaced with an authentication module through what has come to be called an Enterprise Service Bus (ESB). |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| An ESB is not a physical bus in the sense of a network; rather, it is an architectural pattern comprised of a set of network services that manage transactions in a Service Oriented Architecture. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| You may prefer to think of an ESB as a set of services that separate clients from components on a transactional basis and that the use of the word bus in the name indicates a high degree of connectivity or fabric quality to the system; that is, the system is loosely coupled. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Messages flow from client to component through the ESB, which manages these transactions, even though the location of the services comprising the ESB may vary widely. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Chapter |NUMBER|: Understanding Service Oriented Architecture An ESB is necessary but not essential to a Service Oriented Architecture because typical business processes can span a vast number of messages and events, and distributed processing is an inherently unreliable method of transport. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| An ESB therefore plays the role of a transaction broker in SOA, ensuring that messages get to where they where supposed to go and are acted upon properly. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The service bus performs the function of message translation, registration, routing, logging, auditing, and managing transactional integrity. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Transactional integrity is similar to ACID in a database consistency, isolation, and durability, the essence of which is that transactions succeed or they fail and are rolled back. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| FIGURE |URL| An SOA application of a shared logon or Authentication module Client Payroll Module Production Database Accounting Package Enterprise Service Bus (ESB) Other Services Authentication Service Part Understanding Services and Applications An ESB may be part of a network operating system or may be implemented using a set of middleware products. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| An ESB creates a virtual environment layered on top of an enterprise messaging system where services are advertised and accessed. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Think of an ESB as a message transaction system. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| WebSphere ESB |URL| is an ESB based on open standards such as Java EE, EJB, WS-Addressing, WS-Policy, and Kerberos security, and it runs on the WebSphere Application Server. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| It is interoperable with Open SCA. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| WebSphere ESB contains both a Service Federation Management tool and an integrated Registry and Repository function. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| These typical features are found in ESBs, among Monitoring services aid in managing events. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Process management services manage message transactions. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Data repositories or registries store business logic and aid in governance of business processes. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Data services pass messages between clients and services. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Data abstraction services translate messages from one format to another, as required. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Governance is a service that monitors compliance of your operations with governmental regulation, which can vary from state to state and from country to country. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Security services validate clients and services and allow messages to pass from one to the other. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Figure |URL| shows how these different services in an SOA relate to one another. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The difference between a repository and a registry in the context of a Service Oriented Architecture is subtle. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Repositories and registries are both data stores, but a repository stores references to the components of the SOA, their source code, and linking information that are used to provide SOA services. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| An SOA registry contains references to rules, descriptions, and definitions of the seris, the metadata of the components. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A repository serves the role that a name server does in a network operating system infrastructure, while the registry plays the role of a directory service (domain). |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The service broker uses the rules contained in the SOA registry to perform its function as translator and delivery agent. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| For developers, the registry serves as the central location to store component descriptions that allow composite applications to be created and the place in which services may be published for general use. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| These services in an SOA also include the provider interfaces and standard sets of network protocols that were mentioned previously. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Developers may also choose to create a Business Process Orchestration module to coordinate the access and transactional integrity of multiple business applications that integrate into a larger platform, described in the next section in more detail. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Chapter |NUMBER|: Understanding Service Oriented Architecture FIGURE |URL| This figure shows a network services model infrastructure for an SOA, which is based on the SOA metamodel of the Linthicum Group, |NUMBER|. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A slightly different version of this diagram appears in Networking Bible by Barrie Sosinsky, Wiley, |NUMBER|. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Monitoring Event Management Process Orchestration Services Data Services Messaging Data Abstraction Data Internet Services New Services Legacy Application Repository Service catalogs Finding any particular service and locating the requirement in a large SOA implementation can involve a large amount of network system overhead. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| To aid in locating services, SOA infrastructure often includes a catalog service. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This service stores information on the following, among other Part Understanding Services and Applications What services are available, both internal and external How to use a service Which applications are related to a particular service (dependencies) How services relate to one another Who owns the service and how a service is modified The event history of a service, including service levels, outages, and so on The nature of service contracts Service catalogs are dynamic and under constant modification. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Catalog servers have these They can be standalone catalog servers serving a single site. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| They serve the role of a global catalog service where two or more catalog servers are merged to include several sites. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A global service usually requires some sort of synchronization or update to maintain a unified data store across the servers involved. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| They can be part of a federated catalog service where two or more global catalog servers have access to one information through a trusted query relationship. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Catalog services have an enormous impact on large system performance and eventually become essential as a SOA internetwork system grows. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| An internetwork is a network that is constructed through the consolidation of separate networks, in the same manner that the Internet has been built. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Note The Information Technology Infrastructure Library (ITIL) developed by the United Office of Government Commerce (OGC) has developed a Service Catalog Management design specification as part of the ITIL Service Design Package (SDP). |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Service Designs present best practice guidance for planned services. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The ITIL Web site may be found at |URL| n Defining SOA Communications Message passing in SOA requires the use of two different protocol the data interchange format and the network protocol that carries the message. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A client (or customer) connected to an ESB communicates over a network protocol such as HTTP, Representational State Transfer (REST), or Java Message Service (JMS) to a component (or service). |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Messages are most often in the form of the eXtensible Markup Language (XML) or in a variant such as the Simple Object Access Protocol (SOAP). |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| SOAP is a messaging format used in Web services that use XML as the message format while relying on Application layer protocols such as HTTP and Remote Procedure Calls (RPC) for message negotiation and transmission. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Chapter |NUMBER|: Understanding Service Oriented Architecture The software used to write clients and components can be written in Java, Web Service Business Process Execution Language (WS-BPEL), or another form of executable code; the services that they message can be written in the same or another language. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| What is required is the ability to transport and translate a message into a form that both parties can understand. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| An ESB may require a variety of combinations in order to support communications between a service consumer and a service provider. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| For example, in WebSphere ESB, you might see the following XML/JMS (Java Message Service) SOAP/JMS SOAP/HTTP Text/JMS Bytes/JMS The Web Service Description Language (WSDL) is one of the most commonly used XML protocols for messaging in Web services, and it finds use in Service Oriented Architectures. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Version |URL| of WSDL is a standard, but the current version WSDL |URL| (formerly version |URL| has yet to be ratified by the The significant difference between |URL| and |URL| is that version |URL| has more support for RESTful (|URL| Web |URL| application, but much less support in the current set of software development tools. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The most common transport for WSDL is SOAP, and the WSDL file usually contains both XML data and an XML schema. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| REST offers some very different capabilities than SOAP. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| With REST, each URL is an object that you can query and manipulate. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| You use HTML commands such as GET, POST, PUT, and DELETE to work with REST objects. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| SOAP uses a different approach to working with Web data, exposing Web objects through an API and transferring data using XML. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The REST approach offers lightweight access using standard HTTP command, is easier to implement than SOAP, and comes with less overhead. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| SOAP is often more precise and provides a more error-free consumption model. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| SOAP often comes with more sophisticated development tools. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| All major Web services use REST, but many Web services, especially newer ones, combine REST with SOAP to derive the benefits that both offer. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Contained within WSDL are essential objects to support message transfer, including The service object, a container where the service resides. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The port or endpoint, which is the unique address of the service. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The binding, which is the description of the interface (|URL| RPC) and the transport (|URL| SOAP). |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The portType, or interface that defines the capabilities of the Web service, and what operations are to be performed, as well as the messages that must be sent to support the operation. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The operation that is to be performed on the message. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Part Understanding Services and Applications The message content, which is the data and metadata that the service operation is performed on. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Each message may consist of one or more parts, and each part must include typing information. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The types used to describe the data, usually as part of the XML schema that accompanies the WSDL. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Tip A set of primers on WSDL may be found on the Web site. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The latest version, “Web Services Description Language (WSDL) Version |URL| Part |NUMBER|: Primer” may be found at |URL| The code that follows is the WSDL |URL| document that is created and analyzed in the WSDL primer referenced in the accompanying tip. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| version=”|URL|” ?> This document describes the GreatH Web service. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Additional application-level requirements for use of this service beyond what WSDL |URL| is able to describe are available at |URL| resSvc” name=”checkAvailability” name=”tCheckAvailability”> name=”checkInDate” name=”checkOutDate” name=”roomType” Chapter |NUMBER|: Understanding Service Oriented Architecture name=”checkAvailabilityResponse” name=”invalidDataError” name=”opCheckAvailability” messageLabel=”In” messageLabel=”Out” ref=”tns:invalidDataFault” name=”reservationSOAPBinding” ref=”tns:invalidDataFault” ref=”tns:opCheckAvailability” name=”reservationService” name=”reservationEndpoint” address Part Understanding Services and Applications Notice the major elements of the document. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The XML document sets up the namespace, defines the interface, specifies the binding, names the service, provides the documentations for the service, and then supplies a schema that may be used to validate the document. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In the message descriptions, the message types are declared. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| XML schema can be separate files, but what we see here is normal for WSDL, an inline schema that is part of the WSDL document. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| For a much more complete description, refer to the tutorial. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A WSDL file contains essential message data for a transaction, but it capture the full scope of a Service Oriented Architecture design. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Additional requirements need to be specified. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The functional requirements for message passing between client and service in SOA are embodied in the concept of a service contract. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A service contract codifies the relationship between the data to be processed, the metadata that accompanies that data, the intended service, and the manner in which the service will act upon that message. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Messages therefore must have some of the following pieces of information contained inside Header: The header contains the name of the service, service version, owner of the service, and perhaps a responsibility assignment. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This is often defined in terms of a RACI matrix where the various roles and responsibilities for processes are spelled out in terms of a set of tasks or deliverables. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The acronym designates the Responsible party or service, the Accountable decision maker, the Consulted party, and or that must be Informed on the use of the service. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Service Examples of service types include data, business, integration, presentation, and process types. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Functional This category includes the functional requirements, what service operations or actions and methods must be performed, and the manner in which a service is invoked or initiated. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Invocation usually includes the URL and the nature of the service interface. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Transaction A message may define a transaction that may need to be managed or tracked or be part of or include another transaction operated at a specific Quality of Service and under a specific Service Level Agreement (SLA). |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Security parameters also are part of a attributes, as are the role the message plays in a process and the terms or semantics used to describe the interaction of the message with a interface. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Depending upon the degree of formalization a service contract may require messages to carry a variable amount of information in order to be successfully transacted. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| You can see, therefore, how SOA expands the definition of a Web service transaction from WSDL. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Business Process Execution Language If a message represents an atomic transaction in a Service Oriented Architecture, the next level of abstraction up is the grouping and managing of sets of transactions to form useful work and to execute a business process. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| An example of an execution language is the Business Process Execution Language (BPEL) or alternatively as the Web Service Business Process Execution Language Chapter |NUMBER|: Understanding Service Oriented Architecture (WS-BPEL), a language standard for Web service interactions. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The standard is maintained by the Organization for the Advancement of Structured Information Standards (OASIS) through their Web Services Business Process Execution Language Technical Committee (WSBPEL-TC; see |URL| BPEL is a meta-language comprised of two executable commands for Web services and clients, and internal or abstract code for executing the internal business logic that processes require. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A meta-language is any language whose statements refer to statements in another language referred to as the object language. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| BPEL is often used to compose, orchestrate, and coordinate business processes with Web services in the SOA model, and it has commands to manage asynchronous communications. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| BPEL uses XML with specific support for messaging protocols such as SOAP, WSDL, UDDI, WS-Reliable Messaging, WS-Addressing, WS-Coordination, and WS-Transactions. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| BPEL also builds on Web Services Flow Language (WSFL) and XLANG for data transport; the former is a system of directed graphs, while the latter is a block-structured language adding to additional verbs and nouns specific for business processes to BPEL, which were combined to form and are being merged with BPEL. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A version of BPEL to support human interaction is called and it falls under the WS-HumanTask specifications of OASIS. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| BPEL was designed to interact with WSDL and define business processes using an XML language. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| BPEL does not have a graphical component. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A business process has an internal or executable view and an external or abstract view in BPEL. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| One process may interact with other processes, but the goal is to minimize the number of specific extensions added to BPEL to support any particular business process. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Data functions in BPEL support process data and control flow, manage process instances, provide for logic and branching structures, and allow for process orchestration. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Because transactions are long-lived and asynchronous, BPEL includes techniques for error handling and scopes transactions. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| As much as possible, BPEL uses Web services for standards and to assemble and decompose processes. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Business process modeling SOA was created by the industry to solve a how to make disparate, diverse, and distributed services talk to disparate and diverse clients. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The final result of an SOA project the access of services, per se; it is the creation of a business process. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In a complex business project, the developers juggle many clients and many services, which can make visualization of the overall system difficult. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| To address this problem, various modeling tools have been developed to support SOA development and optimization, system and process management, change and life-cycle management. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Several methodologies have been developed to model SOAs. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Working in a software package to model your business processes is similar in approach to designing and optimizing a relational database in entity-relationship, object-role modeling package, or another Computer Aided System Engineering (CASE) tool for data equally as valuable. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Commonly encountered system models include the Part Understanding Services and Applications Unified Modeling Language The UML standard is the work of the Object Management Group (|URL| UML creates graphical representations of software systems in the form of a set of diagram types. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Elements in a UML architectural blueprint include actors, business processes, logic modules (components), program routines, database schemas, software components, and activities. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| UML diagrams are separated into seven structural types and four behavior types; structure types model the components of the system, while behavior types model states, actions, and events. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| UML is widely used in the industry for software system modeling. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A developed system model can be reduced automatically to code. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| XML Metadata Interchange XMI is another standard of the Object Management Group (OMG) and is used to exchange metadata using the Extensible Markup Language (XML). |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Metadata is structured into a metamodel that fits into the Meta-Object Facility. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| UML models often use XMI as their interchange format, although they can be used by other languages. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| XMI files are not generally interchangeable between the different modeling languages that can use them. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| XMI has been codified as an international standard by ISO, as |NUMBER|:|NUMBER|. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Systems Modeling Language (SysML) is an open-source extension of the part of the UML system dealing with profiles. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| It is smaller, more focused, and easier to learn and work with than UML itself. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| SysML reuses |NUMBER| of UML |URL|’s |NUMBER| diagrams. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The effort to develop SysML was rolled into OMG in |NUMBER| but remains open source. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| SysML can use XMI and is developing toward support of ISO |NUMBER| which is the Standard for the Exchange of Product Model Data (STEP) STEP aims to create the mechanisms for sharing information between the different software engineering tools described in this section (and others). |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Business Process Modeling Notation (BPMN) is a methodology for representing business processes as a set of connected visual objects that illustrate workflow in a Business Process Diagram (BPD). |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| It is similar to UML. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Originally developed in the Business Process Management Initiative (BPMI), it was incorporated into the Open Management Group in |NUMBER|. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A BPD can be reduced to the OASIS standard WS-Business Process Execution Language, which is an executable language for information transfer between different Web services. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| However, this mapping is tool specific and standardized at this point. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Service-Oriented Modeling Framework This framework was proposed by Michael Bell and combines a modeling language with a graphical display of the various SOA components so the system can be viewed as a map of objects and associated relationships. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| SOMF software allows developers to create an action plan to implement their business processes and can be valuable in system and architecture optimization, tracing message pathways, positioning software assets correctly, and providing a language for describing through abstraction and generalization how the processes operate. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| SOMF software not only allows you to determine what needs to be done, but also allows you to run “what-if” scenarios to see how changes will impact your SOA system. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Tip The Enterprise Architect (EA) offered by Sparx Systems (|URL| is an example of a unified modeling language tool that supports software systems modeled in these various languages. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| n Chapter |NUMBER|: Understanding Service Oriented Architecture A well-known SOMF modeling technology is Service-Oriented Modeling and Architecture (SOMA), introduced in |NUMBER|. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| SOMA reduces services to a set of service objects and breaks down relationships into three the services themselves, the service components that make use of those services, and the information flows required to interact between them. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Flows consist both of processes as well as their internal composition. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In SOMA, domains and functional groups are identified, variables that affect processes are analyzed, and component development and object oriented analysis are used to model specific cases. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| SOMA is meant to provide information on service and service boundaries, service granularity, and asset analysis. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In SOMF, the modeling is based on the elements of the service life Conceptualization: Defining the processes that will be supported Discovery: Determining how components are exposed Analysis: Identifying the relationships services have to clients Integration: Implementing the messaging infrastructure that connects clients to components Logical Building the system and process logic and determining how orchestration or choreography will be performed Architecture Creating the system component architecture and reducing design to software components with specified interfaces System Building and testing the system components Figure |URL| shows the various practices brought together in the SOMF modeling discipline. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Four modeling topologies for message passing are used in Circular A circular topology is one where message passing is carried out in a circular fashion. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| There is no orchestrator in this system, and each component providing a service is responsible for knowing which message to act on and where to send a message next. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| That is, the choreography of the system is maintained at the component. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Hierarchical In a hierarchical topology, services are arranged in a tree pattern with relationships. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Messages from one service to another must traverse up the branch of the tree and down another branch from the root until the matching service is found. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Hierarchical topologies offer the advantage of a well-defined set of relationships, a central location (the root) where logic may reside, and a clearly stated address space. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The disadvantage of a hierarchical topology is that the overhead of passing a message from one service to another optimized. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Network A network topology has a relationship between services and their clients. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The advantage of a network topology is that the overhead associated with message passing has been minimized (often there is a direct path), but there is considerable overhead built into the system in order to maintain the many links needed. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Star In a star topology, services are designed to connect through a central service. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The star model is favored in orchestration processes and is useful for services that use broadcasting or multicasting services, publish and subscribe, and other related systems. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Part Understanding Services and Applications FIGURE |URL| SOMF |URL| practices, principles, and design methodologies Service-Oriented Modeling Practices Abstraction Practice Realization Practice Conceptual Environment Analysis Environment Logical Environment Service Conceptualization Discipline Conceptual Architecture Discipline Service Discovery Analysis Discipline Business Integration Discipline Service Design Discipline Logical Architecture Discipline Conceptual Service Conceptual Architecture Analysis Service Design Service Logical Architecture Modeling Solutions Solution Service Solution Architecture Service-Oriented Architecture Modeling Framework (SOMF) Version |URL| Best Practices Business Transparency Architecture Best-Practices Traceability Asset Reuse Consolidation Virtuality Loose Coupling Interoperability Modularity Componentization Figure |URL| shows an interaction diagram of these four different topologies. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A service in SOMF that is granular and very narrow in scope is referred to as an atomic service. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| An atomic service cannot be decomposed into smaller services that provide a useful function. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| An example of an atomic service is a customer lookup that contains a customer ID and the name and address. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| An address that contain the name or lists a customer name without an ID have much value, so this service stands alone. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In Figure |URL| an atomic service would be represented by one of the circles in the diagrams. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Chapter |NUMBER|: Understanding Service Oriented Architecture FIGURE |URL| The four different message-passing topologies used in SOMF are shown above. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The lines and arrows indicate message-passing pathways and relationships. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Circular topology Network topology Star topology Hierarchical topology Rarely do atomic services stand alone. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A service that provides ID, name, and address might be part of a set of services that describe a bank account, customer purchase record, or any number of services. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A collection of services that work together is referred to as a composite service. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The Enterprise Service Bus described previously in this chapter is another example of a composite service; it contains functions for message routing, message interchange and translation, and process orchestration. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A composite service is usually organized as a hierarchical topology and is multifunctional or a coarse-grained entity. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| SOA describes a distributed collection of services performing business process functions. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A collection of composite services that would form a process module is referred to as a service cluster. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Service clusters may be composed of both atomic services and composite services. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Large functions such as payroll modules would normally be composite SOA services. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Part Understanding Services and Applications Tip To view a structured presentation on how to build an SOMF diagram, go to |URL| |URL| The white paper “Enacting the Service Oriented Modeling Framework (SOMF) Using Enterprise Architect” by Frank Truyen (|URL| shows different SOMF diagram types. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| n In an SOMF model, each of these three service types (atomic, composite, and clusters) appears as a specific shape, and connections are made between them that generalize, specify, expand, or contract the services they provide. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Services are typed, granular services are identified, and then services may be aggregated, decomposed, unified, intersected, or subtracted from other services to suit the needs of the business process being modeled. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The SOMF modeling notation has a symbol for each analysis that relates one service to another. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| As you build a business process, you add services to the model and connect them in ways that make sense for your workflow. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| When the model is complete and optimized, it is reduced to a conceptualized service that relates the business process to the specific implementation chosen. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Some modeling technologies allow for the reduction of the model to executable code. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Managing and Monitoring SOA Software for monitoring and managing an SOA infrastructure plays an important role in large SOA deployments. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| While SOA offers a logical design and reusable components, it does not make the task of network management any easier. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| If anything, SOA management requires proactive oversight because you wait for a particular application to fail before taking corrective action. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Therefore, tools for managing SOAs tend to be multifaceted and run constantly. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| SOA management tools There are a number of network management frameworks products and suites, notably HP Software and Solutions OpenView SOA Manager (|URL| |URL| IBM Tivoli Framework Composite Application Manager for SOA (ITCAM; see |URL| |URL| These products have SOA tools for network management. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| product specializes in change management and SOA lifecycle development, and it integrates with a WebSphere and other Tivoli systems. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| HP SOA Manager provides dynamic mapping, monitoring, and optimization of SOA services such as Web services, software assets, and virtual services. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| These framework products create a central console with a variety of management views. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| BPEL Process Manager and WebSphere are process managers for creating an Enterprise Service Bus. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Chapter |NUMBER|: Understanding Service Oriented Architecture The SOA management software technology is dynamic, with many small products some of which have been purchased and rolled into (or are being rolled into) larger systems. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| recent acquisition of SOA Management System is an example of this trend. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| BMC |URL| is an automated SOA problem-resolution package, as is Tidal Intersperse package, which has root cause analysis services. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The CA Wily SOA Solution |URL| is a monitoring and discovery service that can map SOA transactions and dependencies and discover components such as ESBs, Web portals, and various Web services. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| LISA (|URL| Enterprise SOA Testing platform specializes in testing Web service components that are used in SOA. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Another example of an SOA transaction manager is CoreFirst |URL| Configuration and change management present a particular challenge in the area of SOA (and cloud computing in general). |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In addition to the fact that elements of an SOA infrastructure can be highly distributed and therefore require good discovery mechanisms, these environments also are highly virtualized. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| As workloads vary, solutions often provision virtual servers as needed and move these virtual processing across physical servers. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Virtualization will continue to challenge SOA management software well into the future. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| SOA security Any system that sends hundreds or thousands of messages across an internetwork as SOA does is subject to attack in all the traditional ways that network traffic is hijacked, spoofed, redirected, or blocked. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Because SOA eliminates the use of application boundaries, the traditional methods where security is at the application level likely to be effective. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Cisco has a family of products that enforce rules and policies for the transmission of XML messaging that they have named Application Oriented Networking (AON; |URL| A similar policy based XML security service may be found in Web application delivery appliance. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| To address SOA security, a set of OASIS standards (|URL| was created, which includes the Security Assertion Markup Language (SAML) is an XML standard that provides for data authentication and authorization between client and service. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The SAML technology is used as part of Single Sign-on Systems (SSO) and allows a user logging into a system from a Web browser to have access to distributed SOA resources. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| WS-Security (WSS) is an extension of SOA that enforces security by applying tokens such as Kerberos, SAML, or |URL| to messages. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Through the use of XML Signature and XML Encryption, WSS aims to offer security. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Part Understanding Services and Applications WS-SecureConversion is a Web services protocol for creating and sharing security context. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| WS-SecureConversion is meant to operate in systems where WS-Security, WS-Trust, and WS-Policy are in use, and it attaches a security context token to communications such as SOAP used to transport messages in an SOA enterprise. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| WS-SecurityPolicy provides a set of network policies that extend WS-Security, WS-Trust, and WS-SecureConversion so messages complying to a policy must be signed and encrypted. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The SecurityPolicy is part of a general WS-Policy framework. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| WS-Trust extends WS-Security to provide a mechanism to issue, renew, and validate security tokens. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A Web service using WS-Trust can implement this system through the use of a Security Token Service (STS), a mechanism for attaching security tokens to messages and a set of mechanisms for key exchanges that are used to validate tokens and messages. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Another approach to enforcing security in SOA is to use an XML gateway that intercepts XML messages transported by SOAP or REST, identifies the source of the message, and verifies that the message was securely received. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Providing XML Gateway SOA security requires a Public Key Infrastructure (PKI) so that encryption is enforced by digital signatures. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Progress SOAPscope Server and has an XML middleware service that performs diagnostic testing and Web services governance, adding that component to ability to monitor and map XML appliances and application servers. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The Open Cloud Consortium The Open Cloud Consortium (OCC; see |URL| is an organization comprised of several universities and interested companies that supports the development of standards for cloud computing and for interoperating with the various frameworks. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| OCC working groups perform these They develop benchmarks for measuring cloud computing performance. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Their benchmark and data generator for measuring large data clouds is called MalStone |URL| They provide testbeds that vendors can use to test their applications, including the Open Cloud Testbed and the Intercloud Testbed that are part of the work of the Open Cloud Testbed and Intercloud working groups. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| They support the development of open-source reference implementations for cloud computing. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The Working Group on Standards and Interoperability For Large Data Clouds extends the architecture for data storage with a distributed file system, table services, and computing using MapReduce following the model that is part of offering. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Chapter |NUMBER|: Understanding Service Oriented Architecture MapReduce is patented software framework that supports distributed large data sets organized by the Google File System (GFS) accessed by clusters of computers. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The Apache Hadoop (|URL| open-source system is based on MapReduce and GFS. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| They support the management of cloud computing infrastructure for scientific research as part of the Open Science Data Cloud (OSDCP) Working initiative. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Relating SOA and Cloud Computing Cloud computing is still in its infancy, and although Web services can implement a Service Oriented Architecture, it is not a requirement. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Most of the large implementations of cloud computing described in this book are single-purpose applications that have been optimized on a grand Carbonite’s backup, Gmail e-mail, and Instant Messaging (IM) are several examples. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Applications of those types have less of a need for the flexibility and loose coupling that SOA provides. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| As cloud applications become more diverse in scope, SOA offers an architectural blueprint for accessing diverse optimized services through a loosely coupled standardized method that provides an ability to evolve that is difficult to implement in any other way. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| SOA is loosely coupled because the service is separated from the messaging. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| If a component provide the capabilities required, it is an easy task to switch to a different component, and switching requires almost no programming. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Developers lose some of the ability to customize modules, but gain a significant advantage in simplifying their applications. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Taken as a whole, applications that rely on SOA components can be very complex and appear to be tightly coupled, when in reality they are not. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| SOA components are often service providers that can provide a measured service level and can play a role in Business Process Management (BPM) systems. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The separation of services from their design allows for much easier system upgrades and maintenance. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Many Web |URL| applications use SOA components, and SOA will become increasingly useful in larger applications that require many Web services. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Web |URL| is an acronym coined by Tim to describe Web services that allow for user input and modification. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| These applications often rely on REST and feature AJAX components in a user interface that supports Web syndication (think of the Google customizable user page), blogs, and wikis. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Some people regard mashups as Web |URL| applications as well. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A mashup is the combination of data from two or more sources that creates a unique service. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The layers added to Google maps are examples of mashups. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| AJAX stands for Asynchronous JavaScipt and XM. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| AJAX is a set of development tools that allow for client input into Web applications; it is not a standard. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Rather AJAX describes a group of technologies that leverage HTML and CSS for styling, Web objects in the Document Object Model (DOM) Part Understanding Services and Applications for data, XML and XSLT for data interchange, the XMLHttpRequest for asynchronous communication, and JavaScript commands to request data from data sources. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The challenge SOA faces in designing systems to support Web |URL| is the lack of standardization in how components in Web |URL| are used. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| However, many people believe that SOA will play a role in creating what has been dubbed an “Internet of Services” where complex services will be available for use as a set of building blocks based on the convergence of SOA and Web |URL| The Gartner Group refers to this trend as the development of “Advanced SOA,” but features of SOA that are event-driven have been part of many middleware offerings for several years now. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Summary This chapter described Service Oriented Architecture (SOA). |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| SOA offers a design methodology for creating distributed applications using diverse clients and components. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| SOA defines a messagepassing infrastructure from clients or consumers to and from service providers. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Making SOA work correctly requires a certain set of middleware products in your infrastructure. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| These servers may aid in transaction management or brokering, message translation, or other services. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Taken as a whole, these services are referred to as an Enterprise Service Bus (ESB). |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Most message-passing protocols are based on a version structured XML, although that is not required in SOA. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A variety of transport protocols are used, but SOAP and RPC are the most common ones. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The nature of SOA messaging was explored. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In a complex system of message passing and services, system management and security is an important consideration. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Tools for setting up and running an SOA infrastructure were described. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Finally, this chapter described the relationship between SOA and cloud computing. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| You need to use SOA to build a massively scaled cloud computing application, but as cloud computing applications become more capable and user configurable, the logic and structure that SOA design imposes on infrastructure will prove to be invaluable to cloud applications. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The two areas of technology benefit from their mutual convergence. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In Chapter |NUMBER| I consider the topic of transactional Web applications in cloud computing systems. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| That subject builds on what you have learned about SOA in this chapter, extending the discussion into the command Web APIs that are in use today. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| IN THIS CHAPTER Learning about cloud transactions Determining the best features to move to the cloud Seeing a cloud burst solution Knowing the factors of cloud application development Moving Applications to the Cloud In this chapter, you learn about some of the important considerations involved in moving an application from a local or on-premises installation to one that is either fully or partly in the cloud. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Some applications benefit from cloud deployment, and the cloud enhances some features. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The process for determining whether, what, and when to move your applications to the cloud involves an analysis of what critical features of the application need to be supported. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| After those critical features are understood, you can determine the features supported by your particular cloud service provider to see whether the cloud can support the critical features. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Factors such as access to data, latencies, data security, and so on often limit what applications are good candidates for porting. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Two examples of application porting to the cloud are discussed in this chapter. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In one application, physical hardware is eliminated by moving the entire application to the cloud. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In the second example, a system is essentially cloned to the cloud to provide an overflow capability, an example of a hybrid application technique called cloud bursting. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| When you move an application to the cloud, you must use the APIs of your particular cloud service provider. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| There are APIs for each of the types of cloud infrastructure, software services, and applications in the case of platform providers. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| These APIs are generally not interoperable. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| So although the situation may change in the future, an application developer must make an informed choice to select the vendor that both best suits his needs and allows him to have the greatest flexibility. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Part Understanding Services and Applications Applications in the Clouds When you deploy an application to the cloud, you start with the advantages and disadvantages of a distributed system that is the Internet and add to that mix the fundamental characteristics that clouds offer. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In the cloud, your applications must account for system abstraction and redirection, scalability, a whole new set of application and system APIs, latencies, and other factors that are specific to one cloud platform or another. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In theory, any application can run either completely or partially in the cloud. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The question a developer needs to ask is whether his function is best served by cloud or local deployment. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| That answer depends upon the attributes of the application that the developer is trying to preserve or enhance, and how locating those services in the cloud impacts those attributes. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This chapter takes a broad look at cloud computing from an application-specific viewpoint and attempts to highlight the factors that make cloud-based applications successful. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The location of an application or service plays a fundamental role in how the application must be written. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| An application or process that runs on a desktop or server is executed coherently, as a unit, under the control of an integrated program. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| An action triggers a program call, code executes, and a result is returned and may be acted upon. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Taken as a unit, “Request Process Response” is an atomic transaction. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Because the transaction is executing locally within the purview of a monolithic application, the process is stateful and transaction is consistent. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| That is, the condition of the transaction is always known and the result is always accounted for. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A coherent transaction either succeeds and is enacted, or fails and is rolled back. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| When rollback is not possible due to optimistic transaction commitment in a multiuser application, atomicity requires correcting the condition or performs some other compensating action at some later time. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The properties necessary to guarantee a reliable transaction in databases and other applications and the technologies necessary to achieve them have been called the ACID principle. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The acronym stands Atomicity: The atomic property defines a transaction as something that cannot be subdivided and must be completed or abandoned as a unit. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Consistency: The consistency property states that the system must go from one known state to another and that the system integrity must be maintained. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Isolation: The isolation property states that the system cannot have other transactions operate on data that is currently being processed by a transaction. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Durability: The durability property states that the system must have a mechanism to recover from committed transactions should that be necessary. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Chapter |NUMBER|: Moving Applications to the Cloud The ACID rules were developed by Jim Gray to apply to database technology in the late The ACID principle is used today by any application that is reading and writing to a stored data set, which includes just about any application type you can think of. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| An application that runs as a service on the Internet has a client portion that makes a request and a server portion that responds to that request. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The request has been decoupled from the response because the transaction is executing in two or more places. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In a distributed system, the transaction is stateless. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In order to create a stateful system in a distributed architecture, a transaction manager or broker must be added so that the intermediary service can account for transactions and react accordingly when they succeed or fail. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| When applications get moved to the cloud, they retain the features of a three-layered architecture, but now physical systems become virtualized systems. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Virtual machines are not only stateless, but the place where program execution occurs is likely to be different every time the process runs. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| These fundamental properties must be accounted for in any cloud-based application. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Functionality mapping Some applications can be successfully ported to the cloud, while others suffer from the translation. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Understanding whether your particular application can benefit from cloud deployment requires that you deconstruct your functionality into its basic components and identify which functions are critical and can be supported by the cloud. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| For example, any application that requires access to a data store quickly runs up against some of the limits that cloud computing imposes. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Order transaction systems require that data in a database maintain the transactional integrity implied by the ACID model. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| For many non-relational cloud storage systems, such as the Amazon Simple Storage Service the newly announced Google Storage for Developers, and the Windows Azure Storage Service, the ability of the system to maintain transactional integrity through record locking part of those systems. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| These types of storage systems are secure and store large amounts of data, but they have very slow access to that data and do not support query and retrieval well. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| These limitations are why all these vendors offer alternative relational cloud database systems such as SQL Azure. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In Figure |URL| an attribute tree is constructed for an order transaction system where the functionality is decomposed into different functional areas. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| At the top are high-level attributes; some of these functions are essential to the operation of the application while others are not. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Drilling down on the data management attribute, the second level explores data access and then access methods. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A critical attribute for the application is the need to be able to access data when the client is both online and offline. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Note This exercise required for all attributes, just the critical ones, which should result in a manageable list. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| n Part Understanding Services and Applications FIGURE |URL| An attribute map is created to expose critical functionality. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Availability Data Management Distribution Managebility Reliability Scalability Scalability User Interface Data Management Access Data Structure Index Persistence Query State Transaction Access Methods Online Offline The choice to allow both online and offline data access determines the nature of your interaction with both cloud and local data stores. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| If the application needed to access data only when the client was online, then access to cloud-based storage would be the only data store your application would required. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Perhaps the application could be entirely in the cloud and browserbased. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The decision to allow both online and local data access means that you must create a hybrid application with a cloud component and a local component. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Even if the access to data on the local system is a simple caching system, client-side support is needed. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| To support the data access, you may also be faced with building a synchronization or replication feature, which adds more overhead to the application. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This type of mapping exercise leads to some conclusions about the value of cloud computing to this particular application. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| You could safely conclude that an application that gets the most value from a cloud deployment is one that uses online storage without the need for offline storage. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| An application that needed offline storage alone might not benefit from a cloud deployment at all. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In the case of a hybrid application, other factors such as scalability, costs, or ubiquitous access might offset the cost of offline access and make the cloud more attractive. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Application attributes Table |URL| lists some of the firstand second-level application attributes that you might want to consider in your analysis of an suitability to be ported to the cloud. |ENDSENT|

|STARTSENT| Each cloud platform also has its own set of attributes that need to be mapped. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In considering the needs of any feature, the key drivers for applications that benefit from deployment to the cloud are those that meet these Are not mission critical Are not core business functions Do not have sensitive data to protect Tolerate high network latencies or low network bandwidth Are legacy applications with no particular competitive advantage Are based on industry standard technologies Do not need to be customized Are mature enough and understood well enough to be successfully ported to the cloud Cloud service attributes You then want to match up application attributes to these key cloud service Applications Core services Infrastructure Platform features Storage At the current stage in its development, it is impracticable to match the needs of an application to a set of cloud service providers. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Each provider has a unique solution, uses its own APIs, and provides unique services. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Therefore, each cloud provider needs separate developer skills, and integration between clouds would be a major chore. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Perhaps someday this situation may change as more standards are developed, but at the moment application developers need to match their application to the single best vendor. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Table |URL| lists some of the firstand second-level cloud features that you might want to consider in your analysis. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| You should map your critical application features to the features of a particular cloud platform to get the best match. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Chapter |NUMBER|: Moving Applications to the Cloud TABLE |URL| First Level Application Core Services Infrastructure Cloud Service Attributes Second Level First Level Second Level Accounting Database Event management Messaging Location service Relation management Web server Accounting Application support Auditing Data access Identity Index Query Transaction management Workflow Application support Availability (network) characteristics Load balancing Platform Features Storage Operating system support (platform) Resource pooling Scale up or out Site location Redundancy and replication Virtual machine types API Application support Deployment technology Development environment Language and locale Programming language support Testing API and commands Query Non-relational Relational Reliability Replication SQL support System abstraction The cloud turns physical systems into virtual systems. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Organizations choose to deploy systems to the cloud entirely when they can recreate the essential part of their process and eliminate infrastructure. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| As an example, consider a service that does medical imaging. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In the past, this service created patient scans and then rendered the image on a local computer. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| After the image was rendered, it was posted to the hospital LAN and made available to the people who read the scans. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| When the people reading the scans were outside the hospital, across the country, or around the world, those people would have to log into the hospital server via VPN to download the file. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Part Understanding Services and Applications The scanning service decided to eliminate infrastructure and streamline the process. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The service began its redeployment by first moving the stored images off the LAN and onto shared storage in the cloud. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This feature eliminated the need to maintain a great deal of managed storage locally. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| As the service began to outsource the reading of scans to other countries, it enabled a content delivery network feature that the cloud service provider had. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| CDN (Content Delivery Network) placed copies of recently used and created scans in locations that were closer to the readers and made the system faster. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The second stage in the redeployment was to eliminate the local processing associated with the scanning machines themselves. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Most of the time the scanning machine was operating, it was collecting data, and an economic analysis revealed that it was significantly cheaper to process the files in the cloud. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In the new system, shown in Figure |URL| the files are created locally and transmitted to the cloud. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Virtual machines are provisioned to process the scans. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The system leverages a message queuing server to create a steady stream of execution for the application server to process. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| At times of peak load, the system creates new machine instances to handle the load. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| As the application server completes the scan processing, it notifies the message queue, records the result in a database, and displays it on a Web page on a Web server, all of which are in the cloud. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This new system results in greater system efficiencies because the system is always processing at its optimum load. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The rendered scans are available from anywhere viewed inside a browser. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Also, because the system is scalable, the scanning service can expand to other sites and bring on new capacity to handle additional load. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| As the service loses sites, it can also release resources as well. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| When it is decided that the scans need to be converted into a different format, this can be done in a central location and need to be rolled out to the computers attached to individual scan systems. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Infrastructure, storage, and the queuing system all come together to eliminate a great deal of cost and operational complexity. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This is a pure cloud play. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Cloud bursting Many cloud deployments are hybrid Part of the application is on a local system, and part is in the cloud. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Often, this is the first stop on the path for many organizations migrating their applications to the cloud. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| There are many reasons why this is desirable, but one of the most common reasons is that the cloud can serve as excess capacity at times of high volume. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This type of hybrid has been called cloud bursting. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Examples of systems where there is high volume over short periods of time are transaction processing systems such as reservations systems. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In a reservation system, there is a certain low level of background transactions occurring at any time. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| At certain times, events trigger high demand. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| If the system builds infrastructure to accommodate peak demand, then that infrastructure is wasted. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Chapter |NUMBER|: Moving Applications to the Cloud FIGURE |URL| An application deployed entirely to the cloud LAN WAN Connection Proxy BLOB Storage Transaction Server Application Server Database Server Web Server WAN Connection LAN Part Understanding Services and Applications Most systems built to perform cloud bursting have a simple underlying clone the local system in the cloud. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Often, there may be little activity in the cloud portion of the system, but when the activity grows, the copy of the system in the cloud picks up the extra activity and, when necessary, provisions extra resources. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Figure |URL| shows a simple reservations system set up for cloud bursting. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| FIGURE |URL| An application that provides for transaction overflow in a reservation system is an example of cloud bursting. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Local Systems Proxy Web Server Database Server Transactions rflo Transactions Payment Gateway Cloud Platform Proxy Web Server Database Server Reservation systems often require that transactions not only are atomic, but that when there is a pool of items being reserved, the system is consistent. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| When a transaction enters the local branch in Figure |URL| and another transaction enters the cloud platform branch, they both reserve the same item. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| So there must be a transaction manager in this system to manage the pool. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This is shown as a dotted line between the two database servers, labeled “Synchronization.” The underlying mechanism is to perform record locking on a set of database records and when the transaction or a batch of transactions completes, the system performs a commit operation. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In most reservation systems, the actual transaction commitment is a small part of the traffic and processing. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Most of the traffic is generated on the Web site as users browse the content. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| So it makes sense in this scenario to recreate the company Web site and create additional load-balanced Web server instances as needed. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| You also can optimize that Web site for faster transactions with less Chapter |NUMBER|: Moving Applications to the Cloud customization. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| If your Web site relies on dynamic data driven content, you can speed up its operation by switching more of the content over to static content. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| need to synchronize changes between your on-premises and cloud-based Web servers in order to keep the information current. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The other step in a reservation system that is often a bottleneck is the payments gateway to credit card companies and financial institutions. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| It may make sense to move the payment portion completely to the cloud so that the processing of payments affect the other parts of the system. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Because the commitment of the payment either is effective or not, this portion of the process does not need to be tracked. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The fact that a virtual server is executing the payments and that the process is stateless has no impact in this point. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Eventually, developers will want to create composite applications that are built from the breed cloud services on multiple platforms. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This offers the benefit of redundant suppliers, access to additional services and features, more data sources, and a whole host of other advantages. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Cloud architectures offer enough advantages that over time large organizations will want to adopt them as a core architectural design. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| For example, in Figure |URL| an internal cloud provides high-speed transactional services on the LAN, an external cloud services other needs of users, and the company cloud is replicated to multiple sites. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Where services get located then depends upon factors such as cost, latency, and convenience. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| FIGURE |URL| For the users in large organizations, it is literally clouds everywhere in their future. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Directly accessed Internet Services Internal Services only Internet Services access through internal cloud Internet Services WAN Connection External Cloud External Cloud External Cloud WAN Connection Company LAN Internal Cloud Part Understanding Services and Applications Applications and Cloud APIs The nature of a cloud Cloud API will impact your ability to move an application to the cloud and affect the way many of your application features operate. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Cloud APIs are the Application Programming Interface to functions that exchange information in and with the cloud, request supported operations, and provide management and monitoring functions for applications running in the cloud. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| At this stage in cloud development, Amazon Web Cloud API dominates the conversation, but that is probably subject to change. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Each cloud vendor has its own specific API; most are exposed as REST, a few are exposed as SOAP, or some are both. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Each API provides specific calls required by that infrastructure and service. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Most importantly, the cloud API contains the authentication and authorization mechanisms needed to access cloud services. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| When a vendor like Google allows other cloud application providers to access its ID mechanism (as is the case now), there is the same flexibility in using those services on other platforms. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Although efforts are underway to create more standardized cloud APIs, the situation limits the portability of any application developed for the cloud. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The two cross-platform API initiatives are the Simple Cloud API (|URL| and the work arising out of the Cloud Computing Interoperability Forum (|URL| Several cross-platform cloud API projects are underway, including the Design Cloud, Deltacloud, jclouds, and libcloud APIs. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| These cross-platform APIs are based on generalizing the major cloud vendors APIs. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Each layer of a cloud application has its own specific API as well. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| So at the infrastructure level in addition to AWS you have the All these present the developer with their own APIs. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Individual services such as Windows Azure SQL, Flickr, and Google Maps present a service cloud API. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| If your application is developed in a platform such as Facebook, LinkedIn, or the Salesforce Force APIs, each platform has its own specific application API. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The point is that the decision to move an application to the cloud rapidly funnels you into a specific solution that provides a measure of vendor lock-in that, depending upon the nature of your application, can be anywhere from very easy to nearly impossible to port to any other cloud technology. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This may not always be so, but it currently is true and it should give a developer some moments to pause. |ENDSENT|

|STARTSENT| Cloud computing supports some application features better than others. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| To determine whether your application will port successfully, you should perform a functionality mapping exercise. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This process involves determining the critical application features and then matching them to the cloud offering to see if those features can be supported. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Examples of applications that were ported were presented. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| One application virtualized the entire application in the cloud and presented users with a browser-based service. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The second scenario, called cloud bursting, is an overflow solution that clones the application to the cloud and directs traffic to the cloud during times of high traffic. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The role of a cloud specific API and the impact that it has on porting an application was also considered. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This aspect of a migration given enough thought beforehand and can cause problems later on should you wish to move to other solutions. |ENDSENT|

|STARTSENT| Working with Cloud-Based Storage The world is creating massive amounts of data. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A large percentage of that data either is already stored in the cloud, will be stored in the cloud, or will pass through the cloud during the lifecycle. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Cloud storage systems are among the most successful cloud computing applications in use today. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This chapter surveys the area of cloud storage systems, categorizes the different cloud storage system types, discusses filesharing and backup software and systems, and describes the methods being used to get cloud storage systems to interoperate. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Cloud storage can be either unmanaged or managed. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Unmanaged storage is presented to a user as if it is a disk drive. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The user has little control over the nature of how the disk is used. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Most user-oriented software such as file-sharing and backup consume unmanaged cloud storage. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Applications using unmanaged cloud storage are Software as a Service (SaaS) Web services. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Managed storage involves the provisioning of raw virtualized disk and the use of that disk to support applications that use cloud-based storage. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Storage options involved in formatting, partitioning, replicating data, and other options are available for managed storage. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Applications using managed cloud storage are Infrastructure as a Service (IaaS) Web services. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Developing cloud storage interoperability standards are described in this chapter, notably those from the Storage Networking Industry Association (SNIA) and the Open Grid Foundation (OGF). |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The Cloud Data Management IN THIS CHAPTER Drowning in a sea of data; saved by the cloud Categorizing cloud storage system types Examining file hosting and backing up to the cloud Comparing unmanaged and managed cloud storage Developing protocols for cloud storage interoperability Part Understanding Services and Applications Interface (CDMI) interoperability storage object protocol is described. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This interface can store data objects, discover stored data objects, and supply these data objects to subscribing applications. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The Open Cloud Computing Interface (OCCI) is another storage data interchange interface for stored data objects. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The two protocols interoperate with one another. |ENDSENT|
