|STARTSENT| Total Digital Universe Touched by Cloud Cloud Services Cloud storage definition Think of cloud storage as storage accessed by a Web service API. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The characteristics that separate cloud storage include network access most often through a browser, on-demand provisioning, user control, and most often adherence to open standards so that cloud storage may be operatingsystem-neutral and These characteristics, taken as a whole define an offering that is best described as an Infrastructure as a Service model. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| However, most users do not provision storage under IaaS systems such as Amazon (described in Chapter |NUMBER|). |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Instead, most users interact with cloud storage using backup, synchronization, archiving, staging, caching, or some other sort of software. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The addition of a software package on top of a cloud storage volume makes most cloud storage offerings conform to a Software as a Service model. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Storage devices may be broadly categorized as either block storage devices or file storage devices. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A block storage device exposes its storage to clients as Raw storage that can be partitioned to create volumes. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| It is up to the operating system to create and manage the file system; from the standpoint of the storage device, data is transferred in blocks. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The alternative type of storage is a file server, most often in the form of a Network Attached Storage (NAS) device. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| NAS exposes its storage to clients in the form of files, maintaining its own file system. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Block storage devices offer faster data transfers, but impose additional overhead on clients. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| File-oriented storage devices are generally slower (with the exception of large file-streaming applications), but require less overhead from attached clients. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Cloud storage devices can be either block or file storage devices. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Part Understanding Services and Applications Provisioning Cloud Storage Cloud storage may be broadly categorized into two major classes of unmanaged and managed storage. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In unmanaged storage, the storage service provider makes storage capacity available to users, but defines the nature of the storage, how it may be used, and by what applications. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The options a user has to manage this category of storage are severely limited. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| However, unmanaged storage is reliable, relatively cheap to use, and particularly easy to work with. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Most of the userbased applications that work with cloud storage are of this type. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Managed cloud storage is mainly meant for developers and to support applications built using Web services. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Managed cloud storage is provisioned and provided as a raw disk. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| It is up to the user to partition and format the disk, attach or mount the disk, and make the storage assets available to applications and other users. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The sections that follow describe these two storage types and their uses in more detail. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Unmanaged cloud storage With the development of high-capacity disk storage starting in the midto a new class of service provider appeared called a Storage Service Provider (SSP). |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Fueled by venture capital and the |URL| boom, dozens of companies created datacenters around the world with the intent of doing for online storage what Internet service providers (ISP) did for communications. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| With so much excess capacity in place, companies with names like iDrive (now at |URL| FreeDrive (|URL| MyVirtualDrive (defunct), OmniDrive (gonzo), XDrive (kaput), and others were formed to offer file-hosting services in the form of unmanaged cloud storage. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| It is unmanaged storage in the sense that the storage is preconfigured for you, you format as you like, nor can you install your own file system, or change drive properties such as compression or encryption. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Storage was offered to users by these file-hosting services as fixed online volumes. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| These volumes were first accessible using FTP, then from a utility, and then from within a browser. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Often the service offered a certain capacity for free, with the opportunity to purchase more online storage as needed. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| FreeDrive is an example of an unmanaged storage utility set up to do automated backups, a class of Web services that is discussed in the section “Exploring Cloud Backup Solutions” later in this chapter. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Three factors led to the demise of many of the early SSPs and to many hosted file The |URL| bust in |NUMBER| The inability of file-hosting companies to successfully monetize online storage The continued commoditization of large disk drives, which led to free online storage from large vendors such as Google Chapter |NUMBER|: Working with Cloud-Based Storage These SSPs and file-hosting services were ahead of their time, but in many acquisitions and offspring legacy remains. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The simplest of these unmanaged cloud storage services falls into the category of a file transfer utility. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| You can upload files to the service where that file is stored (for a while) and made available to you for downloading from another location. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Some of these services allow the transfer of only a single file. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| File transfer services may be shared by other users you allow, and the files that are uploaded may be discoverable for some services. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| That is, you can query the system for a file or information that meets the criteria you set. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The service FreeDrive is storage that allows Facebook users to view the content of others. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Dropbox, shown in Figure |URL| is an example of a file transfer utility. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| You install the Dropbox utility on your system and create an account, and the Dropbox folder appears. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Dropbox also installs a System Tray icon in Windows for you. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| You can then drag and drop files and folders to your Dropbox. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| When a remote user logs into a Dropbox account, he installs the Dropbox folder for that account on his system, creating what is in effect a shared folder over the Web. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| FIGURE |URL| Dropbox is a file transfer utility that creates a shared folder metaphor using a Web service. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Part Understanding Services and Applications In an unmanaged cloud storage service, disk space is made available to users as a sized partition. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| That is, the remote storage appears as a mapped drive inside a folder like My Computer. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Filehosting services allow the user to READ and WRITE to the drive and, in some cases, share the drive with other users, and often little more. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| As unmanaged storage offerings progressed in sophistication, they began to offer value-added software services such as folder synchronization and backup. |ENDSENT|

|STARTSENT| Part Understanding Services and Applications Managed cloud storage The most basic service that online storage can serve is to provide disk space on demand. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In the previous section, you saw examples of services where the service provider prepares and conditions the disk space for use by the user, provides the applications that the user can use with that disk space, and assigns disk space to the user with a persistent connection between the two. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The user may be able to purchase additional space, but often that requires action by the service provider to provision the storage prior to use. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| That type of storage is considered unmanaged cloud storage because the user proactively manage his storage. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The second class of cloud storage is what I call managed cloud storage. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| You saw an example of a managed cloud storage system in Chapter |NUMBER| where Simple Storage System was described. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In a managed cloud storage system, the user provisions storage on demand and pays for the storage using a model. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The system presents what appears to the user to be a raw disk that the user must partition and format. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This type of system is meant to support virtual cloud computing as the virtualized storage component of that system. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Note SNIA (Storage Networking Industry Association; |URL| has coined the term Data Storage as a Service (DaaS) to describe the delivery of storage on demand to clients over a distributed system. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Others have called these types of system services Storage as a Service (STaaS). |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| n Managed cloud storage providers include the |URL| Simple Storage Service |URL| This hosting service is described in Chapter |NUMBER|. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Atmos, you can create your own cloud storage system or leverage a public cloud service with Atmos online. |ENDSENT|

|STARTSENT| It will share authentication and data sharing platforms. |ENDSENT|

|STARTSENT| Creating cloud storage systems The Internet was designed to be a fault-tolerant network that could survive a nuclear attack. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Paths between endpoints are redundant, message transfer is packetized, and dropped or lost packets can be retransmitted and travel different paths. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Networks are redundant, name servers are redundant, and overall the system is highly fault tolerant. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| These features help make cloud-based storage systems highly reliable, particularly when multiple copies of data are stored on multiple servers and in multiple locations. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Failover can involve a system simply changing the pointers to the stored location. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In Chapter |NUMBER| you saw how Amazon Web Services (AWS) adds redundancy to its IaaS systems by allowing virtual machine instances and storage containers (bucket) to be created in any one of its four datacenters or regions. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| AWS essentially lets you create your own cloud storage, provided you distribute your provisioned storage appropriately on system. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| AWS created “Availability Zones” within regions, which are sets of systems that are isolated from one another. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In theory, instances in different availability zones fail at the same time. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In practice, entire regions can be affected, and storage and system redundancy needs to be established on a multi-regional basis. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| AWS can perform load balancing on multiple instances and can perform failover from one geographical location to another, but this is an additional service that you must purchase. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The important point about redundancy is that for it to be effective, it has to be implemented at the highest architectural level. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Companies wishing to aggregate storage assets into cloud storage systems can use an enterprise software product like StorageGRID. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This storage virtualization software from Bycast (now a part of NetApp; |URL| creates a virtualization layer that pools storage from different storage devices into a single management system. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| You can potentially pool petabytes of data storage, use different storage system types, and transport protocols even over geographically dispersed locations. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Figure |URL| shows how SystemGRID virtualizes storage into storage clouds. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| StorageGRID can manage data from CIFS and NFS file systems over HTTP networks. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Data can be replicated, migrated to different locations, and failed over upon demand. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The degree of data replication can be set by policy, and when storage in the pool fails, StorageGRID can failover to other copies of the data on redundant systems. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| StorageGRID can enforce policies and create a tiered storage system. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Part Understanding Services and Applications FIGURE |URL| StorageGRID allows you to create fault-tolerant cloud storage systems by creating a virtualization layer between storage assets and application servers. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Application Application Application CIFSCIFS CIFS NFSNFS NFS HTTPHTTP HTTP Bycast StorageGRID virtualization layer SANs SCSI SATA SATA Tape Main Site Other Backup Site Virtual storage containers In traditional pooled storage deployments, storage partitions can be assigned and provide a device label called a Logical Unit Number (LUN). |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A LUN is a logical unit that serves as the target for storage operations, such as the SCSI READs and WRITEs (PUTs and GETs). |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The two main protocols used to build large disk pools, particularly in the form of Storage Area Networks (SANs), Fibre Channel and iSCSI both use LUNs to define a storage volume that appears to a connected computer as a device. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Unused LUNs are the equivalent of a raw disk from which one or more volumes may be created. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Traditionally, pooled online storage assigns a LUN and then uses an authorization process called LUN masking to limit which connected computers (or hosts) can see which LUNs. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| LUN masking as strong a security feature as the direct identification of a physical Host Bus Adapters (HBAs), Chapter |NUMBER|: Working with Cloud-Based Storage which are the storage networking equivalent of NICs (Network Interface Cards). |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| LUN addresses can have their unique addresses spoofed more easily than a hardware address can. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| However, LUNs do protect against a server being able to write to a disk to which it have access. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Storage partitioning in large storage deployments also may be achieved using SAN zoning, as well as a partitioning disk based on physical location. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| When online storage is converted for use in a cloud storage system, none of these partitioning methods allows for easy, storage assignment and the high disk utilization rates that are required in a multi-tenancy storage system. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Delivering effective cloud storage solutions requires the use of a virtual storage container, which allows a tenant to perform storage operations on the virtual storage container consistent with the capabilities of the underlying storage system. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Different storage vendors call their virtual storage containers by different names, but all use this entity as a construct to create high-performance cloud storage systems. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| LUNs, files, and other objects are then created within the virtual storage container. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Figure |URL| shows a model for a virtual storage container, which defines a cloud storage domain. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This model, based on the SNIA model but modified somewhat, includes the interface operations that are needed to use that domain. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| When a tenant is granted access to a virtual storage container, he performs standard disk operations such as partitioning, formatting, file system modifications, and CRUD (Create, Read, Update, and Delete) operations as desired. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Data stored in a virtual storage container may be stored in chunks or buckets as the Amazon Simple Storage Service (Amazon does, or it may be stored in containers that are in a hierarchical relationship typical of most file systems. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The main requirement is that however cloud storage data is organized that data and its associated metadata may be discoverable. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Making cloud storage data discoverable on a network using HTTP or some other protocol requires that objects be assigned a unique identifier such as a URI (Uniform Resource Identifier) and that the relationship between objects and their metadata be specified. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In the section “Developing Cloud System Interoperability,” I describe the OCCI protocol for discovering and retrieving objects from a cloud. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Because virtual storage containers must be secured, these objects must carry a set of security attributes that protect a data from snooping, denial of service attacks, spoofing, inappropriate deletion, or unauthorized discovery. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The main mechanism for securing one virtual storage container from another is to assign an IP address to the virtual storage container and then bind that container to a separate VLAN connecting storage to the tenant (host). |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Traffic flowing over the VLAN is encrypted, and the tenant is carefully authenticated by the system. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Usually, data sent over the VLAN is compressed to improve data throughput over a WAN connection. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Different cloud storage vendors may implement their own proprietary management interfaces to connect distributed hosts or tenants to their provisioned storage in the cloud and to provide for security services. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| One open interface standard is the Storage Networking Industry Cloud Data Management Interface (CDMI) described later in this chapter. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Part Understanding Services and Applications FIGURE |URL| A cloud storage domain model and the interface commands needed to access those elements User Application Service Service Service Requirements S Requirements S Requirements Metadata Data Reqs Storage System Pointer Table (URLs) Stored Data Chapter |NUMBER|: Working with Cloud-Based Storage In evaluating cloud storage solutions, these factors are deemed to be important Client self-service Strong management capabilities Performance characteristics such as throughput Appropriate block-based storage protocol support such as iSCSI or FC SAN, or file-based storage protocol support such as NFS or CIFS to support your systems Seamless maintenance and upgrades In addition to assigning security-provisioned cloud storage to a client or service requester, a cloud storage service provider must be able to deliver a measured level of service as captured by its stated Service Level Agreement (SLA). |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| An SLA might specify that a particular Quality of Service (QoS) for a virtual storage container may be measured in terms of the per second or IOPS that may be provided, as well as the reliability and availability of the service. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| QoS levels may be applied to different services against a single virtual storage container or a single service applied to the multiple assigned storage containers. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In situations where multiple virtual storage containers are assigned to a client, a mechanism would need to be provided to federate the different containers into a consolidated management console. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| One unique characteristic of cloud-based storage solutions is that they permit rapid scaling, both in terms of performance and storage capacity. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| To provide for scaling, a virtual storage container must be easily migrated from one storage system to another. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| To increase the capacity of a storage provision, it is necessary to provide the capability to scale up or scale out across storage systems. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| To scale up, the service must allow for more disks and more spindles to be provisioned. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| To scale out, the service must allow for stored data to span additional storage systems. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Cloud storage systems that successfully scale their provisioned storage for clients often allow for the multiple storage systems to be geographically dispersed and often provide load-balancing services across different storage instances. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Exploring Cloud Backup Solutions Cloud storage is uniquely positioned to serve as a last line of defense in a strong backup routine, and backing up to the cloud is one of the most successful applications of cloud computing. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This area is a cornucopia of solutions, many inexpensive and feature rich. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Backup types Backups may be categorized as belonging to one of the following Full system or image An image backup creates a complete copy of a volume, including all system files, the boot record, and any other data contained on the disk. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| To create an image backup of an active system, you may need to stop all applications (quiesce the system). |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| An image backup allows a system to do what is referred to as a bare metal restore. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Ghost is an example of software that supplies this type of backup. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Part Understanding Services and Applications Point-in-time (PIT) backups or The data is backed up, and then every so often changes are amended to the backup creating what is referred to as an incremental backup. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This type of backup lets you restore your data to a point in time and saves multiple copies of any file that has been changed. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| At least |NUMBER| to |NUMBER| copies of previous versions of files should be saved. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The first backup is quite slow over an Internet connection, but the incremental backup can be relatively fast. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| For example, software such as Carbonite may take several days to backup a system, but minutes to create the snapshot. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Note The amount of time needed to backup a system is referred to as its backup window. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| n Differential and incremental A differential backup is related to an incremental backup, but with some subtle differences in the way the archive bit is handled. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| During an incremental backup, any changed files are copied to the backup media and their archive attribute is cleared by the incremental backup. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In a differential backup, all of the changed files since the last full backup are copied by the backup software, which requires that the software leave the archive bit set to ON for any differential backup, as only a full backup can clear all archive bit. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| An archive bit is used by backup software to specify whether a file should be backed up or not. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The bit is set on for backup and cleared when backup has copied the file. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In a sense, an archive bit is a directive to the software. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The archive bit comes into play in backup software in the sense that an incremental backup solution must examine the full backup data and then analyze all subsequent increments to find the latest In a differential backup, the backup software can obtain the backup from the last full backup and the last incremental backup alone. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Files in intervening incremental backups may be taken as temporary or scratch versions. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| While incremental backups are faster and more efficient from a storage perspective, they are also less fault tolerant. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Reverse Delta A reverse delta backup creates a full backup first and then periodically synchronizes the full copy with the live version. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The older versions of files that have been changed are archived so that a historical record of the backup exists. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Among the software that uses this system is Time Machine and the RDIFF-BACKUP utility. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Continuous Data Protection (CDP) or The goal of this type of backup system is to create a cloned copy of your current data or drive. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A cloud storage system contains a certain built-in latency, so unless the original data set is quiescent, the mirror lags behind the original in concurrency. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Open file Some applications such as database systems and messaging systems are mission critical and cannot be shut down before being backed up. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| An open file backup analyzes the transactions that are in progress, compares them to the at the start of the backup and the at the end of the backup, and creates a backup that represents a complete file as it would exist at the time the backup started after all the transactions have been processed. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This is a difficult proposition, and open file backup systems are expensive and highly customized to a particular application such as SQL Server or Exchange. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Chapter |NUMBER|: Working with Cloud-Based Storage |NUMBER|-|NUMBER|-|NUMBER| Backup Rule Peter |NUMBER|-|NUMBER|-|NUMBER| Rule for data protection is a good one to follow. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Krogh is a professional photographer, a member of the American Society of Media Photographers, and a consultant in the area of data storage and archiving. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| One of his clients is the Library of Congress, where data archival is a missioncritical task. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| As Krogh states on the site |URL| (|URL| a simple but effective backup scenario includes the following |NUMBER|. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Retain three copies of any original and two backups. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Files must be on two different media types (such as hard drives and optical media) to protect against different types of hazards. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| One copy must be stored offsite (or at least online). |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| If you have a local version of a file, then a version of that file stored in the cloud conforms to all three of the |NUMBER|-|NUMBER|-|NUMBER| backup rules. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Data The term archiving is used to specify the migration of data that is no longer in use to secondary or tertiary long-term data storage for retention. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| An archive is useful for legal compliance or to provide a long-term historical record. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Note Data archives are often confused with backups, but the two operations are quite different. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A backup creates a copy of the data, whereas an archive removes older information that is no longer operational and saves it for long-term storage. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| You restore your current data set from an archive. |ENDSENT|

|STARTSENT| Lossless data compression to improve throughput. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A related feature called differential compression transfers only binary data that has changed since the last backup. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Automated, scheduled backups. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Fast backup (snapshots) after full online backup, with |NUMBER| to |NUMBER| historical versions of a file retained. |ENDSENT|

|STARTSENT| Logging and reporting of operations. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Open file backups of mission-critical transactional systems such as enterprise databases or applications. |ENDSENT|

|STARTSENT| Cloud attached backup The backup solutions described have been clientor software-based solutions that are useful for an individual desktop or server. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| However, some interesting hardware-based solutions are available for backing up your systems to cloud-based storage. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| referred to as Cloud Attached Storage, which is meant for the Small and Medium Business (SMB) market, branch offices, and the Small Office Home Office (SOHO) market. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The CTERA Cloud Attached Storage backup server has the attributes of a NAS (Network Attached Storage), with the added feature that after you set up which systems you want to back up, create user accounts, and set the backup options through a browser interface, the system runs automated backup copying and synchronizing of your data with cloud storage. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Backed up data may be shared between users. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Figure |URL| shows how the CTERA Cloud Attached Storage Device is deployed in practice. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| CTERA cloud backup provides a solution that optimizes the backup based on bandwidth availability. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| It performs incremental backups from the server, compressing and encrypting the data that is transmitted to cloud storage servers where de-duplication is performed. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The CTERA server performs the backups of clients without requiring any client-based software. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Clients have browser-based access to the backups or can locally access files using “Virtual Cloud Drive” network drive. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Snapshots are captured on the CTERA file system, which is based on the open source file system. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Part Understanding Services and Applications FIGURE |URL| cloud-attached storage network backup scenario Cloud Storage Router Online Backup Sharing Synchronization CTERA Cloud Attached Storage Device The development of systems on a chip has enabled CTERA to create a scaled-down version of the CTERA server called the CTERA CloudPlug for the SOHO market. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This palm-sized low-power device converts a drive and your Ethernet network and turns the hard drive into a NAS server. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| CloudPlug performs backup and synchronization services and then performs automated or on-demand backups and snapshots of your systems. |ENDSENT|

|STARTSENT| Cloud Storage Interoperability Large network storage deployments tend to get populated by vendors who provide unique functionality for their systems by creating proprietary APIs for the storage hardware that they sell. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This Chapter |NUMBER|: Working with Cloud-Based Storage problem exists for online network storage, Storage Area Networks (SANs), and to an even greater extent for cloud storage systems. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Storage vendors have encouraged adoption of their proprietary APIs by making them “open,” but cloud system vendors have not responded by making any single API an industry standard. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The development of Open Source APIs from the Open Source community has only added more storage APIs to the mix. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Cloud Data Management Interface (CDMI) An example of an open cloud storage management standard is the Storage Networking Industry (SNIA; |URL| Cloud Data Management Interface (CDMI). |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| CDMI works with the storage domain model shown in Figure |URL| to allow for interoperation between different cloud systems, whether on public, private, or hybrid cloud systems. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| CDMI includes commands that allow applications to access cloud storage and create, retrieve, update, and delete data objects; provides for data object discovery; enables storage data systems to communicate with one another; and provides for security using standard storage protocols, monitoring and billing, and authentication methods. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| CDMI uses the same authorization and authentication mechanism as NFS (Network File System) does. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In the Cloud Data Management Interface (CDMI), the storage space is partitioned into units called containers. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A container stores a set of data in it and serves as the named object upon which data service operations are performed. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The CDMI data object can manage CDMI containers, as well as containers that are accessible in cloud storage through other supported protocols. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Figure |URL| shows the SNIA cloud storage management model. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In the figure, XAM stands for the eXtensible Access Method, a storage API developed by SNIA for accessing content on storage devices. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| VIM stands for Vendor Interface Modules, which is an interface that converts XAM requests into native commands that are supported by the storage hardware operating systems. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| CDMI can access objects stored in the cloud by using standard HTTP command and the REST (Representational State Transfer) protocol to manipulate those objects. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| CDMI also can discover objects and can export and manage those exported objects as part of a storage space called a container. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| CDMI provides an interface through which applications can gain access to the storage objects in a container over the Web. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Other features of CDMI are access controls, usage accounting, and the ability to advertise containers so that applications see these containers as if they are volumes (LUNs with a certain size). |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| CDMI uses metadata for HTTP, system, user, and storage media attributes accessing them through a standard interface using a schema that is known as the Resource Oriented Architecture (ROA). |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In this architecture, every resource is identified by a standardized URI (Uniform Resource Identifier) that may be translated into both hypertext (HTTP) and other forms. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| CDMI uses the SNIA eXtensible Access Method (XAM) to discover and access metadata associated with each data object. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Metadata is stored not only for data objects, but for data containers so that any data placed into a container assumes the metadata associated with that container. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Should there be conflicting metadata at different levels of the hierarchy (container, object, and so on), the most granular level metadata attribute takes precedence. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Part Understanding Services and Applications FIGURE |URL| CDMI allows data in cloud storage to be managed from a variety of resources. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Clients Using Data Storage Interface Block Storage Client Filesystem Client Client Object Storage XAM Client Database Client POSIX Filesystems POSIX Filesystems POSIX Filesystems (NFS, CIFS, WebDAV) (NFS, CIFS, WebDAV) (NFS, CIFS, WebDAV) CDMI CDMI CDMI iSCSI LUNs iSCSI LUNs iSCSI LUNs Other Targets Other Targets Other Targets XAM VIM for CSI CDMI CDMI CDMI APIsAPIs APIs Hard Data Hard Data Container Container Soft Data Soft Data Container Container Table Table Data Cloud Storage Data Storage Management Client On Demand Resource Access On Demand Resource Access On Demand Resource Access CDMI CDMI CDMI Clients Managing Storage CDMI Data Services Information Services Storage Services “Cloud Storage for Cloud Computing” |DATE|, |URL| |URL| In CDMI, resources are identified as nouns, which have attributes in the form of key-value pairs, upon which actions in the form of verbs may be performed. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Standard actions include the standard CRUD Create, Retrieve, Update, and Delete; which translates into the standard HTTP action verbs POST, GET, PUT, and DELETE. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Additionally, the HEAD and OPTIONS verbs provide a wrapper for metadata and operational instructions. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A typical action might be a PUT or GET operation, as PUT |URL| GET |URL| Chapter |NUMBER|: Working with Cloud-Based Storage The domain |URL| would be the service provider, myfile is the instance, and compute is the folder containing the file. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In a PUT operation, the container (store) is created if it exist previously. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The metadata pair MIME is required in a PUT; other metadata VALUE pairs are optional in a PUT. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A variety of pairs describing object attributes in CDMI is defined by the standard. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Open Cloud Computing Interface (OCCI) SNIA and the Open Grid Forum (OGF; |URL| have created a joint working group to create the Open Cloud Computing Interface (OCCI), an open standard API for cloud computing infrastructure systems. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| OCCI is meant to span the different standards and allow for system interoperability. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Note To view the Cloud Standards Wiki with information about all the different standards groups working in this area of technology, go |URL| This page contains links to the work of groups in cloud storage, virtual machines, protocols, and more. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| n The OCCI interface standard is based on the Resource Oriented Architecture (ROA) and uses the URI definition for OCCI that was previously defined by Cloud Data Management Interface (CDMI) that OCCI interoperates with CDMI. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Associations between resources appear in the HTTP header in the Atom Publishing Protocol (AtomPub or APP) that transfers the Atom Syndication Format (XML) used for XML Web news feeds. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The OCCI API maps to other formats such as Pub, JSON, and Plain Text. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| OCCI specifies, but does not mandate, what is called a service life cycle. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In a service life cycle, a client (service requestor) instantiates or invokes a new application and through OCCI commands provisions its storage resources, manages the use, and then manages the destruction and the release of its cloud storage. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Cloud storage devices can be either a block or file system storage device, and in that regard they are no different than online network storage devices or even local storage. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| It is the ability to provide storage on a demand basis and pay as you go that is the key differentiator for cloud storage. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The ability to provide storage on demand from a storage pool is referred to as thin provisioning, a term that also applies to compute resources such as virtual machines. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Management of cloud storage is performed by management systems through a data storage interface. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| refers to a management console that on the storage network, but is most often on an Ethernet network inside a browser. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| From the management console, additional data services such as cloning, compression, de-duplication, and snapshots may be invoked. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| As previously mentioned, CDMI and OCCI are meant to interoperate, and CDMI containers can be accessed through a data path and over other protocols. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A CDMI container can be exported and then used as a virtual disk by Virtual Machines in the cloud. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The cloud infrastructure management console can be used to attach exported CDMI containers to the Virtual Machine that is desired. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| CDMI exports containers so the information that is obtained from the OCCI interface is part of the exported container. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Part Understanding Services and Applications OCCI also can create containers that are interoperable with CDMI containers. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| These export operations can be initiated from either the OCCI or CDMI interfaces, with similar results. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| However, there are syntactical differences between using either interface as the export starting point. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In Figure |URL| CDMI and OCCI are shown interoperating with cloud resources of different types. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| FIGURE |URL| CDMI and OCCI interoperating in an integrated cloud system Compute Resources Virtual Machine Manager VM VM VM iSCSI NFS NFS NFS iSCSI WebDAV Filesystems OCCI OCI API OCI API OCCI API Cloud Compute Infrastructure Client CDMI API CDMI API CDMI API CDMI Private Cloud SAN iSCSI NFS WebDAV CDMI Exports Data Object Data Object Data Object Data Object Data Object Data Storage Resources “Cloud Storage for Cloud Computing” |DATE|, |URL| |URL| Chapter |NUMBER|: Working with Cloud-Based Storage Summary In this chapter, you learned about the nature of stored digital data and the role that cloud storage will play in the future in storing and processing data. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Cloud storage is classified as either unmanaged or managed storage. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Most user applications work with unmanaged storage. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The two major classes of cloud-based storage applications described in this chapter were file sharing and backup utilities. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Managed storage is cloud storage that you provision for Web services or applications using cloud storage that you are developing. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Managed storage requires you to prepare the disk and manage its use. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| All cloud storage vendors partition storage on the basis of a virtual storage container. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A model describing the virtual storage container is described. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Efforts to make cloud storage systems interoperate, particularly the CDMI and OCCI protocols, were described. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In Chapter |NUMBER| “Working with Productivity Software,” I consider desktop applications that replace office suite applications. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| These applications have the potential to displace a major portion of their commercial shrink-wrapped software counterparts over time, and while not as feature-filled as commercial software, they are surprisingly good. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The chapter discusses the state of the art in this area and makes some predictions of what to expect over time. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Working with Productivity Software IN THIS CHAPTER Defining productivity software Assessing the benefits and drawbacks of online applications Learning about office suites Knowing the features of the most important cloud-based office suites Office productivity software is one of the most important categories of applications in use today. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A vast majority of desktop computers have the applications that comprise office suites installed on their systems. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Word processors, spreadsheets, presentation programs, and other programs that are typically bundled together by vendors such as Apple, Microsoft, Corel, IBM Lotus, and others in their office suites are the most heavily used applications, with the exception perhaps of your browser. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| It is no accident, therefore, that cloud software developers have targeted productivity software as the one area where cloud computing can have impact. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The cloud offers a variety of benefits that make productivity software accessed over this medium attractive. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Those benefits include lower software costs, ubiquitous and nearly universal access, ease of sharing and collaboration, and a standards-based approach that enables cross-platform capabilities. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| These benefits must be weighed against the risks of requiring an Internet connection, storing sensitive data in the cloud, and the generally smaller feature sets that online productivity applications have than their desktop counterparts. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In this chapter, you learn about some of the major online office suites from vendors such as Adobe, Glide, Google, Microsoft, ThinkFree, and Zoho. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Some of these sites offer a large array of tools and have been established since the Others such as |URL| and Microsoft Live Office and their Office Web Apps are relatively new and are being developed rapidly. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Part Understanding Services and Applications Using Productivity Applications Everyone thinks he knows what the term “productivity software” It means Microsoft Office. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In theory, anything you do on the computer that is faster and more productive than you could do any other way can be termed productivity software. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| So, sorry; Instant Messaging, e-mail, and killing aliens in a video game probably qualify. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A definition for productivity software is elusive, but try searching the term online and see what I mean. |ENDSENT|

|STARTSENT| n For the sake of this chapter, therefore, let me define productivity User-facing software that creates work product in the form of documents or files If you want to define cloud-based productivity software, add the phrase “using resources accessed over a WAN” (Wide Area Network) to the end of that phrase. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Chapter |NUMBER|: Working with Productivity Software User-facing inexorable migration from a personal computer to the cloud has been well underway for the past five or six years. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The good reasons for this trend and some reasons that inhibit this migration are the subject of this chapter. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Software is to change and substitution. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The inclusion of many of the modules in the original office suites beyond their word processors and spreadsheets was as much a matter of serendipity as it was due to planning. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In only a few instances, a suite was completely written by its developers. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| By contrast, most of the productivity suites and applications that are cloud-based are the work of their original developers and represent the desire to displace desktop applications. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Characteristics of productivity software The range of productivity applications is great. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| So if it possible to define productivity software based on application type, at least we know the characteristics of productivity software. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Those characteristics apply to online and to locally based applications. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Tip This chapter does not describe many applications that are available online as standalone applications. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Numerous programs, such as to-do lists, calendars, photo editors, and so forth, are often online software, but would require more space to describe than is available here. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| To learn more about these other programs, I refer you to survey books that cover these types of programs from a functional category basis. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| n To be included in the category of productivity software, an application must have the following User-centric and Productivity software is used daily. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Static Productivity software offers limited customization. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| When a user sits down to use a productivity software package, the interface and command set should be roughly the same regardless of where and when the applications are used. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Ease of Productivity software must follow a set of defined interface guidelines that make it easy for even inexperienced users to follow. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Standards for data Productivity software should save data in file formats that are standardized, even if they are based on a format. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Some of the options for saving data or for importing data should be through standardized data interchange formats. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Examples of proprietary formats are DOC or PDF format; two interchange formats might be the word processing RTF (Rich Text Format) or the CSV (Comma Separated Values) formats. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Modular Productivity application suites should enable a functionality that allows one application to interact with another. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Interactivity can occur through operating system functionality such as the Clipboard or or by using a mechanism that is proprietary to the application suite itself. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Inter Applications Communications IAC is the ability of one application to use the services of another to do productivity work. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The level of IAC in a productivity suite may be seen to be a measure of the sophistication. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| An example of IAC in action is when you create an object like a drawing in a word processor and the drawing tool becomes available to work on that object while it is in use. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Part Understanding Services and Applications Inter-Applications Communication and Cloud Computing The development of systems to enable and encourage IAC reads like the history of networked application development itself. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| To enable IAC functionality over the years, we have seen these Microsoft’s Common Object Model (COM) and Distributed Common Object Model (DCOM) and the Framework; the Object Management Common Object Request Broker Architecture (CORBA); the inter-process communication (IPC) protocol Network Computing System (originally from Apollo Computer), Remote Procedure Calls (RPC); the Open Database Connectivity (ODBC) database drivers; and many others. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The applications that are described in this chapter rely on Service Oriented Architectures (SOA) to implement IAC using SOAP over HTTP, Web Services Flow Language (WSFL), the XML Remote Procedure Call XML-RPC, or a number of other Web service protocols that were discussed in Chapter |NUMBER|. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Thus, you can see that cloud computing enablement is simply a natural progression of trends that have a long history in the computer industry. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Online Office Systems Online office systems are growing increasingly popular and are displacing shrink-wrapped office software for many users. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Although the online systems have used traditional office products as their model, the nature of the Web and the services it provides makes some features hard to copy and other features that exist locally possible on the Web. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In this section, I look at why online office suites are becoming popular and what features hinder their adoption. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| These are benefits of using a cloud computing office Generally lower costs for users Platform independence because the software runs inside a browser and is universally available Reduced maintenance costs because of fewer hardware requirements Centralized software patches and updates, whereby users have access to the latest version of the software Easier document sharing due to standard formats, and often easier document sharing for group collaboration Using cloud-based productivity applications also has some An Internet connection is required to access your documents. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Some cloud-based applications now offer what is called an “off-line” mode so you can work on documents on your local system when an Internet connection is not available. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Performance can be slow, particularly when you have a slow Internet connection. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Chapter |NUMBER|: Working with Productivity Software Online productivity applications generally have fewer features than their shrink-wrapped competitors. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Documents stored in the cloud may not be secure and are certainly not under a full control. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Data in the cloud can be lost and must be managed and backed up. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Documents created with desktop applications may not be fully compatible with cloud-based applications. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In the sections that follow, you learn about some of the major players that have office suites available for use on the Internet. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Most of these vendors offer a free basic service, with premium or paid services available that extend their features. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A subscription model based on monthly usage is common. |ENDSENT|

|STARTSENT| Summary This chapter gave you a taste of the range of cloud-based applications available to users and of the relative sophistication of these applications relative to their desktop counterparts. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Online productivity applications have the potential to displace local applications over time in many instances, but the more likely scenario is that the industry will arrive at a blended model that places some of the functionality of an application on the desktop while accessing other functionality through the cloud. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In this chapter, you saw examples of online office suites such as |URL| Glide, Google Docs, Microsoft Live Office Web Apps, ThinkFree, and Zoho Office. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Google and Zoho offer a wide range of applications; |URL| focuses on document creation and publishing; site offers Office Web Apps as a supplement to its desktop counterparts. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Each vendor has a unique slant on the capabilities that it is providing and what its vision of office software in the cloud will be. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| All these sites leverage assigned storage containers as its data repository. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| For the most part, these systems are platformand browser-neutral. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| easy to see the appeal of online office suites. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| They offer reduced costs, universal access, better collaboration, and rapidly developing standards. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The world is rapidly getting connected to the Internet, and many users are very comfortable with the idea of doing their work in the cloud. |ENDSENT|

|STARTSENT| Part Understanding Services and Applications Exploring the Cloud Mail Services By any measure, browser-based hosted e-mail or “Webmail” is one of the great success stories of the Internet. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| It is the prototypical Software as a Service (SaaS) application. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Webmail was also one of the first cloud computing applications to emerge and is today among the most heavily used services. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Webmail is differentiated from hosted e-mail primarily by the use of browser-based client access. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The underlying e-mail servers and the mail protocols are the same ones used for server e-mail services, but the servers and services have been deployed on a massive scale. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Many of these services such as Gmail and Hotmail are free up to a certain level of service; it is certainly the price that has attracted such a large worldwide audience. |ENDSENT|

|STARTSENT| Working with Syndication Services A syndication service is another way for people to send messages to a group of people; a form of published e-mail. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| To receive syndicated content, you must opt into the system and subscribe to the “feed” from one of the many content management system services. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| You can read RSS and Atom formatted content inside special applications called newsreaders, or as they are called more often “readers,” as well as in many Webmail applications. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| After you subscribe to a feed, the reader uses the link provided to download content from a site that you downloaded already. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Part Understanding Services and Applications The technology behind syndication is simple, but the value of the content can be impactful. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| a shame that more people make better use of this free Web service, although Web service providers have proved themselves to be creative consumers of syndication. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Your personalized Google home page can be altered to include information from any of thousands of feeds, serving the role of a reader or aggregator application, and with Ajax you can rearrange pages of feeds into various channels. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Web feeds also are used to follow blogger and wikis entries. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Note RSS and Atom are prototypes of a class of XML specifications called syndication markup languages. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| n The RSS and Atom Protocols Two technologies are behind most of the syndicated content being used on the RSS and Atom. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The first of these technologies, RSS, stands for Really Simple Syndication. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A typical RSS document or feed contains text and metadata that can be used to indicate publication dates, authors, keywords, and more. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| RSS uses an XML file format and the concept of an RSS world or module. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Several modules exist that are XML namespaces, including Ecommerce RSS |URL| Media RSS |URL| and OpenSearch RSS |URL| modules. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The major browser providers use the feed icon shown in Figure |URL| to indicate that you can subscribe to content on that Web page; the icon applies equally to RSS and Atom content. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| FIGURE |URL| The RSS syndication feed icon used in browsers. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The format has a long history of development starting as far back as |NUMBER| as an effort to summarize content of Web pages. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Dave Winer and UserLand Software were instrumental in developing the format specification, which exists in two main RDF (RSS |URL| |URL| and |URL| and RSS (RSS |URL| |URL| and |URL| Winer added the ability for subscription to include audio files in RSS feeds at the end of |NUMBER|. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Most consumers of RSS can work with either branch of the standard. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Currently, the RSS Advisory Board (|URL| manages this format. |ENDSENT|

|STARTSENT| Because of the number of people involved in the development of RSS and the absence of a standards body endorsing it, an alternative version of XML syndication called the Atom Publishing Protocol was developed by the IETF. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| That standard was released as part of the Proposed Standard RFC |NUMBER| (|URL| with the Atom Publishing Protocol Atom has some structural differences with RSS, but is similar in approach and technology. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Most of the major browsers support RSS and Atom, but some ask you to choose between them. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Blog and wiki content tends to use Atom as the format. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| When you view a syndication content management application, the aggregators tend to list feeds by content. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This is possible because a feed contains keywords in its metadata. |ENDSENT|

|STARTSENT| Part Understanding Services and Applications Exploring Instant Messaging Instant messaging (IM) is a software category that has benefited greatly from the growth of large user communities. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Instant messaging builds on the older concept of Internet chat to add a more immediate response to text messages between individuals and groups. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Whereas online chat is aimed at exchanging information between people in a forum or multiuser environment, instant messaging is most often a communication. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Instant messaging fills the gap between e-mail, which is asynchronous, and telephony, which is synchronous communication. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A good description of IM is that it is communications. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In the preceding chapter, you saw that each Webmail service offers its own IM client in its Webmail interface. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| While IM is meant to be instant communication between people, the merger of Webmail and IM means that many systems support sending messages to other people who are not currently logged into the system. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This form of offline messaging blurs the differences between IM and regular e-mail. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Instant messaging clients It is difficult to avoid exposure to instant messaging Operating systems, Webmail services, video games, enterprise messaging systems, and many other applications install IM clients. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Any application that wants to foster a sense of community can benefit from instant messaging. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Instant messaging applications have the following Discrete instant messaging desktop clients Enterprise messaging services with IM capabilities Browser-based IM clients (often in conjunction with Webmail) Mobile device clients, either embedded and client specific or mobile browser-based You can get some sense of the diversity of instant messaging clients by looking at the home page for AOL Instant Messenger (|URL| shown in Figure |URL| AIM comes in desktop, browser, and native client formats on multiple platforms. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The tendency recently has been to connect instant messaging systems to social media sites. |ENDSENT|

|STARTSENT| Chapter |NUMBER|: Communicating with the Cloud Instant messaging interoperability Some IM clients use messaging, but not all. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| IM software aimed at businesses such as XMPP, Lotus Sametime, and Microsoft Office Communicator use a architecture based on their message server products such as Domino and Exchange. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Early developers in this field have tended to create their own proprietary messaging standards, which has made communications between different IM clients difficult or impossible. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Interoperability between different instant messaging clients has been a major area of contention. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In an effort to create an interoperability standard between different IM clients, several instant messaging protocols have been created. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The most important are the three IETF (Internet Engineering Task Force) Session Initiation Protocol (SIP), SIP for Instant Messaging and Presence Leveraging (SIMPLE), and Extensible Messaging and Presence Protocol (XMPP). |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The Open Mobile Alliance also has an IM communications standard called IMPS (Internet Messaging and Presence Service) for cell phones. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| For a long time, each of the top IM services was locked into its own proprietary protocol. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| However, there has been some movement in this area over the last several years. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The top three IM service providers (AOL, Microsoft, and Yahoo!) |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| have adopted as their interoperability protocol, and they allow their users to connect with the other public users for a fee. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Several third-party IM clients aim to allow their users to connect to the different major IM services, including Most notable among these is Trillian, which runs on Windows, Macintosh, IOS (iPhone OS), Android, Blackberry, and inside browsers. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Trillian connects to the IM services AIM, ICQ, Windows Live Messenger, Yahoo! |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Messenger, IRC, Novell GroupWise Messenger, Bonjour, XMPP, and Skype. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Additionally, Trillian can be used to send and receive messages from Facebook, MySpace, and Twitter. |ENDSENT|

|STARTSENT| Exploring Collaboration Technologies The emergence of cloud networks, the lowered cost of computing, and the high cost of travel also have helped spur the popularity of collaborative software for conferencing and workgroup support. |ENDSENT|

|STARTSENT| Features These are the central elements of social networking Personal In this section, you enter your biographical data, your likes and dislikes, personality traits, and whatever else you want to share with your friends and the world. |ENDSENT|

|STARTSENT| Groups: Nearly all social networks have a feature called groups where people interested in a similar topic can post messages to one another. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Groups can be related to your high school classmates, a topic of interest, or just about anything you can think of. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Part Understanding Services and Applications Discussions: Discussions are message boards where people who are usually in a group post messages on a topic. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The conversation, referred to as “the thread,” represents the evolved thinking of two or more people. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| You often see discussions with useful links and media. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Discussions are often indexed by the major search engines, so it is often the case that when trying to solve a technical problem, I find my answer in a discussion on one of these social network sites. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Blogs: Blogs are personal Web logs, collections of journal entries you make, shown in reverse chronological order. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Most social networking sites have the ability to create blogs and either show them on your pages or post them to one of the leading blog hosts, such as Blogger or Wordpress. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Widgets: A widget is a small utility that you can add to your page. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Many social networking sites have widget galleries that contain clocks, calendars, animations, weather information, electronic Post-It notes, and many more. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The use of Ajax as a programming medium for these types of sites makes the use of widgets even more prevalent than in the past. |ENDSENT|

|STARTSENT| Social networks have had the normal history of infrequent break-ins by hackers, often because a password set to a strong one. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Because many of these sites are free, their business model must use advertisement or the sale of user demographics or information to monetize themselves. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| That puts lots of pressure on social networks to disclose information in aggregate or by individual. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| However, two other aspects of security are more privacy rights and the fungibility of the data over a long time period. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Ideally, social networking sites should be opt-in systems. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| When you sign up, you are presented with a list of options that you select to belong to. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Unfortunately, these networks often have lots of options, so some sites set their accounts to be opt-out by default. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| That is, the site itself determines the default options and assigns those options to any new account. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| If you want out of an option, you need to change the setting in your settings. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| For a site like Facebook with many options, this has been a problem, and it has caused an uproar. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Facebook has had to change its privacy policy several times over the last couple of years. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| When you post data on a social network, you have to realize that the data may have a long lifecycle. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A picture or story you post on your page as a teenager might influence your candidacy for a job a few years later. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| So it is very important to protect your data and retain your privacy rights. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| One of the issues encountered is the ownership of the data; do you or does the Web site have ownership rights? |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This is an evolving area of law. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Chapter |NUMBER|: Communicating with the Cloud Interaction and interoperability Participating in multiple social networks is a major chore, and it is easy to be overwhelmed. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Not only do you have to manage the data you are entering into the system, but if you are following or subscribing to different individuals on different services, you may find yourself logging into each of those services separately during your day or week. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| As the sites get bigger and their technologies get better defined, there has been a trend in the industry to get different sites to interoperate with one another. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| One imitative to create a common API is the OpenSocial (|URL| API that Google and MySpace support. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| OpenSocial has yet to achieve critical mass in the industry, but is indicative of the direction of this technology to interoperate. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A new class of social network aggregators has appeared that collects information from other sites into a consolidated data store. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Some of these sites also allow you to create a universal personal profile that can be shared with several social networks. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In order to perform aggregation, these applications have to tap into the social API, provided that the service is given consent by the user in the form of supplying his username and password for the social networking service. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This is similar to OpenID, and in fact several of the major sites are adopting OpenID as their authentication. |ENDSENT|

|STARTSENT| IN THIS CHAPTER Learning about large scale streaming Understanding why cloud computing makes streaming easier Viewing examples of audio streaming Discovering the many cloud video services available Using Media and Streaming Streaming files is a way of delivering large content in pieces so playback can begin more quickly. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Streaming is used for broadcasting current events, showing TV and movies on your computer or cell phone, listening to Internet radio, making phone calls, and using many other applications. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Cloud computing has a number of advantages that aid content providers and delivery systems. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Cloud computing provides large storage for maintaining libraries, large networks where content can be deployed worldwide, compute power for streaming servers, and an engine for content. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This chapter describes some of these advantages, introducing you to early products and services in this field. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Audio streaming was among the first media applications to find widespread use on the Internet. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Cloud computing has expanded the use of streamed audio to make radio, Web casts, music sites, and other services widely available. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| VoIP is a form of audio streaming with a set of specialized protocols. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Cloud computing is bringing a whole new class of applications to Internet users. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Two applications in this area, Skype and Google Voice, are highlighted in this chapter. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Broadband connections and low-cost infrastructure have made video streaming services widely available. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The formats used for video streaming are described here. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Cloud computing has made many of these services available at low cost or for free. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This chapter presents some of the best and most widely known video services on the Internet, many of which are household names and among the most heavily visited sites. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| One trend worth watching is the move of TV into the cloud. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A number of video sites bring this type of content to you. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The video sharing site YouTube is described in some detail. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Part Understanding Services and Applications Understanding the Streaming Process Streaming media are files that are sent in pieces by a service and played back by a client as the delivery continues. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Streamed material can be live or on-demand. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Live streaming is called progressive streaming or progressive download, while on-demand streaming is from material that is already stored to disk. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In order to stream content successfully, the system requires that the network bandwidth be adequate to support the transfer of enough material to support user playback. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| For cloud computing where the media files are large and the connection is a low latency WAN connection, this is a major consideration and potential bottleneck. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The amount of data transferred during streaming can be enormous. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Assuming that you have a one-hour video file transferred at |NUMBER| kbps and encoded into a widow that is pixels in size, on-demand streaming would require the Size (MB) Time (seconds) x bit rate where a mebibyte (MiB) is |NUMBER| x x bits x bps)/ = |NUMBER| MiB or about |NUMBER| Because |NUMBER| kbs is equal to bps, in the line above |NUMBER| kbs is equal to bps. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Notice that this calculation uses mebibytes (MiB). |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A MiB is a measurement of the number of binary bytes in units of |NUMBER| which is what the prefix mebiindicates. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A MiB is equal to |NUMBER| or bytes. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| When a live stream is sent multicast to concurrent users at |NUMBER| kbps, the number of megabytes transferred is calculated like MB transferred Bandwidth x Time x Number of Users These figures are based on calculations found at |URL| When this stream is sent unicast to users, it uses a bandwidth of |NUMBER| kbps. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Unicast is a stream sent from a service to an individual user. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| For many content services, such as the music services |URL| and Rhapsody, a vast number of files are being served to individual users and they go out using unicast protocols as individual streams. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The more users being served by the same content, the less efficient unicast is, and multicast protocols are employed. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In a multicast scenario, the same content is being pushed out to multiple users. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The system can send an individual copy or stream of the content to an intermediary server, which then uses the replicated copy to service users. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Because we know that live streaming requires be transferred per hour, a multicast system would require that we transfer to each of the relay servers in the multicast network. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The amount of data sent per customers would then be a function of the amount of fanout in the system. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| where a content delivery network deployment in the cloud really pays for itself. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| assume that you choose to serve the content out of |NUMBER| datacenters worldwide to users and that your system load balances the clients using an algorithm that determines the closest or |NUMBER| users to each site. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Then you have transferred |NUMBER| x or |URL| of data to your servers from the service, but your relays have then transferred |NUMBER| x |URL| or to end users. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| If Chapter |NUMBER|: Using Media and Streaming those relay servers are on LANs with their clients, then the speed-up can be greatly enhanced. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Even if delivery is always over a WAN connection, CDN (Content Delivery Network) still offers enormous efficiencies. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The second requirement is that the service sending content be able to deliver the material in sequence or nearly in sequence to the client. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| As material is streamed to a client, the material can be buffered to memory and the system can use the sequence number in the packets received to structure playback. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Depending upon the player application in use, the downloaded information can be viewed and then discarded, or it can be viewed in sequence in parts until the file is completely downloaded. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In the latter case, the technology is performing what is called progressive downloads, which is so similar to streaming that it also is called pseudo-streaming. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Applications that protect streamed content by playing part of the file and discarding it are more aptly referred to as streaming. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Protocols in Use A digital audio or video file is partitioned into many small pieces and played back at high speed. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Depending upon the nature of the material, playing streamed material can suffer a certain amount of loss of transmitted packets, which is displayed as dropped frames or missing notes without the viewer noticing. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This difference between streamed media and transferred media is fundamental in deciding which transfer protocol to use. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| For transferred media, the entire file must be transmitted with fidelity, thus TCP (Transmission Control Protocol) is the transmission protocol. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In a streamed media scenario, fidelity a prerequisite, thus UDP (User Datagram Protocol) is the transmission protocol. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Note You can find a fuller discussion of TCP and UDP in the book Networking Bible by Barrie Sosinsky, Wiley, |NUMBER|. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| n A number of network control protocols have been developed to stream media. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Prominent among them are Real-time Transport Control Protocol (RTCP), Real-time Streaming Protocol (RTSP), and Real-time Transfer Protocol (RTP). |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| RTP and RTCP are used exclusively with UDP, while RTSP is used with several different protocols. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| These three protocols are Application layer protocols, whereas TCP and UDP are Transport layer protocols. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| All the streaming protocols in use take raw files and compress them in some way. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| If the material is to be protected, then the files also are encrypted prior to transmission and decrypted when they arrive. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The cloud computing advantages People in the streaming media community are very excited about cloud computing, and for good reason. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Cloud computing has some unique features that make it a very suitable platform for large scale audio and video streaming to customers on demand. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Cloud systems offer the Access to large scale storage, which enable the storage of large media files and on-demand media libraries. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Amazon Microsoft Windows Azure Blob Storage, Nirvanix, EMC Atmos Online, Mezo, Google Storage for Developers. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Rackspace CloudFiles, and Eucalyptus are examples of Part Understanding Services and Applications some of the large cloud storage systems available to content providers. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Some of these systems, such as Microsoft Azure and Google Storage, support the applications position on those SaaS services. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Access to scalable compute engines and network storage that can serve as the streaming server to large audiences. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Access to a scalable compute engines that can be useful when you want to perform or transcoding on media files. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The company |URL| is an example of a transcoding service where you can use an Adobe AIR application to drag and drop files that are encoded right to your desktop. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Access to content delivery networks or edge systems that can push content out to users based on geographical location. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Examples are Akamai, CloudFront, and edge streaming systems that are part of its content delivery networks. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| |URL| whose home page is shown in Figure |URL| offers a great example of how the cloud can be leveraged to provide a service on demand. |ENDSENT|
