|STARTSENT| Audio Streaming Audio streaming makes much lower demands on network bandwidth than video streaming does. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| An audio file is roughly |NUMBER| times smaller than a correspondingly long video file. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Therefore, the first streaming services that appeared even before broadband became widely available were audio streaming services. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| An early entrant into this area was Real Real Player technology and its associated protocol suite. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| There was a time when many content providers required you to use RealAudio technology and the RealPlayer media player. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Two other competing formats appeared that have gotten general Windows Media Player and Apple QuickTime. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| These players play video formats as well as audio formats, and all are available as stand-alone players or as browser plug-ins. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Many sites still offer content in one of these three formats, but the trend over the past five years has been to shift away from proprietary formats to standard formats. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Today is king, and all three Part Understanding Services and Applications of the aforementioned players will play streamed files in addition to their native formats. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The bulk of the large services that have migrated to the cloud have stored their material in format. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Some services protect their audio content by making sure that only their player can play back material from their service, and that the sound be recorded digitally; |URL| is an example of this type of service. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Another type of streamed service is SHOUTcast, a proprietary server solution for streaming media on the Internet. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| SHOUTcast is best known for its SHOUTcast Radio, which maintains a directory of SHOUTcast servers. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| These servers stream content in the form of channels or streams that form the basis for Internet radio stations. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| More than |NUMBER| million people listen to Internet radio every week. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Several other competitive streaming services exist. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| National Public Radio is a very good example of how audio streaming has evolved. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The goal of NPR is to be available on all platforms in current use. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| NPR started out providing RealAudio files for streaming and then added Windows Media files as a second format. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Today, NPR provides an audio stream from Internet Explorer on Windows inside Windows Media Player, as shown in Figure |URL| Programs are recorded as files. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| If you subscribe (via RSS) to an NPR program using a program like iTunes, files are transferred to your system. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| RSS stands for Really Simple Syndication, a protocol for providing Web feeds from publication sources such as blogs, news sites, and others. |ENDSENT|

|STARTSENT| Chapter |NUMBER|: Using Media and Streaming Working with VoIP Applications Voice over IP or VoIP is a set of communication protocols for delivering voice over the Internet. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Some of these services have been migrated to the cloud, particularly those services that require the involvement of large number of servers. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| VoIP uses additional protocols and standards other than audio streaming; these are the most commonly used VoIP |URL| IP Multimedia Subsystem (IMS) Media Gateway Control Protocol (MGCP) Session Initiation Protocol (SIP) Real-time Transport Protocol (RTP) Session Description Protocol (SDP) The older protocol |URL| while still used on long transmission lines, is being replaced with more lightweight protocols such as MGCP and more particularly SIP. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| VoIP is a growing market, displacing older switching technologies used in the public telephone system, what has come to be called the “Plain Old Telephone Service” or POTS. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| As such, it is a technology that benefits from deployment in clouds. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| To illustrate the kind of impact that cloud computing can have on VoIP and telephony applications, the examples of Skype and Google Voice are presented here. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Note POTS is also referred to as the Public Switched Telephone Network (PSTN), although the latter term includes many of the more modern switching technologies. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The ITU-T is the standards body for PSTN. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| n Skype Skype is an example of a VoIP application. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The Skype protocol is a proprietary (closed-source) protocol, parts of which use the Global Index protocol. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Unlike standard VoIP, which uses a model, Skype uses the model that was based on Kazaa. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Kazaa was a file-sharing network developed by the Estonian company BlueMoon Interactive, which went on to develop Skype. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Because Skype is a application, the nature of the deployment of the directory must be distributed in some way, but it is not clear how this is done. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Skype communication is encrypted using standard encryption RSA key negotiation and Advanced Encryption Standard (AES) encryption algorithms. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Accounts on Skype do not require that the name of the caller be identified during a call, only his username. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| It is not certain that communication on Skype is entirely secure; there is speculation that the company or government agencies may have access to communications. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| However, in the United States, the FCC has stated that Skype is subject to the Communications Assistance for Law Enforcement Act (CALEA), although Skype claims exemption. |ENDSENT|

|STARTSENT| Part Understanding Services and Applications Streaming video formats The history of streaming video on the Internet has progressed from the raw video formats supported by Real Media to media that is embedded directly into Web pages in the form of Apple QuickTime or Windows Media. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The predominant format at the moment is the platform based on Adobe Flash, although other formats, such as Silverlight, are constantly being introduced as competitors. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| As the industry is moving more and more to the cloud, there has been a push to develop open-source video standards such as the new HTML |NUMBER| video format. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| To view streaming content in video players, you need a compatible browser and a site like YouTube that supports |URL| and WebM codec) formats. |ENDSENT|

|STARTSENT| You also can view HTML |NUMBER| content in the following media Video formats are only half of the story when it comes to video file formats. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The second half of the story is the format for the streaming protocol that encodes the video file. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Several of these container formats are in use. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The most widely used streaming video file container format is |URL| Part |NUMBER|. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Part |NUMBER| is also known as AVC, which stands for Advanced Video Coding. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This standard was designed for the recording and playback of home theater or HD video, and it supports lowerquality video played on mobile devices. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The ITU-T Video Coding Experts Group (VCEG) and the Moving Picture Experts Group (MPEG) created the Joint Video Team (JVT), and the result is that both standards are technically identical. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| You may therefore see streamed video content in the form of |URL| AVC, or Part |NUMBER| all of which refer to the same file format. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| |URL| can carry Flash, and other video file formats. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Chapter |NUMBER|: Using Media and Streaming You will find |URL| used as the streaming format for most large video sites, such as YouTube and iTunes, in cable and satellite TV services, and for video conferencing software. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Older and less capable formats such as |URL| Part |NUMBER| and are still in use, but they deployed in the new cloud-based implementation meant for large audiences. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In order to support a range of devices, the Advanced Video Coding defines a set of profiles to support specific device types. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| These profiles define resolution and bitrates, among other features. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| One profile might be used on the Apple iPhone, another on a standard definition DVD, and yet a third on HDTV. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The profiles in most widespread use are Main and High, with the Baseline and Extended profiles in use for mobile devices. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Within each profile are a set of levels that determine which features are available to support a specific application. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| For example, High Level |URL| has a resolution of and can play at framerates of |URL| |NUMBER| or |URL| fps (frames per second); this level supports the Sony PSP. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Level |NUMBER| has a resolution of and can play at framerates of |NUMBER| |NUMBER| |URL| or |NUMBER| fps (frames per second); this level supports the Blu-ray and HD DVD devices. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The codec that the video content uses a block-oriented motioncompensation scheme. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| It is important to understand that |URL| defines a standard for encoding content, but that the implementation of a codec can vary. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Some codecs may choose to encode some features and not others. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| When content is encoded in |URL| AVC, any codec may decode the file, but some do a better job decoding the file than others. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Some decoders may ignore features that others The newest of the video streaming file formats is WebM. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| WebM (|URL| is an open-source royalty-free media file format that has been optimized for the Web and is used to carry HTML |NUMBER| video content. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This container file format is decoded by the video codec, which was developed by and now owned by Google. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| WebM uses the Vorbis audio codec and the Matroska container file structure. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Introduced in |DATE|, WebM builds on the earlier codec that is the industry standard built into Adobe Flash. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| improves on the compression algorithms in and is supposed to allow WebM to deliver more content with a lower client-processor overhead than content carried by |URL| Jan Ozer at |URL| has done an analysis (see |URL| and |URL| of WebM versus |URL| and concludes that at this early point in development, the minor differences in quality will probably escape notice and that client-side overhead still requires more optimization and yet deliver a significant bandwidth advantage over |URL| Hardware acceleration support in upcoming devices may provide the boost that developers have promised. |ENDSENT|

|STARTSENT| YouTube and the law The sheer volume of content uploaded to YouTube on a daily basis is staggering. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| YouTube posts a notice asking that copyrights be obeyed, and the company subjects content to automatic filters, but impossible to police all the content that gets onto a site. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| As a general rule, YouTube removes content that receives what it sees as valid complaints from individuals or organizations, but after the content is online, often the damage has already been done. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| YouTube relies on its users to police its content. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This has led to some well-known lawsuits, such as the one Viacom has pursued asking for billion in damages for posted content. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| As of |DATE|, the District Court in Southern New York ruled in favor of Google, but this case could be headed to the Supreme Court. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In another case, the artist known as Prince sued a mother who posted a clip of her infant son dancing to the song Go Crazy.” That case was resolved in favor of the posting party on the “fair use” doctrine. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Fair use as defined by the |URL| Copyright act of |NUMBER| allows portions of a copyrighted work to be used |NUMBER|. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The use is for non-profit educational purposes and not for commercial gain. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The nature of the copyrighted work allows its use in part as a natural course. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The amount used is not a substantial amount of the overall work. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The effect of the use diminish the overall value of the copyrighted work. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Chapter |NUMBER|: Using Media and Streaming Courts are supposed to balance these four factors when deciding whether a posting or use falls under fair use, and so should you. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Without fair use, newspapers, magazines, educational institutions, and a myriad of other public goods would be significantly diminished. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| YouTube win them all. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In a recent case in the Italian courts on |DATE|, three Google executives were convicted of violating privacy laws when a video of a group of Italian boys harassing a boy with Down syndrome was shown on the site. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Although YouTube removed the video after two hours and the judge gave community service to the minor boys who posted the video, the conviction of the executives could have a chilling effect on content least in Italy and perhaps in the European Union. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The disposition of this ruling will be interesting to watch. |ENDSENT|

|STARTSENT| Part V Using the Mobile Cloud IN THIS PART Chapter |NUMBER| Working with Mobile Devices Chapter |NUMBER| Working with Mobile Web Services Working with Mobile Devices IN THIS CHAPTER Learning about the cell phone market Discovering the key smartphone Web features Understanding how cloud services are changing phone services Discovering the different smartphone operating systems In this chapter, you learn about mobile phones and their interaction with the cloud. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The impact that cellular phone technology has had on civilization is dramatic. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The most popular consumer device is the Nokia |NUMBER| and the billionth cell phone that Nokia sold was an |NUMBER| in Nigeria. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Cell phones have had nearly universal worldwide adoption. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Cell phones fall into two categories. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| As this chapter explains, there are feature phones, which are phones with added capabilities, and smartphones that run recognized operating systems, install applications, and have persistent Internet connectivity. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Feature phones are being replaced by smartphones, and for many people in the world, smartphones are the only computer that they will ever own. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Cloud services are having a major impact on cellular phone technology, and vice versa. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Many smartphones come with native applications that consume Web services, many of which are currently deployed in the cloud. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Some of these applications do little more than point a micro-browser at a Web site that has been specifically formatted for mobile phone consumption. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Other applications consume RSS feeds, and many more are simply frontends for applications that run in the cloud. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Mobile application developers are staging their apps in the cloud, and a number of hosting services provide support for this. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Amazon Web Service and the iAWSManager app are provided as an example. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The five major smartphone operating systems to consider are Android, iOS (iPhone OS), RIM BlackBerry, Symbian, and Windows Mobile Phone. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Each of these platforms supports installable applications, and Android and the iPhone support hundreds of thousands of third-party applications. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Many of these applications running in part or fully in the cloud contribute greatly to the value proposition of these leading edge mobile platforms. |ENDSENT|

|STARTSENT| Part Using the Mobile Cloud Adopting mobile cloud applications When you consider the term “mobile cloud computing,” you are describing a model where processing is done in the cloud, data is stored in the cloud, and the mobile device serves as the presentation platform or the display. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| For this model to work a phone, tablet, or laptop requires a reliable Internet connection and the ability to run a browser (a micro-browser, really) or another viewing application. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Currently, most of the computing applications that run on mobile devices run on the local device itself, with a few exceptions. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Those exceptions include applications such as Google Earth, Google Maps, the major cloud mail services, and applications that provide navigation, among others. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| For the most part, though, applications that run on the current generations of smartphones such as Android, iPhones, RIM BlackBerry, and Windows Mobile, among others, are processed locally on the phone. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| These smartphones are essentially miniaturized computers. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In |NUMBER| cell phone sales totaled |URL| billion units, while smartphones sold |NUMBER| million units. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Smartphones currently represent only |NUMBER| percent of the overall market. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| While smartphone sales grew from a level of |NUMBER| million units in |NUMBER| versus |URL| billion sales of cell phones, it is and will remain for a while only a small albeit highly profitable part of the cell phone market. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| When you live in the United States, Europe, or another affluent society, you tend to view the world through the prism of your own experience. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Many readers of this book who are technological cognoscenti have smartphones, but most of the roughly |URL| billion cell phone users do not; they have what are described as “feature phones.” What cloud computing offers the cell phone users is the potential to have a smartphone or rich Internet media experience on a cell phone and the potential for smartphones to become technologically “thinner” devices. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| By thinner, I mean that the devices will require less processing, consume less power, and have better battery life. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Currently, when you want to buy a cell phone or a smart phone, you trundle into a service store and buy a phone that is supported by that network. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| To have an application run on the different cell phone types or smartphone operating systems, you need a Nokia developer, a Symbian developer, a RIM developer, an iPhone developer, and so on. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| When you develop an application for the cloud, you need just one type of developer and then all the connected phones can use that application. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This is one of the main reasons why cloud computing represents a disruptive technology for mobile computing and cell phones. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Another reason is the avoidance of vendor lock-in. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| When you “commit” to a cell phone (particularly a smartphone), many people essentially lease these phones and are trapped in oneor two-year commitments. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Worse than that, the data and applications they use are associated with their current phone and platform. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Cloud computing frees those huddled cell phone masses yearning to be free from having to migrate their data and apps. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| If you think mobile service providers concerned about their customers being free to vote with their feet, think again. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The recent “announcement” the support of that they support a tiered pricing model for content transferred over wireless networks is nothing more than an attempt to control Web applications on their network and for Google to retain unrestricted access (for a cost) on willing carriers. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| With such a large audience relying more and more on mobile technologies, and cell phones in particular, it is incumbent on software developers to think about extending their applications to the mobile space. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| What better way to do so than to build a cloud application? |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| For mail servers, Chapter |NUMBER|: Working with Mobile Devices that means migrating your platform to a mail service. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| For a PaaS vendor such as |URL| that means modifying your Web service so the application can be experienced on the pixel iPhone |NUMBER| the HTC Touch HD, or the BlackBerry |NUMBER| (Storm). |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| These are all relatively large displays that can render a window to a near-PC experience. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Indeed, as Figure |URL| attests, exactly what |URL| has done with its Mobile Lite Service and Salesforce CRM Mobile Service applications for the iOS, Windows Mobile, and RIM operating systems, respectively. |ENDSENT|

|STARTSENT| Using Smartphones with the Cloud There are many different ways in which you can define a smartphone, but these are the essential A smartphone has a recognizable operating system. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A smartphone can run installable applications. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Chapter |NUMBER|: Working with Mobile Devices A smartphone offers advanced calling features such as video calls or conferencing. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A smartphone offers messaging features. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A smartphone comes with a touchscreen; the bigger the touchscreen the smarter the phone. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A smartphone offers keyboard entry, either physically or virtually. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A smartphone has a persistent Internet connection. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| So my definition of smartphones goes like Smartphones are small computers on which you can make phone calls, send messages, and access Internet data in real time. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| So much for smartphones, but what about the cloud? |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| As it stands today cloud computing is based around the idea that large industrial-sized information appliances can serve up data to any and all comers. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The smartphone and eventually feature phones too, as well as tablets, laptops, and mobile internet devices, are all cloud clients. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| But smartphones and the cloud, well that is dynamite because the two technologies are you couple a client that requires a ubiquitous service with a service that is ubiquitous, and then you provide the combination with a nearly universal worldwide market penetration. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Each technology enhances and drives the other. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Consider what we seen yet in smartphones that clouds can offer. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| If you move smartphone execution to a virtual machine running in the cloud, smartphones are no longer constrained by their processing power, memory, or storage capacity. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The only two factors of importance are network bandwidth and display quality. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| You have to think that someone will build the equivalent of a thin service using the cloud. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| We also seen phone networks using peering. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| If you design a phone so that each phone is a node in a large distributed network, then the overall computer has almost infinite capability and power. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Some of the most powerful supercomputers in the world are built with large numbers of commodity computers in a cluster or grid, and some of the largest computing projects ever attempted run on the spare cycles of hundreds of thousands of computers. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| So why not a cell phone network too? |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This cloud computing, but it is something you have to wonder about. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| One thing that smartphones have made perfectly clear is that people love apps. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| On the mobile platforms described in the following sections, each vendor (with the exception of Symbian) has an application marketplace. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Each vendor also puts lots of effort into getting third-party applications written for its platform. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Many of the applications using Web services are doing so through sites that are specially formatted for a particular platform. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Nearly every major Web site or service has a version that is optimized for mobile computing and accessed using a mobile URL. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| When you point a micro-browser at one of these sites, you get a smartphone-optimized cloud-based experience. |ENDSENT|

|STARTSENT| In the days when Personal Digital Assistants got apps from software vendors over the Internet, the experience was a miserable one. |ENDSENT|

|STARTSENT| This in turn gave developers a large installed base of devices to write to, a uniform set of tools to write with, and a mechanism for monetizing their applications. |ENDSENT|

|STARTSENT| Working with Mobile Web Services IN THIS CHAPTER Learning about Web services Using Web sites on mobile devices Understanding how services are discovered Understanding push technology Mobile devices use more network traffic in consuming Web services than do fixed-line systems. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Most people find that their use of Web services is increasing dramatically year after year. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Indeed, as this chapter shows you, the Web is becoming a source of rich content for mobile devices. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Mobile devices present some challenges for Web services. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Specifically, their device characteristics match the resolution and detail of desktop computers. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| For that reason, many service protocols are specifically aimed at providing the necessary translation required to make Web sites look good on mobile devices. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| To use a Web service, a device needs to know about that service and know how to access it. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This chapter describes some of the methods used for Web service discovery based on standard methods. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Mobile devices can transmit specific information about the condition of the device and its user. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This information, when properly parsed and logically analyzed, can be used to create context-aware services. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Location-based services are offered as the prime example of this feature. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Push services are an important mechanism in e-mail and in certain forms of publishing. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In this chapter, you learn about different push services, including how BlackBerry does push and the Lemonade Profile. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The Short Message System (SMS) is a form of message push service and is described in this chapter. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The chapter is rounded out by a look at the Wireless Access Protocol (WAP), which is a push mechanism for publishing Web site data that is device-specific. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| You also learn about some of the data synchronization standards used in mobile technology. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Part Using the Mobile Cloud Understanding Service Types Mobile Web services are those in which information is transferred between applications (especially a browser) and services over an Internet connection. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| As you saw in Chapter |NUMBER| more information is transferred over mobile connections now than is transferred over fixed lines. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Early cell phones and feature phones depended upon native applications for most of their enhancements. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Web services have made the development of mobile Web applications much easier and more powerful, and thus these types of applications are steadily replacing native applications that are usually platform-specific and proprietary. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The tendency to include sensors of all types in mobile devices is making the mobile Web a very rich service indeed. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Mobile interoperability In the current market, the mobile Web is fractured into many different competing operating systems and proprietary hardware. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This going to change anytime soon, and the market will probably be supporting many different products for years to come. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The fact is that the approach Apple has taken with the closed iOS products, the iPhone, iTouch, and iPad does tend to make these devices more reliable, and because they are more predictable, they are easier to use. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| For these benefits, you tender a certain amount of flexibility. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The lack of expandable storage on these devices is a classic example of vendor lock-in. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| There are open-system alternatives to systems like the iOS or BlackBerry OS. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The two best examples are the Android OS and the Symbian OS. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Open-system hardware and software tends to evolve more quickly than proprietary systems because there are more players and the work tends to get wider review. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| also a higher emphasis placed on interoperability in open systems. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| One effort to make mobile devices more interoperable is the Mobile Web Initiative (|URL| This initiative sought to make browsing the Web with mobile devices more reliable by setting standards that Web site designers can use to make their sites mobile-friendly. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| There are guidelines on the Mobile Web Initiative Web site that you can read on best practices, as well as a site-checking tool that does an assessment of a site for you. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The problem with mobile site optimization is that many different devices exist, and it is impossible to support more than a few of them. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| These factors need to be addressed, among Variable screen sizes and resolutions Slow transmission over the connection and limited rendering speeds on the device (something that is improving over time) Different methods of navigation through the interface Limited use of windows and lack of some standard graphical user interface controls Exclusion of certain file formats such as PDF, rendering engines such as Adobe Flash, and cookies Message size limitations Nonstandard and often onerous transmission costs Chapter |NUMBER|: Working with Mobile Web Services Vendors approach the problem of interoperability in several ways. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A common way is to create individual sites within a Web site for different devices. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Content is served up to a device based on the identity and content negotiation. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| With the rise of smartphone applications, many organizations are creating application frontends to their sites. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| To my mind, the best of these sites have been created by the major news BBC, CNN, AP, and the New York Times. |ENDSENT|

|STARTSENT| While the computer display is loaded with ads, the iPhone app displays on a single large advertisement. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The content is displayed on the application with much less leading content, and in a strictly hierarchical navigational system. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Each story is a link in the form of a large button to the full text of the story. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Many large links on the display have been replaced by fewer, but easier to select, buttons. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| There is also less use of graphics and images on the application. |ENDSENT|

|STARTSENT| Chapter |NUMBER|: Working with Mobile Web Services The establishment of the domain has been subject to criticism from the director, Tim Berners-Lee, on the grounds that the Web sites on the Internet should be device-independent. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| It is suggested that a better mechanism for content compatibility on the mobile Web is to use content negotiation, cascading style sheets, or other devices. |ENDSENT|

|STARTSENT| For example, if a device goes to the URI and is recognized as belonging to a supported type, then the program logic serves up the appropriate content. |ENDSENT|

|STARTSENT| Performing Service Discovery Web services are useful only if they can be discovered by mobile devices and accessed by those devices by mutually supported protocols. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| If protocols are standard and open, the chances of being able to exchange information is increased. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Web services are a form of In some cases, they involve messaging; in others, they use a metaphor; and in other cases, they are broadcast. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The nature of the protocol supports the mechanism for data transfer that is required. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| One standard for publishing a Web service that is used in cloud computing and contributes to the Service Oriented Architecture (SOA) is the Web Service Description Language (WSDL). |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This protocol was described in Chapter |NUMBER|. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In WSDL, the service is described in terms of an interface or endpoint that can be accessed to send information to and get information back from the service. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Note The Web site for these various OASIS Web service discovery protocols may be accessed at |URL| n Chapter |NUMBER|: Working with Mobile Web Services Several mechanisms exist for aggregating WSDL documents into a searchable form. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The Universal Description, Discovery, and Integration (UDDI; |URL| service is an open registry of business services. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| UDDI is an OASIS standard that is searchable and is in the XML format. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Documents stored in UDDI conform to the Web Service Inspection Language (WSIL) format, which makes the information searchable. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| IBM has a UDDI federated search technology in its Business Explorer for Web Services product http:// |URL| UDDI publishes information in the following White pages with identification information Yellow pages with industry categorization based on standard schema or taxonomies Green pages that specify the service endpoints The WS-Discovery service provides a means for advertising services on small networks using a multicast protocol. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Typically, the service is delivered using SOAP over UDP. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| WS-Discovery is an OASIS standard and is used as part of network discovery in Windows (WSDAPI), in the Device Profile for Web Services (DPWS), and in the Windows Rally technologies. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Microsoft uses Windows Rally to provision network nodes such as computers, access points, printers, and other networkconnected devices. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| ebXML, which stands for Electronic Business using eXtensible Markup Language is a joint standard of OASIS and and aims to create a searchable global registry of business services. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The standard is maintained by the freebXM (|URL| initiative. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Context-aware services As mobile computing has grown, each mobile device contains and is capable of transmitting a large amount of information concerning the condition or state of the device and the user who carries the device. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| When parsed properly, this information can provide intelligent systems with not only the identification, but the context in which that user finds himself. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Location is the prime example of context. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| When we search for something near us, the search engine returns results that are location-based and thus have context. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| When a phone transmits its GPS coordinates to a service, that service may be able to compare that location to the registered home or work address and then send information appropriate to each environment back to the user. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Or more specifically, if a phone transmits its location as being in a specific building or room to a service, then the service can display a map showing where the nearest restroom is or where the light switches are located, or it can provide instructions for how to work the overhead display in the room. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| You can see how this very tailored and specific information could be incredibly valuable and useful. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Note Keith Jones, an SOA Designer at IBM, published an article, “Building a context-aware service architecture” that goes into more detail on this topic and addresses different approaches. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| n Part Using the Mobile Cloud When a mobile user is connected to her mobile service, she is exchanging two different sets of Physical Information derived from measurements made from the mobile device or its sensors Logical Information derived from the user or from the manner in which the user has interacted with services over time As an example to demonstrate the difference between the two, the identification string associated with your cell SIM card is a physical attribute, and your service login ID and its associated password are a logical attribute. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Physical context provides location, ambient device conditions, device states, and more. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Logical contexts are information about the purpose a location serves, a digital identity and its associated attributes, relationships, interests, past searches, Web sites visited, privileges, and preferences. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Chapter |NUMBER| covers Service Oriented Architectures. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| An SOA provides a set of methods for using modules to construct loosely coupled complex systems from standard parts. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| You may recall from that discussion that the essence of SOA is that the method of construction of the modules is abstracted out of the system and encapsulated, and what SOA requires is a standard method for exposing the services that a module provides as a standard interface exposed by an API. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The methods remain invariant, even when the module is moved, re-architected, or subsumed into another module. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| SOA requires a standard messaging protocol and a form of federated database system. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In a Web service, the mobile client plays the role of a service consumer and the Web service is the service provider. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In Figure |URL| a system for processing contextual information is shown, based on the ideas of a Service Oriented Architecture. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A system of this type provides a much richer environment in which to respond to requests and allows both service providers and content providers to either narrowcast or tailor information for a specific user based on his current context. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The Context Logic Processor plays the role of the orchestrator providing programmed logic that works with the data parsed by the Context Parser. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The Context Parser takes all the input data (digital signals in many cases) and applies a logical schema to create the needed structured objects for the Logic use. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This infrastructure can be placed in the cloud. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The concept of creating a structured representation of concepts and their relationship in a domain is referred to as ontology. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Ontology is a formal way of specifying a shared abstraction. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Ontologies are used in all fields of computer science and are at the heart of efforts to create the Semantic Web, in artificial intelligence, library classification scheme, and so on. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The specific ontology that applies to a mobile SOA is the Web Ontology Language (OWL; |URL| and the formal semantics and Resource Data Framework |URL| serializations are under active development. |ENDSENT|

|STARTSENT| Contextual service requests Service providers MEMS MEMS stands for microelectromechanical systems and is a class of very small sensor or actuator devices where small mechanical systems are driven by electricity to indicate a position. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| MEMS as a class can be between |NUMBER| and |NUMBER| micrometers in size, and they are packaged into components that often include a microprocessor, memory, and other components. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Several MEMS are packaged in smartphones, and their numbers and complexity are growing over time. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The incorporation of low-cost geo-sensors in the form of Global Positioning System (GPS) chips into mobile devices opens the mobile user to a whole range of services based on the location. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This type of service is sometimes referred to as context-aware services, but location is just one context that can be used in processing client requests and returning relevant information. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| There are many more. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The following are built into the latest cell Accelerometers for measuring relative motion changes Gyroscopes Part Using the Mobile Cloud Image sensors in the form of CCD chips Proximity sensors Light sensors Sound sensors Compasses Pressure sensors (barometer) Thermisters (resistance thermometer devices or RTDs) The iPhone uses the proximity sensor to turn the screen off when a user puts the phone to his face. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The Droid, Nexus One, and iPhone have dual microphones so they can perform Active Noise Cancellation (ANC). |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| These sensors have the ability to measure the physical world around the user and translate an analog signal into a digital one that can be used to enhance a cloud-connected experiences. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| These types of devices are called systems or MEMS for short, and the MEMS industry is experiencing explosive growth. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| MEMS are everywhere you look. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| They are in smart watches like the Casio Pathfinders, cars, the Wii-mote, Rock Band instruments, on the suits actors wear to do green-screen work, in mirasol Display (|URL| used for e-readers, and (as previously mentioned) in smartphones. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Without MEMS, smartphones would be stupid phones, and smartphones are driving both innovation and demand for these devices. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| MEMS are turning smartphones into the ultimate digital Swiss Army knife. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Location awareness The idea behind context-aware services is that your device is constantly being polled for or sending data from its sensors that indicate the condition of the device. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| For a desktop that never moves anywhere, knowing the location is a one-time thing. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Suppose you type a search in Google on your desktop like pizza |NUMBER| Google returns a search that shows you the pizza joints in that ZIP code. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| You can see how this kind of search would be helpful for shopping, social networks, services, and other location-based information. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| However, when you are motoring around with your smartphone, laying rubber to the road, and cutting the night with your beams, you need to tell Google what your zip code or location is because your phone has already given that information to Web service. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| If lucky, your iPhone might ask you if you want to share your location with this service, but usually the information is simply passed on through with your query. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| There are many examples of locationaware services based on GPS data, where your location is found to within a few feet through the triangulation of three or more overhead satellite distances and positions. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Skyhook Wireless operates services, as shown in Figure |URL| that are based on a Wi-Fi Positioning System (WPS). |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The advantage of WPS is that there are hundreds of millions of Wi-Fi access points worldwide and they are closer to the mobile device, so there the significant lag time during Chapter |NUMBER|: Working with Mobile Web Services triangulation that you experience with GPS. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Skyhook holds a patent on a hybrid positioning system it calls XPS, which uses several location technologies in WPS, GPS, and cellular tower triangulation to obtain accurate user location to within a few feet and taking just a few seconds. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| FIGURE |URL| Skyhook Wireless (|URL| provides a location service that identifies a Web site location. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The system uses a large reference database of Wi-Fi access points and cell tower IDs, raw position data from each location source (a signal), and the proprietary algorithm to locate the device. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The XPS system is constantly polling locations to update them and recalibrating data points to improve accuracy over time. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Failing that, the system performs a location analysis based on your IP address and your known service provider. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Loki (|URL| has a Java API that works with the Skyhook network and its browser plug-in to locate users for subscribing Web sites. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Push services Push services are a technology where the transaction is initiated on a server and sent automatically to the client. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The opposite of a push is a pull technology, in which the client polls for and requests Part Using the Mobile Cloud a transaction. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In some instances, push can be a form of publishing and is described as conforming to the model. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The following services are examples of push Automated software updates Comet, an Ajax application data transfer (Comet uses either HTTP streaming or long polling, described below.) |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Instant Messaging e-mail HTTP streaming (also known as HTTP server push) Java pushlet RSS services Software installations Teleconferencing Not all push technologies used in mobile applications are server-based. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The IRC protocol and the XMPP IM and VoIP protocol are two examples of push technologies. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Bidirectional Streams Over Synchronous HTTP (BOSH) is a transport protocol that, when combined in XMPP service. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The XMPP PubSub extension is how Apple creates a push service for MobileMe. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Cross-Ref WAP Push is covered in the section “Defining WAP and Other Protocols” later in this chapter. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| n Push e-mail is the penultimate example of a push service. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In push e-mail, the service is always connected to the client, and it sends out to the client more or less immediately any new e-mail that arrives at the server. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In the parlance of system design, the active transfer process is referred to as “push,” the server is called the Mail Delivery Agent (MDA), and the client is called the Mail User Agent (MUA). |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The concept of push is that the mail is sent without the client asking for it, whereas the process of sending mail when the client asks for mail is referred to as “polling.” The well-known e-mail protocol is a polling protocol; IMAP can support both push and polling. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Push-IMAP is a push technology, as is the SMTP protocol. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Push-IMAP |URL| stands for the Push extensions for Internet Message Access Protocol (P-IMAP); it is an addition to the protocol that was added for mobile clients. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| P-IMAP allows an IMAP server to automatically keep a connection alive and update using what essentially amounts to a heartbeat signal and response. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| These signals are short and compressed, can contain commands and macros, and can be sent in three using the IMAP IDLE command |URL| as SMS, or using WAP Push. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| P-IMAP contains a feature that sends rich e-mail in a manner similar to SMTP. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Some polling mechanisms set the polling interval so short that the system appears to behave as if it is a push technology, so it can sometimes be hard to tell the difference. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| With a technique called long polling, the client requests information from the server, and if the server have information to send back to the client, it queues the request until a response with data is possible. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Chapter |NUMBER|: Working with Mobile Web Services When the server sends a response, the client typically sends another request to add to the queue, thus maintaining the apparent connection. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A mobile device that is polling is constantly activating its antenna and network services and draining its battery. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This is one reason that the BlackBerry and its push service gives a noticeably longer battery life between charges than other smartphones, Blackberry turns on its antenna only when required. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Both push and polling have pluses and minuses associated with them. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Polling offers the advantages that the client need not be permanently connected to the network and that the MDA (Mail Delivery Agent) can identify the location of the client from the details of the query. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| However, polling requires the client and the server to engage in handshaking, so it imparts lots of overhead to mail transfers. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Whereas a delay of a minute or more matter for many applications, for some stock market is critical. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The following are examples of services that use push DataViz Roadsync (|URL| for Android and Symbian using Microsoft Exchange ActiveSync. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Microsoft Exchange ActiveSync (|URL| RIM’s BlackBerry Enterprise Server (BES; |URL| BlackBerry devices use their own proprietary e-mail protocols. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Seven (|URL| Seven provides push e-mail, messaging, and sync for multiple mail and IM services and devices. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The immense popularity of the BlackBerry push e-mail system has led to a widespread adoption of this technology by many e-mail service providers. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Thus, you also find push e-mail with Push-IMAP on some Nokia Symbian and its Intellisync Wireless Email, Sony Ericsson Smartphones, and Cybershot phones among others. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The BlackBerry Push Service Developers use the BlackBerry Push Service to push application updates, images, text, audio, and other content to BlackBerry users using Java applications or BlackBerry Widgets that they develop using the service. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The Push Service transfers up to messages directly. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| If the content is larger than that, the content provider sets up its system so the notification is a push service and the device downloads the data from the content provider. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| BlackBerry Push Service uses the following Part Using the Mobile Cloud |NUMBER|. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Content provider sends a push request to the server. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| BlackBerry servers send a response back to the content provider. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| BlackBerry servers push the data out to BlackBerry clients. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| BlackBerry clients send a response to the BlackBerry server that the message was received. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| BlackBerry servers forward the acknowledgement to the content provider. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The content provider sends a read notification to the BlackBerry server. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Figure |URL| illustrates the BlackBerry Push service. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Note You can read more about the BlackBerry Push Service at |URL| FIGURE |URL| An illustration of the BlackBerry push technology Content producer BlackBerry push data server Java application sends data using BlackBerry push API at the devices Chapter |NUMBER|: Working with Mobile Web Services The Lemonade Profile The Lemonade Profile (|URL| uses a set of e-mail extensions to provide access to mobile devices. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| It builds on the IMAP protocol for delivery and on the Message Submission SMTP profile. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The Lemonade Profile is an alternative mechanism for push e-mail. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| When a message is available, a timely notification is provided and the Mail Submission Agent (MSA) used in SMTP can be used to retrieve the e-mail from an IMAP data store. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The advantage of the Lemonade Profile is that it uses both IMAP and SMTP and can be used by any IMAP client. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This mechanism is an alternative to a Push-IMAP specification, but uses instead a combination of short notification and the IDLE command in IMAP. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The Lemonade Profile is a specification of the IETF as RFC |NUMBER| (|URL| A Push-IMAP specification has been developed but not standardized. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Using SMS The Short Message Service (SMS) is a text-notification service that has evolved into a primary communications protocol for message passing. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| SMS, or texting, forms a secondary method for mobile users to communicate with one another, and valuable because it occupies a middle ground between an Instant Message and a Chat. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Internet Service Providers have noticed a drop in e-mail volume over the past years that they attribute to the widespread use of SMS. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The majority of cell phone subscribers have SMS text-message accounts. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The word short refers to the limitation of the number of characters that can be sent in a single message. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A message can be only |NUMBER| octets (or |NUMBER| |NUMBER| bits |NUMBER| bits). |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This maximum size in characters is as For characters (upper ASCII), which includes numbers, letters, and symbols, the limit is |NUMBER| characters. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| For characters (full ASCII), the limit is |NUMBER| characters. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| For character representations, like those used by pictographic languages, a lower limit of no more than |NUMBER| characters. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A form of SMS called Concatenated SMS or Long SMS allows longer messages to be sent using multiple packets containing a User Data Header that contains the segment number. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The limit for this multipart or segmented SMS is |NUMBER| characters for |NUMBER| for and |NUMBER| for encoding. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The practice of sending this type of SMS is relatively rare. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| SMS was designed to operate over the control channel during times of low traffic. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| A control channel is sending and receiving handshake information so the connection is maintained correctly; it also is used to send messages with commands that control phone features such as ringtones. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Every so often, the control channel is synchronized and for a while no messages need to be exchanged. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| It is during those periods that SMS packets are transmitted. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This arrangement makes SMS a very low-overhead messaging service. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Part Using the Mobile Cloud SMS is a system for communications. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In a unicast message sent using Short Message Service (SMS-PP), when a phone or PC sends an SMS message, that message is sent over the control channel to a Message Controller, and then onto a Short Message Service Center (SMSC). |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The SMSC forwards the SMS message to a Message Controller connected to the party receiving the SMS, and then the SMS message is sent onto the recipient. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| If the recipient moves to another location, the SMSC can send the SMS message to the appropriate SMS controller. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The SMSC keeps trying to send the message until it receives a response from the receiving party that the message was received. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| An SMS message can be retained at the SMSC for many days until the message reaches its intended recipient. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Also, SMS messages are retained on the sending and receiving systems in their SIM cards until they are deleted. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| SMS also supports broadcasting, sending the message from one person to many. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| SMS is not a particularly secure method of communication. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Over a GSM network system, transfers use a weak encryption. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| One-way authentication is also performed, which is another vulnerability. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| An SMS message also can pass through multiple networks, which exposes the message to various attacks, and there is no protection for a message that appears on a stolen phone. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| SMS over GSM is also the target of SMS spoofing, which is where a message comes from a party who misidentifies himself as someone else. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| SMS is a subscription service; you can purchase a certain amount of message transfers, after which you are charged for additional messages, usually on a per-byte basis. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The cost on a usage basis can be onerous. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Certain plans allow for unlimited texting. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| While SMS is certainly convenient, you count on getting timely delivery with your message. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| It can take minutes or hours for a message to arrive. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Also, basic SMS is strictly text and allow you to send media files or any other binary content. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Many of the smartphone providers offer upgrade versions of SMS, including the Enhanced Messaging Service EMS allows you to attach sounds, pictures, icons, and even formatted text with your message. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Multimedia Messaging Service MMS supports the sending of audio, video, and even animation with the SMS text. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| (MMS uses a combination of WAP and SMS for its transport.) |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| SMS was initially developed for GSM networks. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Over time, SMS has moved to networks and even has satellite phone network. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Not all texting systems are SMS, even if they appear so. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| RIM BlackBerry and NTT DoCoMo i-mode use SMTP to send short messages. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Other exceptions include NTT DoCoMo ShortMail and J-Phone SkyMail. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Some SMS services go through an SMS gateway. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| This service works by aggregating SMS traffic or using what is called the (Signal System No. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| |NUMBER|) telephony signaling protocols. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| An SMS gateway service works by taking the messages received at the SMSC and sending those messages over aggregated or enhanced networks. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| An SMS gateway is more reliable and faster than SMS itself, so these services can be used in mission-critical notification systems, for businesses, and even in polling or voting. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Examples of some SMS gateways include the Chapter |NUMBER|: Working with Mobile Web Services Direct to SMSC gateway Direct to mobile gateway appliances Skype clients Some GSM e-mail like the M-Mail service Microsoft Outlook and Windows Live Messenger Yahoo! |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Messenger To view a list of SMS gateways, see the following Web |URL| |URL| For most SMS users, their SMS phone number is their mobile phone number. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| However, some SMS services offer a short code as an SMS phone number. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The short code is usually |NUMBER| to |NUMBER| digits in length and often can be reserved so the numbers represent words and phrases. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Many short code numbers provide automatic services. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| For example, when you are given a short code and told to put the word “Haiti” or “Pakistan” in the subject line, sending the SMS to that number may make a donation to the agency of your choice and charged on your phone bill. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Some companies use short codes to narrowcast advertisements. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| They have been used as updating services, subscription list opt-ins or opt-outs, and for many other purposes. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Defining WAP and Other Protocols The Wireless Application Protocol (WAP) is an application-layer network protocol that allows a WAP browser on a mobile device to communicate with a WAP-enabled Web site. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Data is transferred between the two in the form of the Wireless Markup Language and is specially formatted to fit on that mobile device. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Web sites can be composed in WML, or the data can be automatically converted to WML. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| WAP was originally created by the WAP Forum in |NUMBER| but is now part of the Open Mobile Alliance (OMA; |URL| Figure |URL| shows the home page of the Open Mobile Alliance, which is the standards body for many of the protocols described in this chapter. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| WAP has had a mixed history of success. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| It is widely used in Asia, but has had limited success in Europe and the |URL| With the advent of MMS services (described in the preceding section), there has been a broader adoption of WAP over the last couple of years. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| usage has been limited due to limitations in WML (Wireless Markup Language), developer tools, and problems with being able to successfully transmit mobile device characteristics. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| As mobile devices get more capable and with the new versions of the protocols, some of these difficulties are being addressed. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Part Using the Mobile Cloud FIGURE |URL| The Open Mobile Alliance is a standards body administering many mobile Web service protocols. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| WAP |URL| is a protocol suite that consists of a number of different technologies that are designed to work over different wireless networks such as GSM or CDMA. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Essentially, this WAP |URL| serves the role of a gateway. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The WAP |URL| protocol stack from top to bottom includes the Wireless Application Environment A set of application specific markup languages, of which WML is an example Wireless Session Protocol Similar to a compressed version of HTTP Wireless Transaction Protocol A transaction monitoring service based on a mechanism Wireless Transport Layer Security A public-key encryption method that is used for the same purpose as TLS and SSL before it Wireless Datagram Protocol Provides unreliable data transport data formatting Wireless Data Network, GSM, CDMA, or another network type Chapter |NUMBER|: Working with Mobile Web Services The last update for WAP was version |URL| released in |NUMBER|. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Version |URL| uses the lightweight eXtensible Hypertext Markup Language Mobile Profile (XHTML MP) for its modified Web page rendering. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Used with XHTML MP is the WAP CSS Cascading Style Sheet. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| In WAP |URL| HTTP is used for complete transport and the gateway and protocol stack described above is eliminated. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| There is a new specification for XHTML that is part of the release of HTML |NUMBER|. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| WAP Push is a form of WAP added to version |URL| that allows content to be pushed from content providers to mobile clients using a gateway service. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| WAP Push works sending messages that contain the link to the WAP address over a WDP carrier such as GPRS or SMS. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| GSM networks use GPRS and must use SMS. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| When a WAP Push Service Indication (SI) notification is received, the user has the option to download the content using this service. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Figure |URL| shows how the WAP Push system works. |ENDSENT|

|STARTSENT| Contact, calendar, and information on devices often need to be synchronized between multiple systems. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The most commonly used standard for performing synchronization is SyncML (Synchronization Markup Language). |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| All or some the following data types may be synchronized by Bookmarks Calendar Contacts E-mail Files Memos Music Photos SMS Tasks Video SyncML is implemented using a SyncML server or alternatively as a SyncML hosted service. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The client portion of SyncML is either a browser plug-in or client connector software. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Different servers and clients allow for the synchronization of different data types. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Some backup software also uses SyncML. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| The standard is an open platform-independent protocol maintained by the Open Mobile Alliance as part of the Data Synchronization and Device Management group |URL| The SyncML protocol finds support in a number of products from major mobile software and hardware vendors. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| It has the advantage over standard Internet protocols. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| SyncML also can be used to share iCalendar data. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Tables of SyncML servers, services, clients, and plug-ins may be found at |URL| Several proprietary synchronization technologies are in wide use. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Microsoft Exchange and Windows Mobile use a technology called ActiveSync (|URL| that has gone through several development cycles. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Exchange server is so widely used that many other vendors have licensed ActiveSync from Microsoft for use in their mobile mail clients. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| You can find ActiveSync on the Apple iPhone, on certain models of Google Android, in the WebOS operating system developed by Palm and now part of HP, and in Lotus Domino and Novell GroupWise e-mail servers. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Exchange ActiveSync is a push e-mail service. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| An open-source version of ActiveSync called SynCE (|URL| exists. |ENDSENT|
|STARTSENT| Chapter |NUMBER|: Working with Mobile Web Services The sync application Windows Mobile Device Center (previously called ActiveSync) allows a mobile client to synchronize to a desktop or Microsoft Exchange Server. |ENDSENT|

|STARTSENT| Mobile devices present a number of challenges for Web services and Web site designers. |ENDSENT|

|STARTSENT| Some of the methods used to standardize Web services for mobile devices were presented. |ENDSENT|
